abstract: The steamship Jura,from Liverpool on the 21st and Londonderry on the "2d, arrived off Cape Race on Friday afternoon, and a summary of her news is telegraphed. The steamship Sidon, from Liverpool on the 19th and Queenstown on the 20th, arrived at this port yesterday. The advices by these arrivals are five days later, but are of no great importance politically.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Jura,from Liverpool on the 21st and Londonderry on the "2d, arrived off Cape Race on Friday afternoon, and a summary of her news is telegraphed. The steamship Sidon, from Liverpool on the 19th and Queenstown on the 20th, arrived at this port yesterday. The advices by these arrivals are five days later, but are of no great importance politically. There was a feeling of suspenso regarding American affairs, and a desire to hear further news. Rumors of an armistice between the North and South, growing in some manner out of the news relating to Gen. HOOKER taken out by the Persia, had been dispelled by the Glasgow, which arrived out on the 22d. The London papers commented freely on the movement of Gen. HOOKER, and the apparent position of the National army, and generally came to the conclusion that he would suffer a reverse, if not a disastrous defeat. The news of the captures made by the Alabama and Florida on the South American coast had reached England. The reply of President LINCOLN to the address of the Emancipation Society had been received. He states that the address was very gratifying to him, and he expresses friendly feelings toward England. Accounts from Poland continue to represent the revolution as spreading. The Russian amnesty had been utterly refused in all quarters. The advices taken out by the Glasgow had created buoyancy in the Liverpool Cotton market, and prices, which had been declining during the week, nearly recovered. Breadstuffs and Provisions were steady. Consols for money 93 1/2.

abstract: A Party Crisis in
snippet: A Party Crisis in
lead_paragraph: An ordinary party crisis in Canada would not be likely to disturb the balance of power in either world; and would, perhaps, fail to excite any particular emotion beyond a limited provincial circle. But, we take it, that a careful analysis of the Parliamentary upheavals which have been witnessed in Canada, at intervals during the past twelve months, would show something like a growing conflict of interest and of sympathy between the great dependency and its parent country.

abstract: It is very amusing to observe the vigorous and united attempts of the journals in the Copperhead interest to disparage the Loyal State Convention at Utica The Albany Argus and Atlas teems with paragraphs of all shapes and sizes seeking to prove that it was a failure, that nobody was there, that it was an overwhelming McClellan demonstration, &c, &c. If it was so small an affair, why make so much fuss about it? And if it was a McClellan meeting, why abuse it? This excessive anxiety to belittle it, proves that somebody is hurt.

abstract: In response to the call for oranges and lemons, for the sick and wounded soldiers in hospitals at Washington and vicinity, we learn that D.R. MARTIN, Esq., President of the Ocean Bank, and the lady members of his family, (members of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association,) aided by the generous contributions of lady friends, procured sixty boxes of the above-mentioned fruits, which were forwarded on Saturday, Forty more boxes will be forwarded on Tuesday. Mr. JOHN HOEY, of Adams' Express, hearing of the movement, offered the services of Adams' Express to Col. HOWE, the Superintendent of the New-England Rooms, which were accepted, and they will be delivered free of expense to Surgeon-General HAMMOND at Washington.

abstract: a Broken Down Rebel
snippet: a Broken Down Rebel
lead_paragraph: -- JOHN C. BRECKIN RIDGE has been as unfortunate as a General as he formerly was fortunate as a politician. In political service he obtained every honor which he coveted, except the highest; and this, too, while yet a young man. In the rebel army, misfortunes have followed him, and dishonors have been heaped upon him, until now, stung to the quick by the accusations officially made against him by Gen. BRAGG, regarding his conduct at the last battle in which he was an actor, he has written a letter to Richmond, demanding justice and a Court of inquiry. He says that BRAGG's report thoroughly disparages both him and his command -- that BRAGG levels his strictures at his conduct as an officer during all the operations, and that BRAGG, by direct statement and unmistakable innuendo, reflects upon his capacity and conduct. BRECKINRIDGE retorts sharply upon his superior officer in replying to these accusations -- charges him with misrepresentation, injustice and baser crimes, and contends that the failure of his troops to hold their position at the battle of Stone River was due to no fault of theirs or his, but to the fact that BRAGG commanded them to do an impossible thing.

abstract: whatever other changes the war may have brought about in men and things at the South, it has not changed the nature and habits of HENRY A. WISE. We see it stated that he has recently written an abusive letter to Gen. DIX, covering twenty-two closely-written pages. This is nearly a tenth part as long as his average messages when he was Governor. WISE was always the longest-winded writer and orator in the Southern States, not even excepting FOOTE, of Mississippi. He always managed to get a good deal of originality and vituperative rhetoric into his productions, but seldom a grain of common sense. In this respect he evidently holds his own, as Gen. DIX returned his missive with the indorsement that it was ï¿½neither fit to be written or received."

abstract: An important change of programme takes place to-night at Niblo's Garden, where, instead of the ordinary "star" performances, we are to have a new, and according to rumors, good play, produced with new scenery, dresses, and a competent company.
lead_paragraph: An important change of programme takes place to-night at Niblo's Garden, where, instead of the ordinary "star" performances, we are to have a new, and according to rumors, good play, produced with new scenery, dresses, and a competent company. The change will, we hope, be acceptable to a large number of the patrons of the establishment. Mr. JOHN BROUGHAM is the author of the novelty in question, which is called the �Duke's Motto.� It has met with the greatest success in London, and is still being played there. All the resources of Niblo's will be exhausted in bringing the work before our public, and Mr. COLLINS and Mr. WHEATLEY sustain the principal parts. At Mr. WALLACK's theatre the comedy of �A Bold Stroke for a Husband� will be played for the last time this season. Novelties are still announced as in preparation at this house, although the season must be drawing rapidly to a close. At the Winter Garden Mile, VESTVALI's opera troupe will give a performance, and at Barnum's Museum there will be levees by TOM THUMB and his wife, little MINNIE WARREN and Commodore NUTT, besides the usual attractions and entertainments in other parts of the establishment.

abstract: Democratic State Committee's Albany Meeting and Resolutions
snippet: Democratic State Committee's Albany Meeting and Resolutions
lead_paragraph: The Democratic State Committee has held another meeting at Albany, in order to define, over again, the position of the Democratic party. The progress of public sentiment sweeps their party landmarks away so rapidly as to render absolutely necessary these reiterated endeavors to keep the party together by constructing new platforms from time to time, as exigencies may require. Two incidents called the Committee together at the present time: the first was the Loyal State Convention at Utica, which ignored all party divisions, and rallied patriots of every name and of every party to the supreme work of saving the country, and the second was the approaching Peace Convention, to convene in this City day after to-morrow. The Democratic State Committee found its party in danger of an attack both in front and rear. Its loyal members were likely to join the Union League, and its peace element seemed in danger of seeking the embrace of FERNANDO WOOD and Company. The Committee had, therefore, the double duty of erecting defences in both directions.

abstract: The telegrams continue to report that the insurrection is increasing in various directions. Between the 8th 10th of May, an insurrection broke out at five different points of Volhynia. The insurgents confined in Galacia had all refused to avail themselves of the amnesty, in spite of the solicitations of the Russian agents. The insurrection had broken out in four districts of Podolia. The peasantry remains quiet. The insurgent corps have made their appearance in the districts of Wladmir and Luck.

abstract: Semi-official advices from Gen. GRANT'S army to the 26th of May have reached the Government. At that time the condition of affairs in the rear of Vicksburgh was mainly unchanged. On the evening of the 25th Gen. PEMBERTON, commanding the rebel forces, asked for two and a half ...
lead_paragraph: Semi-official advices from Gen. GRANT'S army to the 26th of May have reached the Government. At that time the condition of affairs in the rear of Vicksburgh was mainly unchanged. On the evening of the 25th Gen. PEMBERTON, commanding the rebel forces, asked for two and a half hours' truce to bury his dead, which was granted him. There appears to have been no severe fighting since Monday last -- our forces since that time having been engaged in bombarding the rebel stronghold. A dispatch received in Cincinnati states that most of the river batteries had been silenced, and the gunboats were engaged in shelling the rest.

abstract: CHURCH OPENING. -- The opening of the Church of the Immaculate Conception, corner of Erie and Seventh sts., took place yesterday. The Church was dedicated about a year since, but the interior was not completed until recently. There was high mass in the forenoon, and a sermon by Rev. Dr. CUMMINGS, and vespers with a discourse by Rev. Mr. BYRNE in the evening. Right Rev. Bishop BAYLEY was present. The edifice was filled, and the receipts by admission were very large. This is one of the largest and finest Catholic churches in the State.

abstract: It is now fifteen days since the battle of Big Black Bridge, and fourteen since the investment of Vicksburgh. With the first of these events, Gen. JOHNSTON saw the desperateness of the rebel situation at Vicksburgh, and the necessity of the utmost energy in concentrating all possible troops to flank GRANT, and, if possible, to raise the siege.
lead_paragraph: It is now fifteen days since the battle of Big Black Bridge, and fourteen since the investment of Vicksburgh. With the first of these events, Gen. JOHNSTON saw the desperateness of the rebel situation at Vicksburgh, and the necessity of the utmost energy in concentrating all possible troops to flank GRANT, and, if possible, to raise the siege. We have had no special information as to his success during these fifteen days in bringing up reinforcements -- though the dispatch said to have been sent by him to PEMBERTON assured the latter that in fifteen days he would aid him with a hundred thousand men. His facilities for bringing forward men are not very great, as the railroads are few, ricketty and much damaged by our raids, and the places from which reinforcements can be obtained are very distant. We have the evidence of eye-witnesses that troops have been brought from Charleston, which is distant from Jackson 767 miles; and if they have been brought from Charleston, they have doubtless also been brought from Savannah, Mobile, and all the garrisoned positions in the Gulf States, if not from North Carolina. We have also had numerous rumors that reinforcements were being got from BRAGG's army; and though the shortest line of communication between Tullahoma and Jackson may not be available, yet it would be easier to take troops from Chattanooga by the Western and Atlantic Railroad to Atlanta, and thence to Jackson, than to transport them from the Atlantic coast. They would not dare, however, to take them from BRAGG, unless they were fully convinced that ROSECRANS, did not contemplate motion, as they doubtless are convinced that it is not contemplated by HENTER.

abstract: Unofficial dispatches were received here today from the army of Gen. GRANT dated on the 26th. They represent that there had been no material change in affairs there since the 25th. abstract: All the players, except Messrs. SEEREITER, FOX and NELWS, were in town on Saturday evening, when meeting was held in which the above players were represented by proxy. A code of rules were drawn up and signed, after which the parties drew for numbers to represent their respective positions at the tournament, which resulted as follows: No. 1, Kavanagh; 2, Tieman; 3, Seereiter; 4, Foley; 5, Goldthwait; 6, Deery; 7, Fox; 8, Esteppe; 9, Nelms. It was afterward agreed that three games of 500 each should be played by the six first mentioned this evening. Thus the bait opens with KAVANAGH against TIEMAN, SEEREITER against FOLEY, and GOLDTHWAIT against DEZRY. All the players are to be on hand promptly, and the game will begin at Irving Hall at [???] o'clock.

abstract: Last night, at about 9 o'clock, PHILLIP McDERMOTT, a compositor on the World newspaper, fell from the fourth story of the rear of the building occupied by that establishment, and was instantly killed. He was believed to have been sitting or reclining on the window-sill at the time of the accident. In his fail he loosened a sign just below the window, and also struck another sign two stories below -- both signs falling to the sidewalk. McDERMOTT was newly married and lived at No. 77 Nevins-street, Brooklyn. He was formerly a compositor on the TIMES.

abstract: FUNERAL OF A SOLDIER. The remains of the late Lieut. BLOOMFIELD, of Company E, Fourteenth Brooklyn regiment, were yesterday consigned to their last resting place in Cypress Hills Cemetery. The funeral ceremonies were conducted at No. 9 Libertystreet, by the Rev. Mr. DE HASS, who preached a fitting and eloquent discourse on the occasion. The deceased was wounded in the last assault upon Fredericksburgh, and died from the effects of the injuries then sustained.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF A SOLDIER. -- The remains of the late Lieut. BLOOMFIELD, of Company E, Fourteenth Brooklyn regiment, were yesterday consigned to their last resting place in Cypress Hills Cemetery. The funeral ceremonies were conducted at No. 9 Libertystreet, by the Rev. Mr. DE HASS, who preached a fitting and eloquent discourse on the occasion. The deceased was wounded in the last assault upon Fredericksburgh, and died from the effects of the injuries then sustained. He was a corporal when the regiment first left home, and participated in every battle in which it was engaged. He was promoted for good conduct and bravery. The remains were escorted to the cemetery by the members of the Fourteenth now in the city, the exempts of the same organization, and the Twenty-third regiment, National Guard, accompanied by a very large concourse of citizens. A band of music preceded the military. The police, under charge of Sergt. BOYD, escorted the cortege to the Four Mile House, on Fulton-avenue, where stages were in readiness to convey the remains and members of the regiment to the cemetery.

abstract: ALLEGED FORGERY OF A CHECK. -- OFFICER JACOBS, of the First Precinct, yesterday arrested a well-dressed young man, who gave hit name as EDGA??? SMITH, He is charged with having forged the signature of Messrs. STRONG & BROTHER, of No. 291 Broadway, to a check on the Park Bank for $1,856. The check was made payable to the order of MANUEL HORN, dated May 27, 1863, and indorsed "ALBERT HORN." SMITH presented the check for payment at the office of Mr. ROBINSON. No. 47 Exchange-place. There were some suspicions as to its genuineness, and a clerk was sent out to make inquiries. During his absence SMITH exhibited much uneasiness, and us soon as he regained possession of the check, he attempted to escape. In his flight he threw away the check. Both the accused and the evidence of his guilt were afterward secured, and taken before Justice CONNOLLY at the Tombs. SMITH there stated that he was a student of law, and the son of a prominent physician in the upper part of the City, whose, name and residence were given in the course of the examination. It is proper to state that the name of Smith is an assumed one. Just as the officer was in the act of seizing his prisoner, the latter pulled from his face a pair of false whiskers, and threw them into a sink. Justice CONNOLLY committed the accused for a further examination.

abstract: There is a report of the crossing of the Arkansas River, near Fort Gibson, by a body of rebels, on the 19th ult. They were driven back with slight loss, but are said to be the advance guard of the main body of STERLING PRICE's army, 11,000 strong, massed in the vicinity of the crossing. Another crossing will be attempted, in force, if the story is in all its parts reliable, and we may soon look for trouble in Missouri.

abstract: We publish letters from our correspondent with GRANT, giving an account of operations from the capture of Jackson, of which we have heretofore had details, up to the 24th ult., Sunday of last week.
lead_paragraph: We publish letters from our correspondent with GRANT, giving an account of operations from the capture of Jackson, of which we have heretofore had details, up to the 24th ult., Sunday of last week. From these our readers can gain some idea of the work performed by Gen. GRANT, and of the bravery and perseverance of his troops. Since the date of these letters, we have telegraphic news that our troops had made three assaults upon Vicksburgh -- one of them with a body of 20,000 men, led by Gen. SHERMAN -- but in none of them did we achieve our object. This brings our advices down to Wednesday night last, the 27th. GRANT is evidently giving the rebels no pause, but, in his characteristic style, is ceaselessly assailing their works. Our readers will find encouragement in our correspondent's letters that GRANT will ultimately, and probably speedily, bring his campaign to a glorious issue.

abstract: An Abolition View of the War
snippet: An Abolition View of the War
lead_paragraph: We copy from yesterday's Tribune a letter from Hon. M.F. CONWAY, which is intended to define his position in regard to the war. It is a "representative" letter and sets forth the sentiments of a very active if not a very large class of men, concerning the objects and aims for which the war is carried on. Mr. CONWAY recognizes the practical unanimity of men of all parties in declaring that the Union must be maintained -- whatever may become of Slavery or anything else. He acknowledges that ion this point Republicans, Democrats, and to a considerable extent Anti Slavery men, are substantially agreed. But for his own part he protests against it. Unless Slavery is destroyed he does not wish the Union preserved. If Slavery is destroyed, he does not object to the Union; but the abolition of Slavery is with him the main consideration; it is for that he would have the war carried on; -- the preservation of the Union is a secondary matter altogether.

abstract: We hope  THE PRESIDENT'S FOOT NEEDED. We hope  the President will at once "put his foot down" upon a quarrel which is raging between certain officers of our army at Port Royal under Gen. HUNTER and certain officers of our army at Newbern, under Gen. FOSTER  and which, if it does not extend to the chief officers in command of the respective Departments, looks very much as if it did.
lead_paragraph: -- We hope THE PRESIDENT'S FOOT NEEDED. We hope the President will at once "put his foot down" upon a quarrel which is raging between certain officers of our army at Port Royal under Gen. HUNTER and certain officers of our army at Newbern, under Gen. FOSTER -- and which, if it does not extend to the chief officers in command of the respective Departments, looks very much as if it did. forcing HUNTER some months ago, left the Department a qesstion of precedence, HUNTER retained part of his troops; but when, latterly, FOSTER was besieged at Little Washington, HUNTER sent a brigade to his relief. HUNTER now wants that brigade back, while FOSTER wants back with him all the troops he took down to South Carolina. The desire in both cases is natural enough; but such matters are to be settled by the orders of the President, and not by personal desires, natural or unnatural.

abstract: Democratic Sentiment on the War
snippet: Democratic Sentiment on the War
lead_paragraph: It is becoming more and more evident every day that, to all practical intents and purposes, the people of the North are unanimous in support of the war for the preservation of the Union. There has been a very great change in the public mind on this subject within the last six or eight months. There were then thousands and tens of thousands who believed that separation was preferable to a continuance of the war. Very few would declare this sentiment openly, but they were for stepping the war at all hazards, and "letting the Union slide." During the political canvas in this State, last Fall, this was to a very great extent the tone and language of the organs and orators of the Democratic party. But now the same persons are open and explicit in favor of continuing the war, unless the Union can be saved by negotiating terms of peace.

abstract: Nationality and Great States Opposed to Rebellion
snippet: Nationality and Great States Opposed to Rebellion
lead_paragraph: The American rebellion is an anomaly in the spirit of the age, not only because it is a movement for Slavery instead of Freedom, but because it seeks a division instead of a union of people of the same blood. Everywhere else the nationality of race is the great idea. It is deemed the almost indispensable condition of national well-being.

abstract: a piteous appeal of
snippet: a piteous appeal of
lead_paragraph: The fortunes of the Memphis Appeal have been varied and dismal. When our forces took Memphis, the Appeal was removed to Grenada, Miss., where it was known as the Memphis-Grenada Appeal. When GRANT last year threatened Grenada, the Appeal was carried to Jackson, and was known as the Memphis-Grenada-Jackson Appeal. When, in the course of events, on the 14th of last month, our troops captured Jackson, the Appeal once more set out to seek a place of safety, and our correspondent writes that it is next to be set up at Atlanta, Ga. We predict, however, that it will not long be safe in Atlanta, for when ROSECRANS moves he is not likely to stop, till he gets into Georgia, and, perhaps, gets his guns within easy range of the Appeal office. The backward and downward movements of the Appeal furnish a curious sign of the retreating footsteps of the rebellion, of which it has been such a fast supporter.

abstract: The steamship Sheldrake arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana, on the 25th ult. She brings an extra of the Diario dc la Marina, issued just before she sailed, announcing the arrival from Vera Cruz of the French war-steamer Darien, with important dispatches from Gen. FOREY, the French Commander in Mexico, to the Emperor NAPOLEON. These dispatches are said to contain the announcement of the occupation of Puebla by the French forces, preceded by the unconditional surrender of Gen. ORTEGA, with 23 other Mexican Generals, and 900 other officers, and 17,000 men. It appears, according to the account which has reached us, that on May 8, Gen. COMONFORT, commanding the Mexica force outside the city, attacked the French forces in the rear, his object being to favor the entrance into the city of a convoy of provisions and ammunition. He was defeated, however, losing 2,500 men and a part of his artillery and equipment, and his object was frustrated. Gen. FOREY received scme heavy artillery, with which lie opened upon the principal Mexican fort on the 16th, and succeeded in breaching it. An assault was then ordered, when further resistance on the part of the Mexicans ceased, and the place was surrendered as above stated. It is further stated that on the 20th a division of the French army left for the City of Mexico. Puebla was to be garrisoned by a sufficient force to protect it from the guerrillas, and the test of the army was to follow toward the Capital immediately.

abstract: It is not merely in its immediate relation to the reduction of Vicks burgh that the capture of Haines' Bluff by Gen. GRANT was vitally important, but as opening a feasible line of communication between our army and its base and depots of supplies. When our troops crossed to Bruins burgh, on this side of the Mississippi, their supplies had to be brought from Milliken's Bend, eighty miles up the river; and for weeks previous to crossing, every available hoof was kept ceaselessly busy in hauling forward supplies. When GRANT set out on his march from the river to Jackson, his army carried four days' rations; but he could not afford to leave forces behind to guard his line, and so boldly pushed on his army, depending in great measure upon the country for supplies until such time as he should capture Vicksburgh, or cut his way to the Mississippi above Vicksburgh.

abstract: A grand romantic drama, called the "Duke's Motto," was produced here on Monday night. It is an adaptation of a French piece, made with the consent and cooperation of the author, and now playing in London with the greatest success. We shall not attempt to describe the plot The briefest summary of the incidents would alone fill a column, and even a list of the depths and casualties would occupy more space than we propose to devote to the entire work. The here of the piece, Capt. Lagardere, is an amiable swordsman, who, in the pursuit of virtue, finds it essential to assail the vitals of almost every one he meets. A single illustration of his character will be sufficient. At the close of the prologue he makes a vow to kill every living being then on the stage, and before the end of the play he keeps his word. Fortunately, a sturdy and attractive race of females has in the meantime grown up, so that the gaps made in the dramatic ranks from time to lime are not so much remarked as otherwise they would be; and the new characters being in their prime by the third act, there is, not-withstanding the heavy mortality, a good muster at the end. The merit of the dramatist is discovered in the fact that the audience fully indorses the acts of the Captain, regarding him as the champion of innocence, and rejoicing when he turns up, as he always does, just in time for the slaughter. The character-contrasts, situations and incidents by which this is effected, are frequently of the most startling kind, and in every Instance display rare ingenuity. As a consequence, the "Duke's Motto" is a highly elaborate and exciting drama of the sensation school; violating every rule of probability, but beeping the audience in a state of breathless anticipation from beginning to end. It must be added, too, that there is nothing unwholesome in the way this is done.

A single illustration of his character will be sufficient. At the close of the prologue he makes a vow to kill every living being then on the stage, and before the end of the play he keeps his word. Fortunately, a sturdy and attractive race of females has in the meantime grown up, so that the gaps made in the dramatic ranks from time to lime are not so much remarked as otherwise they would be; and the new characters being in their prime by the third act, there is, not-withstanding the heavy mortality, a good muster at the end. The merit of the dramatist is discovered in the fact that the audience fully indorses the acts of the Captain, regarding him as the champion of innocence, and rejoicing when he turns up, as he always does, just in time for the slaughter. The character-contrasts, situations and incidents by which this is effected, are frequently of the most startling kind, and in every Instance display rare ingenuity. As a consequence, the "Duke's Motto" is a highly elaborate and exciting drama of the sensation school; violating every rule of probability, but beeping the audience in a state of breathless anticipation from beginning to end. It must be added, too, that there is nothing unwholesome in the way this is done.

lead_paragraph: -- We observe that Ex-Mayor WOOD is announced to speak first in the main hall where the Peace Convention is to be held, and then at each of the five stands which are to be erected outside. The Ex-Mayor certainly does not mean to be lost sight of at this Convention. The managers of the Democratic party at Albany have for some months past been unable to see him: he has not been conspicuous at their Conventions, committee meetings or other congregations. With all his modesty, FERNANDO does not quite like to be entirety overlooked, and he has taken all proper precautions against such a calamity in the present instance.

lead_paragraph: The match between these fine horses for $2,000, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, took place yesterday afternoon on the Course of the Fashion Pleasure Ground Association. Fillingham is a splendid brown stallion, and was the favorite of the turfmen, who bet two to one that he would beat the famous grey gelding Rockingham; and so well satisfied with him were they, that even after he had lost the first beat by a series of bad breaks, by which he lost a dozen lengths in the first half-mile -- which was made by Rockingham in 1:14 1/2 -- they did not alter their opinion of his superior speed and endurance, and the extraordinary burst of speed by which Filling reduced the space in the last half-mile to a length and a half fully justified them in their course.

lead_paragraph: -- Some folks imagine that the rebels, if defeated at Vicksburgh, may seize some other position at some unthought-of point on the Mississippi, and that we will have as much labor and bloodshed at the new point as we have had to get Columbus, Memphis and Vicksburgh. Even if PEMBERTON's army were captured, it may be thought that the forces under JOHNSTON would manage to reach the river with artillery, and quickly erect another stronghold.

abstract: A collision occurred this evening between the 2 o' clock train from New-York and the 6 o'clock freight and accommadation train for New-York, on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, at Fish House, three miles above Camden. Both locomotives, and several cars, were crushed, but fortunately only two persons were injured THOMAS HARTMAN, of this City, and a newsboy, slightly. The 2 o'clock train was thirteen minutes behind time, but had the right track.

abstract: "The telegraphic news of yesterday announced that BANKS had crossed his army at Bayou Sara. This is about ten miles above Port Hudson. His object is to get behind the post and carry it by a land attack. This movement is designed to finish the work started by GRANT, and clear the Mississippi. A few days will tell the story. The next news will probably be of an assault upon Port Hudson."

abstract: Early and Large Draft Necessary
snippet: Early and Large Draft Necessary
lead_paragraph: We trust that the Administration will spare no pains to complete the preparations for the conscription by the earliest day possible, and that the conscription when made will be on an extensive scale. The great mistake of the war thus far has been the endeavor to wage it with an insufficient force. It requires no professional eye to see that, during the first year, the rebel army positively outnumbered our own; and through the second year we have had at no time a material preponderance; -- for the calls that were made by the President last Summer were nearly balanced by the universal conscription ordered soon after by the rebel Congress. The expiration of the service of the nine months men and of the two years men is fast reducing our numbers to a figure actually below that of the rebel forces. Until this relative strength of the armies is vastly changed, so that we shall have a very great numerical preponderance of soldiers, this war will continue to drag on without result.
headline: {'main': 'An Early and Large Conscription.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Early and Large Conscription.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Removal from Department of the South
snippet: Removal from Department of the South
lead_paragraph: -- It is announced from Washington that Gen. HUNTER has been relieved from the command of the Department of the South, and that he is succeeded by Gen. GILMORE. We have as yet no statement of the reasons for this change. Whether Gen. HUNTER is relieved at his own request, or in consequence of some failure in duty, we are not aware. His letter to JEFF. DAVIS, which we published yesterday morning, was in some respects a singular production, and may have had something to do with his displacement. It is dated April 20. The first part of it threatens to execute the "rebel of highest rank" in his possession for every negro in the employ of the Government who may be executed or sold into slavery by the rebels. This may be justified, perhaps, on the ground of necessary retaliation. But Gen. HUNTER also informs Mr. DAVIS that, unless he immediately revokes an order which he issued in August last, directing the execution of all negroes who may be taken prisoners; he will "at once cause the execution of every rebel officer and every rebel slaveholder" in his possession. This certainly is a strange threat for a Commanding General to make. We do not know that Gen. HUNTER has ever attempted to put it in execution, but it is quite possible that it may have had something to do with his removal. The Government could not permit an officer to announce or initiate any such policy as this, nor is it at all likely that they would permit it to pass without notice.

abstract: The prompt response to the ap  peal recently made for contributions of lemons with which to form acidulated beverages for the invalid soldiers in the Virginia and Washington hospitals, is another proof of the anxiety of people generally to do what they can in the way of patriotic and humane work for the benefit of our army. Over a hundred boxes have within the last four days ...
lead_paragraph: -- The prompt response to the ap peal recently made for contributions of lemons with which to form acidulated beverages for the invalid soldiers in the Virginia and Washington hospitals, is another proof of the anxiety of people generally to do what they can in the way of patriotic and humane work for the benefit of our army. Over a hundred boxes have within the last four days been forwarded to Washington, freely contributed and freely transmitted to the bedsides of the wounded. We hope this will not be a spasmodic movement. The Summer heats are just beginning, and there, will be a steady and earnest demand for this fruit for months to come, even if our wounded in the hospitals should not be vastly increased by the battles likely to be fought in June, July and August. It would perhaps be well if there were a mixed Committee of ladies and gentlemen formed to attend permanently to this little matter during the Summer. It would be a pretty and a Christian labor.

abstract: Discussions on Rebellion Fruitless
snippet: Discussions on Rebellion Fruitless
lead_paragraph: There is a story told of a certain athletic wag that he laid a wager with a friend that he could throw him across a tolerably wide river. The friend submitted himself to the experiment, and, finding himself soused into the water about four feet from the bank, swam ashore and claimed the stakes. "No," replied the other, "I am going to try again; I know I shall succeed in the end." The anecdote, if not true, is well found, and it illustrates admirably the real nature of the programme propounded by the party who think we can settle all our differences with the South by talking the matter over with them in convention. They ask us to suspend the operations of our fleets and armies, give the Southern people time to elect delegates and elect them ourselves, and then proceed to drafting resolutions, compromises and guarantees, and making speeches, and taking votes.

abstract: Official advices from Gen. GRANT's Army to the 29th ult. were yesterday received by the Government. They inidicate that there was no change in the condition of affairs at Vicksburgh, but that the prospects were encouraging. A dispatch from Memphis brings us unofficial advices to the 28th, which state that on the 26th the gunboat Cincinnati was sunk by the fire from the rebel batteries, with a reported loss of over twenty killed and wounded.
lead_paragraph: Official advices from Gen. GRANT's Army to the 29th ult. were yesterday received by the Government. They inidicate that there was no change in the condition of affairs at Vicksburgh, but that the prospects were encouraging. A dispatch from Memphis brings us unofficial advices to the 28th, which state that on the 26th the gunboat Cincinnati was sunk by the fire from the rebel batteries, with a reported loss of over twenty killed and wounded. Several of our men captured by the rebels had been paroled -- it is said on account of a scarcity of food. A more detailed report of the statements of a Staff officer, mentioned yesterday, has been received. From this it appears that Gen. GRANT is engaged in building works, with the view of capturing the place by regular approaches, and that some of the rebel works are being mined. A portion of Gen. BANKS' forces are said to have reinforced Gen. GRANT. The rebels report that Gen. BANKS has landed his forces at Bayon Sara, ten miles above Port Hudson, with the intention of attacking that place in the rear.

abstract: Southern and English Apostles of Slavery
snippet: Southern and English Apostles of Slavery
lead_paragraph: We hope that the London Times, which has been much given to the republication of Confederate boasts of their policy and prowess in war, will find room for the article from the Richmond Examiner which we gave in these columns yesterday. The rebel organ, after felicitating itself and its friends on the martial glory won by the Confederacy, which, it dedeclares, has compelled a reluctant world to respect and finally to "love" it, proceeds to expound the political and social principles upon which the Confederacy is based. These principles, it holds, will be regarded as established, to the acquiescence of mankind and with the approval of Heaven, in the establishment of the independence of the Southern Confederacy.

abstract: Ex-Mayor WOOD'S Peace Convention yesterday was, in many respects, a decided success. It was a large gathering--one of the largest recently held in the City, and its proceedings were marked by energy, directness and a fair degree of enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: Ex-Mayor WOOD'S Peace Convention yesterday was, in many respects, a decided success. It was a large gathering -- one of the largest recently held in the City, and its proceedings were marked by energy, directness and a fair degree of enthusiasm. In one important particular it surpassed all similar meetings hitherto held, -- we mean in its open, straightforward, avowed sympathy with the principles and the cause of the Secessionists.

abstract: At the session of the New-York Baptist Association, now convened in this City, a very interesting letter was read by Rev. J.R. STEWARD, Pastor of the First Baptist Mariner's Church, in which it was stated that the place of worship previously occupied ...
lead_paragraph: At the session of the New-York Baptist Association, now convened in this City, a very interesting letter was read by Rev. J.R. STEWARD, Pastor of the First Baptist Mariner's Church, in which it was stated that the place of worship previously occupied had been disposed of, on account or its ineligible location, and the commodious church edifice corner of Henry and Oliver streets had been purchased; that a debt of $13,000 had been incurred, which amount, having been divided into one hundred and thirty parts, was already diminished by $4,000. An earnest desire was expressed that speedily the entire indebtedness might be canceled, and the valuable property secured forever to the cause of the sailor. A worthier object could scarcely be presented to the benevolence of the public, and it is hoped that such a response will be made at once to the call for funds as shall enable this working Church to prosecute still more extensively its mission of love.

abstract: The steamship Persia arrived at this port yesterday morning, with advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 23d ult., and Queenstown on the 24th. Considerable excitement existed in England regarding the latest reported depredations of the Alabama It appears that the cargoes of at least three of the vessels destroyed on the South American coast were British property, and sufficiently attested to be such. Loud calls were being made upon the British Government to take instant action in the matter, and the impression was that these doings of the Alabama would have consequences not thought of by her pirate Captain. The news of Gen. HOOKER's withdrawal across the Rappahannock had reached England, and the London journals variously comment upon the result of his brief campaign. They find no promise in it of a speedy close of the war. The story of recruiting in Ireland, brought out by the Jura, is exploded, the alleged agent empowered to carry it on having been found to be an imposter. The Polish revolution appears to be growing more and more formidable, and a report was current in Vienna that the Russian Government had called Upon Prussia to be ready with a military force to assist in putting it down. Several successes of the Revolutionists are reported. There had been a slight advance in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were steady. Controls were quoted at 93 1/2@33 [???] for money.

abstract: Our Key West correspondent gives a lively picture of the rapidly growing importance of that town and naval station, and of the large amount of Prize Court business continually being transacted there. At the date of his writing a week ago, upward of forty prize vessels had accumulated in the port, though they were being condemned at the rate of two per week. Among others, the notable case of the British prize steamer Dolphin has just been settled by her condemnation. On board were found concealed a large quantity of Enfield rifles and sabres, put up in packages and marked "Hardware."

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Eagle, which left Havana on the 30th ult., we have advices from Vera Cruz to the l9th, which  do not confirm the report of the capture of Puebla by the French. No such intelligence had reached Vera Cruz at that time.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Eagle, which left Havana on the 30th ult., we have advices from Vera Cruz to the l9th, which do not confirm the report of the capture of Puebla by the French. No such intelligence had reached Vera Cruz at that time. The French [???]-steamer Darien left Vera Cruz on the 20th -- [???] must have put to tea immediately after the dispatches from Gen. FOREY were placed on [???] The Siglo, published in Havana, doubts the report of the capture, and says, if it occurred on the 17th, the news could not have reached [???] Cruz in time to be dispatched by the Darien [???] the 20th. Our correspondent's letter contains [???] official details of the siege, which certainly [???] indicate any intention on the part of OR[???] to capitulate in any event. The Egyptian soldiers in the employ of the French Government had been guilty of atrocities at a rancho in the vicinity of Vera Cruz. Several families were plundered, [???] nine persons were killed, and seven [???] men, women and children, were wounded, some of whom afterward died. The murderers were arrested by the French authorities, and put [???] by Court-martial.

abstract: Intemperate Patriotism at the West
snippet: Intemperate Patriotism at the West
lead_paragraph: Unless we are greatly mistaken, the Government will very soon find it necessary to check the intemperate patriotism of Gen. BURNSIDE in his mode of dealing with disaffected persons and Presses in the loyal States. Whether the powers which he claims to exercise over freedom of speech and of the Press do actually belong to his office or not, it is very clear that they should never he intrusted to any man whose zeal outruns his judgment. An over-zealous friend will often do ten times more harm by restless and injudicious meddling than an open enemy; and in the exercise of powers which, however necessary they may be, are always odious, an excessive prudence is always preferable to a headlong and reckless temper. We have no doubt that Gen. BURNSIDE thinks he is rendering the country an essential service, in suppressing the Chicago Times and in forbidding the circulation of the New-York World within his lines; and we have just as little doubt that he is utterly mistaken. He will very speedily find that he is multiplying ten-fold the very evil he seeks to extirpate. It is very rarely that a military man can be found who is capable of understanding what public opinion is, or who can be made to comprehend that the Press has any other rights than those which he may be pleased to confer upon it. We do not know that we should gain much on either point by appealing from the camp to the Government; but our interest in the welfare of the country impels us to risk the experiment of counseling President LINCOLN to put a check upon Gen. BURNSIDE's super-serviceable and dangerous proceedings as speedily as possible.

abstract: Seldom have there been such hot-headed and bloodthirsty sentiments uttered as at the Peace meeting last night. Threats and defiances were flung at the Government, slander and falsehood were heaped upon the Army, and a carnival of war and bloodshed in our own midst was invited -- in the name of Peace. It was evident that these men were not apostles of peace -- but what they aimed at was a transfer of the war. If such men as WOOD could carry out their original programme of cooperating with the rebellion -- if they could secure the transfer of HOOKER's army to New-York, of ROSECRANS' to Cincinnati, and of GRANT's to Chicago -- if they could raise the seige of Vicksburgh, compel the evacuation of Murfreesboro, and expose Washington to JEFF. DAVIS -- if they could secure the success of the rebels and the subjugation of the North -- their chief and only object in advocating peace would be achieved.

abstract: We understand that dis  patches have been received by French officials in this City from Mexico, confirming the reported capture of Puebla by the French army. abstract: SIR: I have been desired by my legal advisers to reserve any public reply I might have to the calumnies in circulation concerning me until Mr. JORDAN'S case appeared before the tribunals; but I cannot endure any further delay in publishing the following statement. I have no wish to conceal or disguise ...
lead_paragraph: SIR: I have been desired by my legal advisers to reserve any public reply I might have to the calumnies in circulation concerning me until Mr. JORDAN'S case appeared before the tribunals; but I cannot endure any further delay in publishing the following statement. I have no wish to conceal or disguise any imprudence I may have committed, but I deny most indignantly the guilty imputations and disgraceful acts laid to my charge. In July, 1861, Mr. and Mrs. JORDAN arrived in London from New-Orleans, and from that time until the Summer of 1862 they were received on the most intimate footing in my family. It soon became apparent that they lived very unhappily in consequence, as Mrs. JORDAN told my wife, of a connexion which her husband had formed with another lady, a matter which subsequently became notorious. In May, 1862, Mrs. JORDAN left her home, and sought refuge in the house of a friend. I was the means of inducing her to return, and of effecting a reconciliation. In June I opened Drury-lane Theatre, and by Mr. JORDAN's desire I gave his wife an engagement; I did so at the suggestion also of Mrs. BOUGIOAULT, who entertained sympathy for her position, and requested me to pay her every attention in my power. This engagement Mr. JORDAN stated at the trial was without his consent and against his wish -- that he was opposed to it and to any intimacy with me at this time. This is wholly untrue. During the season he came almost nightly behind the scenes, and sat with me and my friends in my room, dined at my house, and exhibited every evidence of intimacy and confidence. After the performances I usually gave them seats in my carriage, and left them at their door in passing. When he did not come I invariably escorted her in my carriage to her door. This continued until the end of July, when I heard that he had expressed some suspicions respecting my relations with the lady. I immediately begged her to resign her engagement, and she consented to do so. On the following day she informed me that Mr. JORDAN refused to allow her to leave the theatre, alleging that he was at the time without any permanent engagement, and she must stay where she was. Subsequently to this Mr. JORDAN continued to visit the theatre as usual, sought my society, dined at my house, I took them borne in my carriage as before, Mr. JORDAN generally preferring to ride on the box; and in his absence I escorted her, as it had been my custom to do. I regret to say I did not tell Mrs. BOUCICAULT of these suspicions respecting me, as I did not wish to give her anxiety or trouble at the time, and I did not think them seriously entertained. A few weeks after this I was informed by the lady that after a dispute, unhappily not unfrequent, her husband had ordered her to leave his lodgings, as he felt convinced of her guilty relations with me. She begged him not to cast that opprobrium upon her, or to give her the means to go to America, where her parents resided. He refused it, and told her to seek what assistance she wanted from me. On learning of this, I wrote to Mr. JORDAN, remonstrating with him on his conduct, but assuring him that if he persisted in it, I neither could nor would allow his wife to be reduced to want; that he left me no alternative but to retain her la the theatre, but if she preferred to return to her parents, that I would give her the means to do so. I added that I did this after consulting with my wife, and had written to inform him of my intentions lest my motives might be misrepresented or misconstrued. To this letter I received no answer. By my advice Mrs. JORDAN, on leaving her husband, went to apartments in Pall-mall, where he and she ha') previously lodged. She wrote to her husband to inform him where she was to be found. I continued, as before, to escort her to her door nightly after the performances. I did so without secrecy, in my own carriage, and as publicly as I could. This was my first imprudence. Mr. JORDAN had, it seems, been watching night after night in the hope of seeing me enter the house, but had been disappointed. On the night in question she had begged me to lend her some books; so, after leaving her door, I drove round to my chambers in King-street, St. James', and returned immediately with the works. I had scarcely entered the hall when I heard a Knock at the door. Presuming it was one of the lodgers in the house, and fearing my presence even in the hall might cause some remark, I withdrew to let them pass. Mr. JORDAN entered. He showed neither anger nor excitement, and exhibited no violence whatever; had he done so I should have followed him into his wife's room, toward which he went. His remark was: "I only desire to see Mr. BOUCICAULT, that he may be identified," or words to that effect. I was unaware of the circumstances that followed, and that Col. GIBBON or any one else had been mixed up in the affair until after Mr. JORDAN had been removed. I am quite aware how injudicious and imprudent my conduct was under the circumstances, and, in my desire to shield the lady's reputation, and avoid, if possible, a public scandal on my own account, I contrived to make matters much worse than they need have appeared. Mrs. BOUCICAULT had been ill for some weeks previously, but, on her recovery, I told her candidly what had occurred, and by her conduct toward Mrs. JORDAN subsequently she desired to exhibit her disbelief in the scandal which then became only too notorious. Shortly after this Mrs. JORDAN returned to America, and I afforded her the means to do so. These are the facts for which I have been so severely reprehended. Mr. JORDAN brought an action against Col. GIBBON in order that a scandalous story might go forth to the public, as it has done, without investigation or defence. This trial was not, nor was it intended to be, against the nominal defendant; it was against me, and so contrived that I might suffer all the odium without even the opportunity of reply. If Mr. JORDAN were injured at all it was by me, and I alone was the proper defendant against whom an action might have been brought. I deny the charges brought against me, and I defy Mr. JORDAN to prove them.

lead_paragraph: Of course, we do not give any credit to the rebel report that Gen. GRANT is preparing to raise the siege at Vicksburgh. Neither the rebel Press nor the rebel military leaders know much about Gen. GRANT'S besieging operations, as the absurd telegrams we have received from the South show. Their communication with Vicksburgh itself is only by stratagem, and, in our rear, they have no force within many miles of our army.

abstract: -The attention of men of taste and mineralogists, and the public generally, is called to the remarkable collection of minerals on exhibition at the rooms of MINER & SOMERVILLE, and which will be sold to-day as per advertisement. There are crystals of every variety and of sparkling beauty -- one dodecahedron crystal of copper pyrites, first quality; crystalized quartz, purple copper pyrites in quartz, calcareous spar, specimens of galena, and other crystals of great variety. They were viewed by a largo number of people yesterday.

abstract: Unofficial, but reliable dispatches received here today from our army, dated near Vicksburgh, May 31, represent no material change in affairs. abstract: On the 19th, ult., the Provost-Marshal arrested, at a boarding-house in Eighth-street, Mr. SIDNEY KIRTLAND, recently from Alabama, who passed under the assured name of Cat???in. The charge against him was that of being a rebel spy and of having communication with the enemy. Day before yesterday, ???LAND sued out a writ of habeas corpus, through his counsel. Ey-judge STUART, which was made recurrence before judge MCCUNN at his Chambers in Wall-street. P.M. GLASSY, Esq., on behalf of the Provost Marshal, made prompt return to the writ, a???ducing the body of the prisoner. The return set forth that, in April last, KIRTLAND left the State of Alabama, now in rebellion against the Government, passed secretly through the Union lines, and, on his arrival in this city, took lodgings with a man named PUTNAM, who was well known to the Provost-Marshal as being in communication with the enemy ??? that he refused to take the oath of alliegiance, on ??? while here went under an assumed name and that he was regarded and held as a spy, subject to the ???ontrol of the military authorities, or if not a spy, that I ??? was a prisoner of war. The return to the writ having been submitted to the Judge, the case was adjourned to 3 P.M. yesterday. At the hour appointed the prisoner was again produced, and his counsel put in a traverse to the above return to the following effect: That KIRTLAND is a Northern man, born and bred in Saybrook, Ct., and never spent a Winter in the South until the rebellion broke out; that his reasons for leaving Alabama were to avoid conscription into the rebel army and to pay a visit to his parents before they died, who are now living in Gaybrook, and are both between ???0 and 90 years of age; that he has always been loyal to the United States Government, and believing that the rebellion would be substantially ended during the present year he was staying here waiting for that event; that the reason why he refused to take the oath of allegiance was because, if he were to do so, all his property, which is in the South, would be destroyed, and his family reduced to poverty, and his Northern creditors defrauded of their just dues; also the additional and more potent reason that his wife and children, who are at present with her parents in Alabama, would be imprisoned and perhaps put to death, if it were known that he had taken the oath of allegiance to the United States Government. He denies that he is a spy or has communication with the enemy, and says that his acquaintance with the man PUTNAM was purely accidental, and he knows nothing of his business or purposes. His reasons for going under an assumed name are not given.

abstract: United States vs. Belle, schooner, >amp;c.; Prize; also, Granite City
snippet: United States vs. Belle, schooner, >amp;c.; Prize; also, Granite City
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner Belle and Cargo. -- This vessel was captured off the coast of Georgia by the gunboat Potomska, on Feb. 22, 1863. The vessel being unseaworthy, was after a survey, delivered over to the use of the Government at Port Royal, at a valuation of $800. No one intervened in the suit commenced to forfeit her. She had on board her when captured a certificate of British Registry, dated at Nassau, May 5, 1862; a shipping agreement between the master and crew, dated Feb. 9, 1863 for a voyage from Nassau to Port Royal and back: a clearance from Nassau for Port Royal, and an agreement signed by the master at Nassau, on Feb. 6, 1863, stating the terms on which he was to navigate the vessel on the voyage for the purpose of running the blockade the payment to be made to him in specie and Confederate money on his arrival at a port in the Confederate States, and a further amount to be paid him on his safe arrival at Nassau on his return trip.

abstract: From the great number of prominent officers bearing the name of SMITH in the army of the Mississippi, it is not always easy to identify them in the reports of the various engagements in which they participate. Having several times during the war bad occasion to allude to the above gallant officer, who ...
lead_paragraph: From the great number of prominent officers bearing the name of SMITH in the army of the Mississippi, it is not always easy to identify them in the reports of the various engagements in which they participate. Having several times during the war bad occasion to allude to the above gallant officer, who has signalized himself at Pittsburgh Landing, Corinth, Arkansas Post, the Expedition up the Sunflower River, and in all the attacks on Haines' Bluff and Vicksburgh, we desire to correct some errors quite common in regard to his name. In the report of the last attack on Vicksburgh where he commanded the Second brigade of Major-Gen. BLAIR's division, he is mentioned as T. KIRBY SMITH, and in other reports of other conflicts as T.J. SMITH and J.K. SMITH. It should be THOMAS KILBY SMITH, late Marshal of Ohio, of Cincinnati.
headline: {'main': 'Acting Brig.-Gen. T. Kilby Smith.; ARMY OF THE MISSISSIPPI.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Acting Brig.-Gen. T. Kilby Smith.; ARMY OF THE MISSISSIPPI.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The second match for $5.000 between these horses -- two miles and repeat in harness -- took place Wednesday on the Fashion Race-course, in presence of about two thousand spectator? -- good order reigning -- against about ten thousand who witnessed the last match. Of course this meag???e attendance is to be attributed to the scenes of rowdyism and robbery which occurred both inside and outside the course, and on the railroad cars, on the former occasion; and, after the fashion of locking the stable door after the horse is stolen, a hundred Metropolitan Police, under the charge of Capt. WALLING, Twentieth Precinct were detailed for the protection of the people who were not there yesterday. Forty of them went to the course in the; 10 o'clock train, and the rest with the crowd in the 2 o'clock train, and were thus enabled to protect the passengers from the operations of the few sly thieves and three card-monte men who had managed to smuggle themselves on board, notwithstanding the vigilance of the Detectives who pointed out great numbers to the Metropolitans, who promptiv sent them back over the ???fesries as fast as they were spotted. Not to be beat, however, a large number of these ???regnes got to the race-course se in hooks by the lower terries. and after attending the race, had made quite a harvest at monte playing before the police arrived at the West Flushing Station to take the cars to New-York: and with the impunity will which the games continued under the eves of the Metropolitans, it is to be presumed that they had no power in the premises, and that the Sheriff is alone responsible for its continuance outside the cars. The Detectives who did such valuable service were Messrs. Stowey, T???n, Smith, Wilson, Dusenbury and Vaughan.
lead_paragraph: The second match for $5.000 between these horses -- two miles and repeat in harness -- took place Wednesday on the Fashion Race-course, in presence of about two thousand spectator? -- good order reigning -- against about ten thousand who witnessed the last match. Of course this meag???e attendance is to be attributed to the scenes of rowdyism and robbery which occurred both inside and outside the course, and on the railroad cars, on the former occasion; and, after the fashion of locking the stable door after the horse is stolen, a hundred Metropolitan Police, under the charge of Capt. WALLING, Twentieth Precinct were detailed for the protection of the people who were not there yesterday. Forty of them went to the course in the; 10 o'clock train, and the rest with the crowd in the 2 o'clock train, and were thus enabled to protect the passengers from the operations of the few sly thieves and three card-monte men who had managed to smuggle themselves on board, notwithstanding the vigilance of the Detectives who pointed out great numbers to the Metropolitans, who promptiv sent them back over the ???fesries as fast as they were spotted. Not to be beat, however, a large number of these ???regnes got to the race-course se in hooks by the lower terries. and after attending the race, had made quite a harvest at monte playing before the police arrived at the West Flushing Station to take the cars to New-York: and with the impunity will which the games continued under the eves of the Metropolitans, it is to be presumed that they had no power in the premises, and that the Sheriff is alone responsible for its continuance outside the cars. The Detectives who did such valuable service were Messrs. Stowey, T???n, Smith, Wilson, Dusenbury and Vaughan.

abstract: Our intelligence from Gen. GRANT'S army this morning is to the 31st ult.--one day later. At  that date there had been no material change in the condition of affairs. The siege operations were being energetically pushed forward, and the army was in good condition and fine spirits.
lead_paragraph: Our intelligence from Gen. GRANT's army this morning is to the 31st ult. -- one day later. At that date there had been no material change in the condition of affairs. The siege operations were being energetically pushed forward, and the army was in good condition and fine spirits. The rebels on the Rappahannock report that Gen. GRANT had fallen back to the Big Black to meet the rebel force under JOE JOHNSTON, but the report undoubtedly crows out of the fact that Gen. BLAIR, with his division, had been sent in that direction

abstract: Prize Cases in America
snippet: Prize Cases in America
lead_paragraph: The debate in the British House of Lords on May 18, in reference to the English vessels captured by our cruisers, was one of more than common interest. It was opened by the Marquis of Clanricarde speaking in favor of his motion for copies of the proceedings, of our Prize Courts, in a speech most remarkable for the untruth of its statements and the recklessness of its charges. The ground of his bringing up the subject was, as he said, that "the whole trade of England with the Gulf of Mexico and the West Indies was at preterit arrested." This statement was, of course, a mere rhetorical flourish; for no seizure of vessels by our cruisers could have had any serious effect upon the lawful trade to that part of the world, and we have yet to see any signs that the illegitimate trade has been checked by such seizure, or by anything else. Now and then, it is true, we notice that some blockade runner has been forced to make his appearance before the Insolvent Courts; but where the profits are so large, the failure of one or two will not intimidate the rest.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, the City Inspector was requested to report by what authority he is cleaning the streets, and what disposition is made of the sweepings.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, the City Inspector was requested to report by what authority he is cleaning the streets, and what disposition is made of the sweepings. A resolution was passed to have a story added to the City Hall, to make it correspond in height with the new Court-house -- the addition to be made when the Court-house shall be completed. Another resolution was adopted, appropriating $10,000 to celebrate the ensuing Fourth of July, ???der the auspices of a Joint Committee of fourteen. Messrs. Farley, Reed, Boole, Ottiwell, Fox, ???enry and Mitcheli were appointed from this ???ard. The Mayor's veto of the resolution to ???rense the salary of the Public Administrator ???$1,250 to $5,000 per annum was overruled, ???12 to 4. On the resolution from the Council???. directing the Park Barracks to be removed, ??? HARDY said the barracks were used for a ???on, and otherwise illegitimately. Mr. OTTI??? said a visit to them would satisfy any one ???they were used for legitimate and good pur???, mostly as a hospital for sick and wounded ???diers. Mr. FROMENT regretted that ultra par??? feeling should be so manifest in a resolution of this character. It was referred to the Com???es on National Affairs. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. on next Monday.

abstract: Party, the New; its Candor and Consistency
snippet: Party, the New; its Candor and Consistency
lead_paragraph: Fighting shy is poor business. It is manly to take the bull by the horns. FERNANDO has done it. The boldness and the consistency with which he now comes out against the war are admirable. Of course we all know it will end in his biting the dust; but then, the straight forwardness and the pluck of the thing--how splendidly it shows off against the shivering fellows in the background:

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication ???ce in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Magazines for June; Irving, Washington; Life and Letters, Vol. 3
snippet: Magazines for June; Irving, Washington; Life and Letters, Vol. 3
lead_paragraph: The new volume of this delightful Biography is embellished with a fine engraving by HALL, of BALL HUGUES' bust of IRVING, executed in 1835; this, though like, is somewhat too much idealised, but conveys a fair impression of the manly and benignant countenance it seeks to represent. According to the originally designed scale of the work the present would have formed the last volume, and it is matter for congratulation that the richness and abundance of the material in the Editor's hands induces him to enlarge the Life to four volumes. The portion now before us includes the incidents of fourteen years, from Mr. IRVING's return to the United States after the long residence abroad, which had allowed a generation to grow up, to whom he was personally strange, in 1832, until his final restoration to his native land in 1846, on his retiring from the Spanish Embassy. Thirteen years of happy home life yet remains for the subject of the concluding volume. The period now illustrated was one of considerable literary activity, including the publication of Astoria, Adventures of Capt. Bonneville, Tour on the P???aries and other volumes of The Crayon Miscellany, and the preparations for the Life of Washington, delayed for a time by diplomatic functions, but always kept in view by the writer as the destined goal of his authorial career. A thousand interesting facts and anecdotes connected with the above works and the literary men of Europe and America, will be found now given for the first time in the correspondence of IRVING with his family and friends, all in the highest degree creditable to him. Amongst others may be mentioned the particulars of the noted sacrifice of time and money that he made when nobly giving up to PRESCOTT the subject of The Conquest of Mexico, on which he had long intended to write a work as the pendant to his Columbus. It is needless to enlarge on a book that will be so generally read. A more perfect picture of a literary life, told with the good taste which allows the subject of it to be mainly his own biographer, has never appeared.

abstract: Party, the, Real Aims of
snippet: Party, the, Real Aims of
lead_paragraph: There can be no question of the gain to the public at large of the peace meeting on Wednesday night. There has been a peace party in the country ever since the war began, but it has never ventured to declare openly its real aims. Either through a consciousness of its weakness, or through faith in the policy of temporization and subterfuge, it has steadily devoted itself rather to the support of things that were likely to hinder or delay the war, than to the advocacy of the immediate cessation of hostilities. It became aware at a very early stage in the conflict that if the Southern property in slaves were scrupulously respected, it would leave in the hands of the rebels the means of protracting their resistance almost indefinitely; and the first efforts of the opposition, therefore, were directed to securing to this species of property a formal exemption from the risks in which every other species of property was necessarily involved. They did all that pen and tongue could do to place negroes, for this once, in a different category from mules and cattle, and to make out their seizure or liberation as something more than usually outrageous and unjust. The natural effect of the operation of this theory, had they been successful in securing its adoption, would, of course, have been to neutralize at one stroke a large ???crtion of the Northern superiority in point of population, on which the National Government relied largely for its final success. It would have converted, in short, the weakest point in the Confederacy into its strongest.

abstract: It is now positively ascertained that there is a movement of a large portion of the rebel army under LEE. Columns of troops are in motion from Fredericksburgh, in a southwesterly direction, towards Gordonsville.
lead_paragraph: It is now positively ascertained that there is a movement of a large portion of the rebel army under LEE. Columns of troops are in motion from Fredericksburgh, in a southwesterly direction, towards Gordonsville. Balloon reconnoissances yesterday discovered heavy clouds of dust, occasioned by the marching of continuous bedies of troops, on the Gordonsville road. Many of the rebel camps recently in sight have also disappeared, and their line of pickets has been doubled.

abstract: Anaconda Plan of Hostilities
snippet: Anaconda Plan of Hostilities
lead_paragraph: -- The necessity of pushing active operations into the rebel territory, and attacking him energetically, is revealed more and more, as we continue to do so; and the errors of the anaconda plan, as a permanent mode of operation, are made more patent daily. We had news, yesterday, that a naval expedition had ascended the Red River as far as Shreveport, 330 miles from its mouth, and had there found on the stocks and destroyed two immense iron-clad rebel vessels, of sufficient power to have demolished our Mississippi fleet. A few days ago Admiral PORTER forwarded a dispatch announcing that he had sent an expedition up the Yazoo; and that at Yazoo City three powerful steamers had been destroyed, and also a monster ram, 310 feet long, 70 feet beam, to be covered with 4-inch iron-plate. At both Shreveport and Yazoo City were found extensive navy-yards, which were demolished. These are but a fraction of the rebel iron-clads that have been destroyed on the Western rivers during the year, or since FARRAGUT and PORTER began active operations in searching for them. All the Western streams have been pretty thoroughly scoured now, however, and we imagine that these late exploits must about have finished up all the rebel iron-clads in that section, unless they happen to have some up the Arkansas River, which as yet has not been penetrated for any distance.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR is reported by one of his party organs to have declined an application by a Committee of colored men, to aid in the organization of a colored regiment for active service.
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR is reported by one of his party organs to have declined an application by a Committee of colored men, to aid in the organization of a colored regiment for active service. He did this, it is stated, on the ground that "he had too much sympathy for the blacks to consent, as the position they must occupy would be one of extreme danger, and would lead to dreadful and unnecessary sacrifice of life." If GOV. SEYMOUR is, indeed, so hard pushed that he has at last to fall back upon such a subterfuge, he can't give in too quickly. Our people will stand any quantity of negro "sojering" sooner than that their Governor shall cut so ridiculous a figure.

abstract: The three rebel States  west of the Mississippi River Louisiana, Texas and Arkansas had, by last census, a population of one million and three-quarters  over eleven hundred thousand of which were whites, and the remainder negroes.
lead_paragraph: -- The three rebel States west of the Mississippi River -- Louisiana, Texas and Arkansas -- had, by last census, a population of one million and three-quarters -- over eleven hundred thousand of which were whites, and the remainder negroes. In the seven Southern States on this side of the river, which, while the rebels hold Vicksburgh, may be said to be yet commanded by JEFF. DAVIS, there were a fraction over three millions and a half of white men -- that is, including the entire population of Virginia, (and we may set off West Virginia, held by us, against East Tennessee, held by the rebels.) It will thus be seen that there is actually close upon one-quarter of the entire population of the Confederacy in the three rebel States west of the Mississippi, which region is completely cut off from the Confederacy, a great part of it reduced by our army, and all of it only waiting for actual occupation by a small force.

abstract: News from Franklin up to 2 o'clock to-day, is that Col. BAIRD, commanding the garrison, was attacked by 1,200 rebel cavalry yesterday, who drove his forces back into their intrenchments. They rallied, however, and repulsed the enemy with heavy loss to the latter.

abstract: Two large brick buildings on the corner of Washington and Wide Water streets, Norfolk, were destroyed by fire last night. They were used as a Government storehouse. All the property belonging to the Government, except about $2,000 worth, was removed. The fire was no doubt the work of an incendiary.
