abstract: We are glad  to furnish some proof this morning that the Government is reinforeing Gen. GRANT. We give from the Western newspapers the names of a number of stemboats that have passed down the Mississippi River laden with troops ...
lead_paragraph: We are glad to furnish some proof this morning that the Government is reinforeing Gen. GRANT. We give from the Western newspapers the names of a number of stemboats that have passed down the Mississippi River laden with troops, and that is a kind of evidence that will gain credence, even though the bare assertions of the telegraph may not. We suggested, yesterday, that there were large bodies of spare troops in Western Tennessee and Kentucky, and it seems to be mainly from these regions that they are being taken. That section is in the Department of Gen. GRANT, and the troops are probably being brought down by his orders; but we trust that the Government will not confine Gen. GRANT's reinforcements to those he can obtain from his own Department.
headline: {'main': 'REINFORCEMENTS FOR GRANT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'REINFORCEMENTS FOR GRANT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 28th ult., arrived at this port yesterday, bringing $318,066 in treasure. The San Francisco steamer, which arrived at Panama previous to the sailing of the Northern Light brought Mexican news, via Acapulco, to the effect that the French had suffered another defeat at Puebla, and that Gen. COMONFORT, with 18,000 men, had added his forces to the garrison.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 28th ult., arrived at this port yesterday, bringing $318,066 in treasure. The San Francisco steamer, which arrived at Panama previous to the sailing of the Northern Light brought Mexican news, via Acapulco, to the effect that the French had suffered another defeat at Puebla, and that Gen. COMONFORT, with 18,000 men, had added his forces to the garrison. The date of this report is not given. The Constitutional Convention of the United States of Colombia had adjourned, after passing the new Constitution and electing MOSQUERA Provisional President. The Capital is to remain at Bogota. The State Legislature of Panama had passed a decree prohibiting French troops or ammunition from being passed across the Isthmus to Mexico, owing to the report that a large force of French soldiers were to be sent by that route to Acapulco. The news from Central America, by this arrival, is not important. CARRERA, the President of Guatemala, had not followed up his threat to again invade Salvador. JEREZ had been totally defeated in his effort to overthrow the Government of President MARTINEZ, in Nicaragua. The new President of Costa Rica, JESUS JIMINEZ, had been inaugurated. The news from the South American States is of little interest.

abstract: since the Schism of 1837
snippet: since the Schism of 1837
lead_paragraph: A movement of considerable importance to the religious world is now in progress in this country. The Presbyterian Church, which was rent in twain in the year 1837, and has existed since in two divisions, known as the Old School and New school, is in gradual process of reunion. There is scarcely a doubt of the eventual redintegration of the body, which will then become one of the most powerful moral and intellectual agencies of the day.

abstract: A man was  arrested yesterday at Mr. DICK BROWN'S saloon, who has been recognized by three or four persons as ColPARKER, the rebel who wrote that letter to GenBLUNT. The circumstances of his capture were these: In the afternoon he came into the saloon and sat down. DICK'S back was turned towards him at the time.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested yesterday at Mr. DICK BROWN'S saloon, who has been recognized by three or four persons as ColPARKER, the rebel who wrote that letter to GenBLUNT. The circumstances of his capture were these: In the afternoon he came into the saloon and sat down. DICK'S back was turned towards him at the time. When he turned round be was startled on recognizing PARKER, Whom he had formerly known in Wyandotte, and who subsequently became a Captain under QUANTRILE. DICK, however, thought he would watch the man and soon found that he in turn had beet, recognized. By some means a policeman was called and PARKER taken in charge. FRANK BRIDE then came up, and also recognized a man who once shot at him in M???souri. He knocked PARKER down as soon as he saw him. Mr. JIM BROWN, himself unknown to PARKER, then asked the prisoner it he had ever known DICK BROWN in Wyandotte, and if he had "seen him this after noon," and was answered in the affirmative.

abstract: The Annual Regatta of the New-York Yacht Club will come off on Thursday morning, the 11th of June, at half-past ten o'clock. There will be three prizes, valued at $150 each, which will be awarded to the first three yachts returning to the staks-boat abreast of the Club House, Hoboken.
lead_paragraph: The Annual Regatta of the New-York Yacht Club will come off on Thursday morning, the 11th of June, at half-past ten o'clock. There will be three prizes, valued at $150 each, which will be awarded to the first three yachts returning to the staks-boat abreast of the Club House, Hoboken. The yachts entering for this Regatta will be "handi-capped" by the Regatta Committee in a race open to all classes. The allowances of time to be taken at the starting, without reference to the wind at the time. The sailing courses are as follows: A flag-boat will be anchored abreast of the Club House, at Hoboken; on the east side of which the yachts will be anchored in two lines, head to the wind, commencing from the flag-boat with those of the greatest allowance of time. Yachts may have their mainsails, or foresails and mainsails, according to their rig, hoisted, and gaff-top- sails set; the Committee reserving the discretionary power, however, of adopting any other preparation for starting they may deem proper, should the weather or circumstances render a change necessary. The yachts will pass to the north and west of a flag-boat stationed off Robin's Reef Light; thence easterly to a fine-boat stationed off Owl's Head, Long Island, passing it to the north and east: thence around the buoy of the Southwest Spit, passing it from the north and east. Returning, they will first pass the flag-boat anchored off Owl's Head, Long Island, passing it to the south and east; thence to the flag boat off Robin's Reef Light, passing it to the south and west; thence to the flag-boat off Governor's Island, passing it to the south and east; thence to the flag-boat abreast of the Club House. Hoboken, passing it to the westward. In going and returning, all the buoys on the west bank -- viz., Nos. 11, 13 and 15 -- are to be passed to the eastward.

abstract: The "Loyal Ladies' League of New-York" held a monthly meeting in the school room No. 388 Ninth-  avenue, on Wednesday, at 4 P.M., Mrs. GEORGE TOMPKINS acting as President, and Miss L. JONES as Secretary. This organization, having nearly one thousand signatures, pledged to unconditional loyalty to the Government, (while it aids disabled soldiers.) has been much retarded in its operations, in consequence of many persons mistaking it for the Loyal "Women's Convention." with which it has no connection. At their meeting on Wednesday, appropriate extracts from the publications of the "Loyal National League" were read, and short addresses made by some of the ladies, one of whom said "it is our bounded duty to become correctly informed in the political as in the religious and historical literature of our country. This knowledge we may obtain without deviating from the strictest delicacy, and we must not be deterred by the fear of having our reputation unjustly censured."

abstract: -We have read with great interest the account which the Chattanooga Rebel gives of the reception of that distinguished patriot VALLANDIGHAM, by those rebels, who, it was said, feared him as more dangerous to their cause than all the bayonets of LINCOLN. We are surprised to learn that "everywhere, those who have heard of his coming greeted him kindly and with silent tokens of sympathy and respect." Some of our captured soldiers, who went through the same region at the same time, report that the behavior of the rebels to them was very insulting and barbarous, and the Confederate authorities robbed them of their private property. We but note the comparison.

abstract: And Reunion, According to Rynders and Wood
snippet: And Reunion, According to Rynders and Wood
lead_paragraph: "Peace and Reunion!" These were the dulcet words which lined the blank walls and guttersides of New-York and Brooklyn, heading the call for the Grand Mass Convention or "those opposed to the war and its continuance." Peace and Reunion! What a delightful combination. Read it again. "It hath a dying fall." Do not all manner of visions at once come over the mind, of millennial glories -- visions of lions and lambs, of Southern chivalry and Northern hyenas, of Copperheads and Butternuts, and Abolitionists, and all manner of opposing elements, all joined together in one grand Happy Family? Did not every one instinctively picture to himself the mild and gentle faces sure to be found at this meeting of the Peace and Reunion seekers? -- the intellectual and honest phiz of FERNANDO, the calm and philanthropic countenance of ISAIAH, the ambrosial curls of EDMON, and the general halo of meekness and serenity which would glorify the walls of Cooper Institute? And then the speeches sure to be heard, full of all gentleness and sweetness and piety, such as beseems those who come forth at the heavenly call of Peace and Reunion. They would all of course be earnestly in favor of free speech, so much so that it would not be very safe for any one to undertake to discuss the other side of the question in the hearing of the audience. They would be strong for the Union, so strong that not a word should be said against those who have armed themselves to overthrow it. They would be strenuous for the rights of the citizen and for a constitutional Government, so much so as to show plainly their sympathy with those who have based their rebellion upon a denial of those rights, and have striven to set up a despotism instead of a Constitution. And through all their outcry about the liberty of the citizen, about Free Speech and a Free Press, it would appear plainly enough that it is only because they have not the power that those who differ from them are not crushed under their feet by a tyranny which would, if it could, trample out even the thoughts of those who love freedom and would elevate the oppressed. Peace and Reunion! Well! we all would like to accomplish that. There is something of a difference, however, in the ways by which we would pursue it. We wish these gentry would be explicit as to the means by which they propose to attain both of these objects. We can understand how one who is "opposed to the war and its continuance" might go to work to obtain peace. He might say let the Army of the Potomac lie down, while LEE rushes over it, and burns Washington. Let GRANT retire from before Vicksburgh, and send back the hundred cannon which he has captured. Let ROSECRANS send a flag of truce to BRAGG, asking permission for his army to lay down their arms at the feet of the rebels whom they whipped at Stone's River. Let BANKS evacuate New-Orleans -- SCHOFIELD St. Lou is -- BURNSIDE Louisville, and MITCHELL Nashville. A vigorous prosecution of such measures might bring peace, but how about Reunion ? -- ay, how about Reunion ?
headline: {'main': 'Peace and Reunion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Peace and Reunion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- A private letter from JERE L. CLARK, of the Fourth New-York battery, after describing the advance of the Third corps to the support of the Eleventh, which was so disco milted in the battle at Chancellorsville, says: "Gen. HOOKER, after, the fight, had the corps relieved. The different corps, as you Know, are distinguished by patches of different shapes, which they wear upon their caps. That of our corps is the diamond. As we passed Gen. HOOKER's headquarters, he took one of our patches, and placing it upon his hat, exclaimed: "Diamonds are trumps!' and wore it through the fight. Men may say what they choose, but they will not lower Gen. HOOKER in our estimation. He is a soldier and a gentleman, and the only one fit to command in the army."

abstract: A number of gentlemen of this City have formed a society called the "Society for the Protection of Destitute Roman Catholic Children in the City of New-York." The corporators are Messrs. Felix Ingoldsby, Charles A. Stetson, Eugene Kelly, Charles M. Connolly, Daniel Devlin, Andrew Carrigan, L. Silliman Ives, Edward C. Donnelly, Edward Frith, Henry J. Anderson, Joseph Fisher, Eugene Plunkett, John McMenomy. Donatien Binssee, Lewis J. White, John Milhau, J. O'Brien, Bernard Amend, John E. Develin, Stephen J. Philbin, Florencio Escalante, John O'Connor, Henry L. Hoguet, James Lynch, Frederick E. Gilbert, Daniel O'Connor "and their successors." Three of these gentlemen have each subscribed $5,000, with a promise to pay $300 annually, and another, $2,500. A house for boys is already open under the charge of the Christian Brothers, and one for girls, under the management of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd. The office of the Society is at No. 25 Chambers-street, where contributions will be received, as also all desired information given and applications attended to by the President, Dr. SILLIMAN IVES.

abstract: Indianola, Gunboat; Lieut.-Commanding Brown's Official Report
snippet: Indianola, Gunboat; Lieut.-Commanding Brown's Official Report
lead_paragraph: We print below the official report of Lieutenant Commanding BROWN, formerly of the Indianola, giving a detailed report of the operations of that vessel from the time she left Admiral PORTER's fleet until she was sunk by a rebel ram in the vicinity of Grand Gulf. It is the only detailed and reliable report of one of the greatest naval engagements ever witnessed. Commander BROWN has just been released from Richmond, where he was carried prisoner after the capture of the Indianola:

abstract: The Crisis in
snippet: The Crisis in
lead_paragraph: This message was delivered and read to the House by Herr VON BISMARK himself, but it did not shake the resolution of the members, or produce the anticipated effect. On the contrary, it was declared to be based on misinformation, and a Committee was appointed to take it into consideration and prepare a suitable reply, in which doubtless ministerial calumnies will be refuted, and royal errors corrected. A heavy responsibility rests on the Deputies. For not only are their own privileges at stake, but even the fate of constitutionalism in Prussia. The Premier and his master are at present merely striving to get in the edge of the wedge. Let them succeed in this, and they will not cease till they have driven it home. Their assumptions are wholly unwarrantable. The right which President GRABOW claims is not a violation of the Prussian Constitution, is not derogatory to the Prussian monarchy. What are the rights of Ministers, and what is derogatory to the dignity of royalty, are questions as well understood in England as in Prussia, yet PALMERSTON, LAYARD and GLADSTONE are as liable to be called to order by the Speaker of the House of Commons, as the most insignificant of its members. But the Prussian Ministers are not, it seems, members of the Lower Chamber, and therefore they claim to be exempt from the jurisdiction of its President. What clause or article of the Constitution justifies this claim? The Constitution, indeed, requires them to attend the House, and authorizes them to take part in its discussions, but it nowhere stipulates that they shall be privileged to indulge in vituperation, insult the Deputies, and violate the rules of the Chamber with impunity. Had the Constitution given the Von Bismark Cabinet any such license, they would doubtless have demonstrated it; and yet, so late as the Autumn of the past year, we find the very Minister who has caused the trouble now pending, submitting as a matter of course to be called to order by President GRABOW, for the use of unparliamentary language, and humbly apologizing to the House for the indecorum. It was not till the debate on the cartel-conventions that a disposition was manifested by any member of the Cabinet to question the authority of the President, and the Premier himself was the first to set that example of insubordination which VON ROON has only too faithfully followed.
headline: {'main': 'The Crisis in Prussia.; The crisis in Prussia continues. The King has come to the aid of his Cabinet, and has attempted to intimidate the Deputies by addressing to them a message, in which he censures them for approving the conduct of their President; pronounces that conduct a violation of the constitutional rights of the Ministry nay, highly derogatory to the dignity of his crown, and counsels the Chamber to abandon its pretensions.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Crisis in Prussia.; The crisis in Prussia continues. abstract: Master Robert Wm. Mathews, aged 18 years, died last Friday morning, at 5 o'clock, at the residence of his parents, No. 40 Summit-street, South Brooklyn. He had been suffering from a complication of diseases, including acute pneumonia and acute rheumatism, for nearly two weeks. He was a truly noble youth, of fine form and rare intellectual power. At the beginning of the present civil war he served, for several months, in the Seventeenth regiment of New-York Volunteers, Col. Lansing. Having had a strong partiality for sea life, he entered the naval service a year ago, and made a ten months' cruise on board the United States brig-of-war Bainbridge, Lieut. Dominick Lynch commanding. While the brig lay at Aspinwall for repairs, he contracted the Isthmus fever, which was the remote cause of his death. He had been home only about three weeks at the time of his demise. His remains were taken, on Saturday afternoon, June 6, to Utica for interment.

abstract: His Peace and Free Speech Farce
snippet: His Peace and Free Speech Farce
lead_paragraph: It is generally supposed that the Americans, as a people, are keenly alive to the ludicrous, and that a party which, in this country, lays itself open to the shafts of ridicule, is already as good as dead, if not buried. If this be true, the Fernando Wood faction must be in a parlous state; for the recent peace meeting was certainly the most notable farce ever played in this City. The presence of that fighting apostle of peace, Capt. RYNDERS, was in itself a capital joke; and not less happy was the hoarse applause which repeatedly greeted the mild proposition to revolutionize the Government by force of arms! To judge from the appearance of the audience, an uninitiated person might have been led to congratulate the City upon the recent conversion of a very large proportion of her rowdies and red-mugs to the Quaker faith; and this, it must be confessed, was another capital stroke on the part of the peace-mongers. It would have moved the ghost of George Fox himself to inextinguishable laughter, to see such an audience vociferously applauding the pacific sentiments of FERNANDO WOOD, and hi-hi-ing when the angelic prophecy of "Peace on earth and good will to men" was alluded to. We have always known WOOD to be a man of daring genius. We are not accustomed to be startled at what he says or does; but we never expected that even he would have the temerity to present a crowd of New-York roughs as the harbingers of the Millenium! It was a dangerous experiment, but it was a successful one.
headline: {'main': "Fernando's Farce.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Fernando's Farce.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We published on the 26th of  May an article from the Richmond Examiner, of the 23d, which proclaimed in very loud and ferocious language that the rebel army was immediately going to assume the offensive, that...
lead_paragraph: -- We published on the 26th of May an article from the Richmond Examiner, of the 23d, which proclaimed in very loud and ferocious language that the rebel army was immediately going to assume the offensive, that the most important movements of the war were about to be made and "???thin the next fortnight the campaign of 1863 will be pretty well decided." That fatal fortnight was up yesterday; but we have not yet heard of any of the terrible occurrences which the Examiner predicted would take place within that time. We have not heard that they have yet opened the campaign, much less closed it triumphantly.

abstract: Although the recruiting rendezvous for this corps, at No. 65 Franklin-street, under the superintendence of Col. ROBT. NUGENT, A.A.P.M. General, has been opened since Monday, there have been nearly a hundred applicants. The duties will be chiefly in garrison and light marches, and the government, in establishing the corps, do so as a reward to those faithful soldiers who, from wounds or the hardships of war, have become disabled. Those only are accepted, and they are required to produce recommendations from their old commanders. Surgeon POWELL. U.S.A., has examined a great number of applicants. The corps will be divided into three battalions, those men who have lost an arm or leg being assigned to the second or third battalions. Capt. CROMIE, late of the Twelfth N.Y. Vols., First Lieut. JAS. W. POWELL. Jr., late Aide-de-camp, (both wounded in the service,) have charge of the rendezvous. Officers and men can obtain further information from them.

abstract: The telegraph has  not taken the trouble either to contradict or confirm the story it brought us, a few days since, that the rebels had captured a regiment of negro soldiers at Helena, Arkansas, and had hung every man of them, with all their white officers. We should think that when it was thought worth while to startle the whole country with a rumor of this kind, it ...
lead_paragraph: The telegraph has not taken the trouble either to contradict or confirm the story it brought us, a few days since, that the rebels had captured a regiment of negro soldiers at Helena, Arkansas, and had hung every man of them, with all their white officers. We should think that when it was thought worth while to startle the whole country with a rumor of this kind, it would also be considered worth while to contradict it when it was proven to be false. The absurd stories which are often telegraphed to the Press may, perhaps, not be thought worthy of contradiction, but the fact is they deceive many people, and leave many others in doubt. News should either be more carefully sifted by the agents, or else they should take more pains to furnish the public any subsequent information that may be obtained on any given subject. In the meantime, it may be taken for granted that there was not a word of truth in the telegram that the regiment of negroes was hung at Helena, as that place is within a few hours' sail of Memphis, from which there is telegraphic communication all over the country; and the news has had no confirmation. The original story came from Murfreesboro, and there it was obtained from rebel sources. So it probably only indicated what the rebels would like to do, instead of what they actually did.

abstract: The Twenty  fourth Iowa, or "Preachers' regiment," as it was called when formed out West two years ago, because largely composed of clergymen, was much ridiculed by the Copperhead Press and much scandalized by the foreign Press. But it has done very hard service for two years past, and the soldiers have proven themselves the bravest of the brave.
lead_paragraph: -- The Twenty-fourth Iowa, or "Preachers' regiment," as it was called when formed out West two years ago, because largely composed of clergymen, was much ridiculed by the Copperhead Press and much scandalized by the foreign Press. But it has done very hard service for two years past, and the soldiers have proven themselves the bravest of the brave. Our Vicksburgh correspondent, in his most interesting letter published the other day, gave an account of an exploit of this regiment, which we hope was not overlooked. The regiment was part of a small storming party ordered to capture a rebel position, located on an almost inaccessible height, the crests of which were bristling with batteries, which rained hurricanes of death, and had to be approached through a gorge commanded by fourteen pieces of rebel artillery, there being also massed on both sides of the gorge heavy supports of rebel infantry. The storming party pushed on through the gorge and up the hill -- the Preachers' regiment being foremost -- and in twenty minutes this forlorn hope were hurrahing over the possession of all the guns, the crest of the hill, and the total rout of the rebel infantry; but our correspondent added that in this terrific charge, this Cerro Gordo charge, the Preachers' regiment was nearly annihilated.

abstract: Calomel in the Army
snippet: Calomel in the Army
lead_paragraph: The recent order of Surgeon-General HAMMOND, prohibiting the use of calomel and tartar emetic in the army, has produced a good deal of lively discussion in medical circles, and is meeting with much criticism and opposition. Dr. HAMMOND asserted that the "abuse" of calomel produced certain "melancholy effects," and therefore he abolished its use, or, at all events, directed that it be struck from the medical supply tables. He said that army diseases could be treated as efficiently without as with tartar emetic, and, therefore, he ordered that it also be struck from the supply tables of the army!

abstract: The Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth NewYork regiments did not arrive in this city till 1 o'clock yesterday morning, although it was confidently expected they would reach here by 10 or 11 A.M. on Friday. It was known here early on Friday morning that the regiments had got as far as Philadelphia,...
lead_paragraph: The Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth NewYork regiments did not arrive in this city till 1 o'clock yesterday morning, although it was confidently expected they would reach here by 10 or 11 A.M. on Friday. It was known here early on Friday morning that the regiments had got as far as Philadelphia, and information to that effect was telegraphed to the military committees at the Astor House, and to the Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council. The time occupied in transferring a few hundred soldiers from Philadelphia to New-York, is usually about six hours, and, in this instance, it was understood by all parties concerned in the reception, that ample preparations had been made for placing the troops on board the cars at the former city and sending them to this point. In accordance with the programme of arrangements the military escort, consisting of several regiments, the whole under the command of Brig.-Gen. HALL, was marched to the Battery, there to await the arrival of the returning regiments. Broadway, from the Battery to Union-square, was thronged, as were also the steps and esplanade in front of the City Hall, with citizens who had assembled to witness the grand ovation to be extended to the gallant volunteers. Hour after hour this large military and civic concourse was kept in anxious waiting for the expected troops, and it was not definitely known by the public till 6 P.M., that the regiments would not arrive in season to participate in the reception which it was proposed to give them on that day. Possibly some few persons in the crowd might have inferred that the delay was the result of political intrigue, but the people generally evidently believed that accident alone prevented the regiment from arriving here at the appointed time. That the troops were purposely detained at Philadelphia is now well-known and freely admitted. Why they were not allowed to reach here at a seasonable hour on Friday will be explained hereafter, and the names of the individuals who identified themselves with the movement will be announced in connection with a full explanation of the affair to be made by a City official. Taking into consideration the great expense attending a reception like the one proposed, it was no light matter that the arrangements should be seriously interrupted, and the thousands of people who were disappointed in not seeing the regiments, did not probably take it all as a good joke. It seems that the Military Committees and the Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council, different as to the arrangements to be observed, consequently, instead of all the Committees working harmoniously together for the benefit of the returning regiments, the Military and the Common Council Committees worked to get the lead of each other; and although the Military Committee temporarily succeeded in accomplishing their object, it remains, to be seen what will finally be done by the Committee on National Affairs. It has been decided to publicly receive the regiments to-morrow, and if the weather should prove favorable, the display will be the grandest that has yet taken place on a similar occasion. The proceedings will be managed entirely by the Committee on National Affairs. Ald. BOOLE. Chairman of the Sub-Committee, consulted with Gen. HAIL yesterday, and received from him the assurance that nothing should be waning on his part to make the event equal the expectation. In the evening the Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth will be entertained with a dinner at the City Assembly Rooms. Yesterday, the Thirty-eighth matched from the Park Barracks to the Arsenal on White-street, which place they will make their temporary quarters.

abstract: The remarkable statuette called the "Freedraan," by WARD, the sculptor, is to be issued in bronze -- a material not only valuable for its artistic character, but especially adapted to this subject. Ten copies only are to be cast, for an equal number of subscribers. WARS has just completed a beautiful and spirited design for the use of the Loyal Publication Society. It represents the Goddess of Liberty upborne in air, while resting by her right arm upon the outspread wings of an eagle. Her left hand out reached holds the National flag, from whose folds flutter scrolls and leaflets earthward, significant of the objects of the Society. The eagle clutches a dying snake in its talons. The whole group is relieved against the radiating beams of the sun.

abstract: Col. DANIEL S. COWLES, reported killed in the assault on the works at Port Hudson, was a native of one of the New-England States, and about forty years of age. He has lately been a resident of the City of Hudson, Columbia County, in this State, where he has held some of the highest positions in the gift of the people, and always performed his duties with the highest degree of honor and success. Col. COWLES raised the regiment which he commanded -- the One Hundred and Twenty-eighth -- by his own individual exertions. It is composed of the flower of Columbia County. The last words of Col. COWLES were: "Tell my mother I died with, my face to the enemy."

abstract: North British Review on the Disintegration of Empires
snippet: North British Review on the Disintegration of Empires
lead_paragraph: The brilliant and original notion of dividing men of public note into three absolutely-defined classes, was, we believe, the thought of a Scotch parson, who enjoys some local renown as a litterateur. His three classes included the man original, the man extraordinary and the man imitative -- represented in their respective order by SHAKESPEARE, Lord BROUGHAM and Mr. N.P. WILLIS! Here, by a fine stroke of generalization, you had before you the types of the notable portion of the human race arranged, as it were, under your nose, so that you could muse over the theme without much of that hard brain exercise which BUCKLE and the ethnologists often impose on one.

abstract: The "Coldwater" cotton, which has passed through many hands, and become somewhat famous by reason of the transactions connected with it, has been on trial during this week before Judge TREAT and a jury, in the United States District Court. Yesterday the jury found a verdict for the Government and against the private parties, of whom there were several, who claimed the cotton, thus condemning the cotton to the use of the Government.

abstract: The new steamship America, belonging to the German Lloyds, from Southampton on the 27th ult., arrived at this port yesterday. Her advices from Europe are three days later than those brought by the Persia. Politically, the news is not speciatly important. The return of Gen.
lead_paragraph: The new steamship America, belonging to the German Lloyds, from Southampton on the 27th ult., arrived at this port yesterday. Her advices from Europe are three days later than those brought by the Persia. Politically, the news is not speciatly important. The return of Gen. HOOKER to the north side of the Rappahannock, continued to excite comment among the English journals, and the death of STONEWALL JACKSON, news of which had just been received, was regarded as a great misfortune to the rebels and their cause. The announcement of his death caused a considerable depression in the rebel loan. An open air meeting was held at Sheffield on Tuesday, the 26th, to consider the advisableness of memorializing the British Government to "use its good offices to procure a suspension of hostilities between the North and the South, with a view to an arrangement of the difference between them." The meeting was called in pursuance of a requisition by the Mayor, and was attended by about 10,000 persons. The following resolution was agreed to: "That, in the opinion of this meeting, the Government of this country would act wisely, both for the interests of England and those of the world, were they immediately to enter into negotiation with the Great Powers of Europe for the purpose of obtaining the acknowledgment by them of the independence of the Confederate States of America." The meeting was addressed by Mr. ROEBUCK, M.P., in advocacy of recognition. The Polish question appears to be as far from solution as ever. The revolution is certainly spreading. So change had taken place in the Liverpool cotton market. Breadstuffs had advanced. Provisions were quiet. Consols 93 1/2 @ 5/8.

abstract: National Convention, Results of the
snippet: National Convention, Results of the
lead_paragraph: The National Canal Convention that met at Chicago on the 2d inst., has adjourned, after a two-days' session, having adopted resolutions and appointed a Committee to look after the interests the Convention was intended to promote. In one respect the Convention was a great success. There was really a national representation of interests there. The City of St. Louis and the City of St. Paul on the far-off Mississippi, had numerous and able delegations present, and so had the City of Portland, the City of Boston, of New-York, and the City of Oswego, on the remote Atlantic and Lake coasts. And all the large cities between -- Buffalo, Cleveland, Detroit, &c. -- sent representatives to take part in the important deliberations. In most cases, the Boards of Trade of the several cities undertook to act in appointing members to the Convention, but in many other cases municipal authorities sent delegates; and a great many prominent politicians were present voluntarily, because of their general interest in the subject to be considered by the Convention. Upon the whole, while it was a "mixed Commission" as well as a voluntary one, it was a very full and fair representation of the opinions and wishes of the country in regard to the great works of internal improvement that are contemplated. Avery great concourse of persons was drawn about the Convention, betokening a deep interest in it, and a quite emphatic popular approval.

abstract: If the captured dis-  patch from the rebel commander at Vicksburgh is genuine and true, we may took for a speedy termination of affairs there. On the 28th ult., his forage was all gone, his ammunition nearly exhausted, the men were on quarter rations, and he could only hold out ten days. The ten days are more than up they closed with last week. Some of the
lead_paragraph: -- If the captured dispatch from the rebel commander at Vicksburgh is genuine and true, we may took for a speedy termination of affairs there. On the 28th ult., his forage was all gone, his ammunition nearly exhausted, the men were on quarter rations, and he could only hold out ten days. The ten days are more than up -- they closed with last week. Some of the statements in this dispatch are corroborated by facts already in our knowledge -- such as the running out of mules from Vicksburgh and the shooting of horses. If PEMBERTON was so hard up for supplies, however, we think he made a mistake in running out his mules; for, killed and salted, they would have made good victual in a strait. At the siege of Derry and at many another historical seige there was much worse fare than mule meat. PEMBERTON's stupidity in this respect rather confirms the Southern story that he is a traitor -- not to say an ass.

abstract: The Savannah Republican contains an interesting letter from HERSCHEL V. JOHNSON, Senator from Georgia in the rebel Congress, in defence of a bill, which he introduced last Winter, providing an amendment to the Constitution of the Confederate States. The amendment proposed to incorporate the doctrine of secession into the Constitution, so that there could be no mistake about it in the future. It provided that when any State being aggrieved by any act of Congress shall by convention declare the act to be unconstitutional. Congress shall call a convention of the States, and if the act is not approved by two-thirds of the States, it shall be void; but if it is affirmed and no adjustment can be made satisfactory to the complaining State, that State shall, if it choose, be allowed to secede in peace. Surely this seems very reasonable, if the secession doctrine is adopted. It was objected that the amendment was unnecessary. But Mr. JOHNSON says that the right of secession is not in so many words recognized in the Constitution, and he fears that in the future trouble may arise on this question. He fears that Congress may exceed its delegated powers. He thinks that a convention of States furnishes a much better arbiter between a discontented State and the Confederate Government than a Supreme Court. He says that "the Supreme Court of the United States had, at the time of secession, become so imbued with the party spirit of the day, that it was an unsafe umpire between the States and the United States."

abstract: And the War; Powers of the Executive
snippet: And the War; Powers of the Executive
lead_paragraph: It is of vital consequence that the Executive, in this national crisis, should have uncommon powers. It also is of vital consequence that those powers should be exercised with great discretion. The people owe the President every instrumentality needful for the suppression of the rebellion. The President owes the people the wisest and most effective use of such instrumentalities. These are reciprocal obligations. Unless they are faithfully performed on both sides, the cause will fail. They cannot be too carefully studied and heeded.

abstract: Notwithstanding "the desire of the public to hear Mile, VESTVALI in some of her celebrated roles," the season at the Winter Garden, after a sorry experiment, has come to an abrupt end. It was based simply and purely upon pretence, and therefore merits the fate that has been awarded to it. Without a single male artist, without a second or third rate
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding "the desire of the public to hear Mile, VESTVALI in some of her celebrated roles," the season at the Winter Garden, after a sorry experiment, has come to an abrupt end. It was based simply and purely upon pretence, and therefore merits the fate that has been awarded to it. Without a single male artist, without a second or third rate prima donna, without in fact anything that constitutes a company, it would have been strange, indeed, if a different result had been attained. A limited knowledge of English seems to have been the only art capital of the concern, but this was hardly a sufficient of an attraction to justify double prices. It was a mistake to call the concern an English opera; every one knew that it was nothing of the kind; it was a mistake, also, after bestowing on it the name of Italian opera, to commence with "Il Trovatore," a work which does not depend on the contralto voice, and which in every respect has been given so well and so often at the Academy, that a hasty performance elsewhere, without the attraction of grand artists, was not likely to excite the community. And this is just the point; the ???public does not want hasty performances of opera anywhere, and least of all, in a theatrical establishment. It would have been a disgrace to any but a provincial community if Mlle. VESTVALI's miserable attempt had succeeded. Better a thousand times no opera, than have it cause such needy experiments. Still, we are sorry that the lady has been the victim of a mistaken idea. She is an excellent and graceful actress, and a singer who generally succeeds in pleasing the public. After a long absence, she was justified in expecting a hearty and genial reception. On some future occasion she will, we are sure, attain it; but we warn her again against any new experiment in management. On Friday next Mlle. VESTVALI will take her benefit. We trust there will be an opportunity of hearing the lady to better advantage in the Fall. Her proper place is at the Academy of Music Adventures elsewhere Invariably come to grief.

abstract: On Saturday evening a number of military and civic personal friends of Brig.-Gen. WARD testified their high appreciation of his merits by a banquet at DELMONICO's, corner of Fourteenth-street and Fifth-  avenue. Among the guests present were Gen. Sickles, Gen. S.B. Hayes, Col. L.B. Hayman, Col. Roome. Capt. J.M. Cooney. Lieut. C.L. Ford, Lieut. T.J. Lee, Lieut. Raphael, Elliot C. Cowdin, Rufus F. Andrews, Richard Busteed and Ethan Alien. The entertainment was magnificent in the extreme, and was well worthy the brave officer in honor of whom it was prepared. The Chairman on the occasion was Mr. ELLIOT C. COWDIN, who, at the proper time, opened the intellectual part of the proceedings with a brief but eloquent speech, in which he referred to the manly and soldierly attributes of Gen. WARD.

abstract: Their Opinion of the Peace Convention
snippet: Their Opinion of the Peace Convention
lead_paragraph: The Democratic newspapers in the interior of the State are not at all pleased with the proceedings of the Peace Convention recently held in this City. They denounce Ex-Mayor WOOD in the most vehement terms for starting a movement which seems likely to divide the Democratic party, and thus, in a party sense, undo the work of last Fall's election. With this aspect of the case we have very little concern. All political parties seem to be in process of disintegration. New issues ought always to create new parties, or revolutionize old ones; and whenever the machinery of a political party proves strong enough to overrule this natural tendency, and to make men act together for the sake of a party triumph, long after they have ceased to hold the same political sentiments, it becomes a nuisance and a curse.

abstract: Rochester Union >amp; Advertiser on the Wood Peace Convention
snippet: Rochester Union >amp; Advertiser on the Wood Peace Convention
lead_paragraph: -- The Rochester Union and Advertiser, a leading organ of the Democratic party, tries very hard to throw upon the Republicans the responsibility of the recent Peace meeting, -- or, as it styles it, "this Convention of Mr. WOOD." While the Democratic papers were content to pass it without notice, the Republican journals, it alleges, "spread its doings broadcast under flaring captions, with a view of giving them character and currency -- the NEW-YORK TIMES being foremost in this work." This is very absurd. "We did for that Convention precisely what we do for every other -- gave its proceedings a full and fair report, not on account of any sympathy with them, but for the information of the public. It is certainly important for the Democrats of the interior to know what their brethren of the City are doing; and if they cannot get this information from their own organs, they ought to feel grateful to other journals for giving it to them.

abstract: Gen. HOOKER on Friday and Saturday pushed a daring reconnoissance across the Rappahannock just below Fredericksburgh, and ascertained fully the movements and intentions of the enemy. HOWE's division of the Sixth army corps was selected for the duty, and executed it in the most thorough and effective manner. The first cross-
lead_paragraph: Gen. HOOKER on Friday and Saturday pushed a daring reconnoissance across the Rappahannock just below Fredericksburgh, and ascertained fully the movements and intentions of the enemy. HOWE's division of the Sixth army corps was selected for the duty, and executed it in the most thorough and effective manner. The first crossing was made in pontoon boats, in the face of a murderous fire from the rebel pickets. The Twenty-sixth New-Jersey regiment did this important service in the most gallant style. They were soon followed by several Vermont regiments, and a charge on the rifle-pits resulted in the capture of some sixty or seventy prisons. The pontoons were then laid by the engineers, and the remainder of the division was crossed over. Our force gradually felt its way out to a position where it remained for the night, and on Saturday morning the reconnoissance was continued. Our skirmishers brought in some thirty others prisoners, during Friday night, making the number captured about two hundred. The results of the reconnoissauce are most important. It is fully ascertained that the rebel force is nearly all yet in the vicinity of Fredricksburgh, and that LEE has not yet begun any offensive movement, though his intention to do so is pretty clearly apparent. Gen. HOOKER's crossing took him completely by surprise, and made a great commotion in his army. LONGSTREET's corps was massed in Fredericksburgh on Friday night, fully expecting an attack. Our forces were safely withdrawn after the purpose of the reconnoissance had been accomplished; the casualties in the crossing not exceeding thirty.

abstract: Never has the old adage, "it is an ill wind that blows nobody good," been more completely verified than in the effect the present war has produced on the railroad interests of the loyal States. At the time of the breaking out of the rebellion, and for a number of years previously, the majority of the great railroads of the Middle and Western States, were financial failures. They were dragging out a
lead_paragraph: Never has the old adage, "it is an ill wind that blows nobody good," been more completely verified than in the effect the present war has produced on the railroad interests of the loyal States. At the time of the breaking out of the rebellion, and for a number of years previously, the majority of the great railroads of the Middle and Western States, were financial failures. They were dragging out a weak and crippled existence -- staggering under Floating Debts, Preferred Stock, First, Second, Third, and even Fourth and Fifth, Mortgage Bonds. The ownership of railroad Shares was considered almost a premonitory symptom of bankruptcy, and Bankers had learned to fear a connexion with railroad enterprises as something fatal to their credit.

It even attacks our new despotism before it is consolidated, and would have it split in fragments ere it is cemented together.

abstract: We suppose all the  thousand rumors concerning the late movements of the rebel army may be considered set at rest by the facts developed on the daring reconnoissance to the south bank of the Rappahannock on Friday last, of which we published telegraphic news yesterday, and give an excellent account today. It was fully ascertained that the
lead_paragraph: -- We suppose all the thousand rumors concerning the late movements of the rebel army may be considered set at rest by the facts developed on the daring reconnoissance to the south bank of the Rappahannock on Friday last, of which we published telegraphic news yesterday, and give an excellent account today. It was fully ascertained that the rebel army was nearly all yet in the vicinity of Fredericksburgh, and that no offensive movement had been begun, though there were evidences that one was intended. We are glad that Gen. HOOKER made this reconnoissance, if it were but to quiet the public mind. The reconnoissance itself was admirably executed in all its details. It is to be hoped that Gen. HOOKER may by such means as this keep himself thoroughly posted in regard to rebel manoeuvres. In this way, they will neither be able to surprise us, as they did by the retreat from Manassas, nor assail us with overwhelming force at unexpected times and places, as they have so often done. Such movements keep the enemy on the alert for the safety of his own position, and also do much to keep up the spirits of our men, by breaking the dreary dullness of a long inaction.

abstract: ROEBUCK sustains his  reputation in his Sheffield speech on the war. No man in England could have uttered such an amusing series of logical contradictions and non-sequiturs. Our fathers fought for independence and threw off the English yoke; and this established the "great principle " that any people anywhere, at any time, could throw off any yoke, "whatever that yoke may be," and declare themselves independent.
lead_paragraph: -- ROEBUCK sustains his reputation in his Sheffield speech on the war. No man in England could have uttered such an amusing series of logical contradictions and non-sequiturs. Our fathers fought for independence and threw off the English yoke; and this established the "great principle " that any people anywhere, at any time, could throw off any yoke, "whatever that yoke may be," and declare themselves independent. France aided our Revolution; which established "another great principle," that any neutral Power could ally itself with the "so- called fighting body," fighting for independence. Verily, "great principles" are cheap, and do not need even one leg to stand upon. ROEBUCK treats his horse well, and so must the rebel his slave. The slaves are kindly treated and like their condition, yet ROEBUCK hates Slavery and regards it with the greatest horror, though he is convinced slavery must exist until the black man obtains the education which it is death for him to attempt to acquire. ROEBUCK does not desire war with the North, but shows it would be rather a good thing. No body of men so much desire England's interference in the war as the Northern States themselves; yet it is clear he thinks we would fight England if she gratify our dearest desires.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Continental, we have advices from New-Orleans to the 2d inst., and our correspondence from Port Hudson to the 28th ult., the day after the battle, of which we have already had brief accounts. The reports of losses in that battle prove to have been much exaggerated, though we are still without the official lists. No more assaults had been ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Continental, we have advices from New-Orleans to the 2d inst., and our correspondence from Port Hudson to the 28th ult., the day after the battle, of which we have already had brief accounts. The reports of losses in that battle prove to have been much exaggerated, though we are still without the official lists. No more assaults had been made upon the enemy's works, and Gen. BANKS had adopted the policy of starving them into a surrender. It is stated that the rebel commander had offered to surrender, provided the garrison were allowed to march out with their arms, &c., but Gen. BANKS refused to entertain any proposition but that of an unconditional surrender. Some further incidents of the fight of the 27th are given, which prove the desperate character of the resistance of the rebel garrison. Our correspondent at Port Hudson assures us that no fears need be entertained as to the result of the siege.

abstract: The United States steamer Pequot, the first vessel of a new fleet of eight screw propellers, was launched at the Boston Navy-Yard on Saturday. The Pequot, like all the others, measures 190 feet long, 28 feet in the beam, and is 12 feet deep. Her armament will consist of one 200-pounder amidships, ...
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Pequot, the first vessel of a new fleet of eight screw propellers, was launched at the Boston Navy-Yard on Saturday. The Pequot, like all the others, measures 190 feet long, 28 feet in the beam, and is 12 feet deep. Her armament will consist of one 200-pounder amidships, four broadside guns, together with a small rifled gun forward and aft. The operation of launching was managed in the most careful and creditable manner by Mr. Naval Constructor HANSCOM, and the vessel slid gracefully into the water at precisely seven minutes before 2 o'clock, amidst the cheers of the multitude. The Naval Band stationed on the vessel's deck played "Columbia the Gem of the Ocean." The ceremony of christening the ship was performed by Miss BARNEY, daughter of Rev. Dr. BARNEY. The Pequot was towed to the pier, where she is to receive her machinery, which will consist of an engine of 600 horse power, from the works of Messrs. WOODRUFF & BEACH, of Hartford, Conn. She will be ready for sea in about nine weeks. The following are the names of the vessels of the same class as the Pequot:

abstract: Banishment of Rebels and the Richmond Sentinel
snippet: Banishment of Rebels and the Richmond Sentinel
lead_paragraph: The question how to receive and how to treat the disloyal citizens of the United States who have recently been sent through to the rebel lines and warned not to return till the war is over, is under discussion in the Confederacy, and exciting no small degree of feeling. We published yesterday a very bitter philippic from the Richmond Sentinel on the subject, which is a type of the prevailing spirit of the rebel Press. The policy of sending these persons South is denounced in a spirit of extraordinary bitterness and ferocity. The Sentinel exclaims: "What should our Government do in response to this demoniacal outrage of our enemies?" And it answers: Some "will cry out precipitately 'Raise the black flag.' Perhaps it will come to that." But the Sentinel intimates that chiefly cowards and laggards who keep themselves out of harm's way will join in this cry for the "black flag," and therefore it suggests other modes of meeting the issue. The allusion to the black flag by one who so obviously regards the frequent appeal to it by rebel noncombatants with a good degree of contempt, is only made by the Sentinel, we judge, to remind the people of the North that there is a "black flag" kept in Dixie, finished, folded and ready for us, and only withheld from the breezy winds of Southern battle by the forbearance of our foes.

abstract: We have news from Gen. BANKS' army at Port Hudson via New-Orleans, up to the 1st inst., and from Gen. GRANT'S army at Vicksburgh up to the 3d. At each of the two scenes of action at these respective dates, things were in a very similar state. Gen. GRANT'S army was still investing Vicksburgh, with his right and left wings resting on the Mississippi River; Gen.
lead_paragraph: We have news from Gen. BANKS' army at Port Hudson via New-Orleans, up to the 1st inst., and from Gen. GRANT'S army at Vicksburgh up to the 3d. At each of the two scenes of action at these respective dates, things were in a very similar state. Gen. GRANT'S army was still investing Vicksburgh, with his right and left wings resting on the Mississippi River; Gen. BANKS' army was investing Port Hudson, 228 miles below Vicksburgh, with the right and left wings of his army resting on the river. GRANT had made no assault in force upon the Vicksburgh defences since the attack of the 22d, which was unsuccessful; and BANKS had made no assault upon the Port Hudson works since the attempt of the 27th, which also was unsuccessful. All that has been done at Vicksburgh for the last eighteen days has been to keep the rebel garrison awake by an active fire from the siege guns in the rear and the gunboats in front; and precisely the same course has been pursued at Port Hudson for a fortnight past. The latest advices from Vicksburgh indicate that it is GRANT's plan to pursue the siege steadily and mainly by engineering operations, with an expectation that the garrison must soon succumb from hunger; and our New-Orleans letters of this morning set forth that BANKS intends pursuing a similar plan, with like hopes. In one important point, however, there is a difference: -- while we hear much about the great rebel army that JOHNSTON is gathering in the rear of Gen. GRANT, we hear nothing whatever of any rebel force in Gen. BANKS' rear. This is fortunate for Gen. BANKS, for his army is very much smaller than that of Gen. GRANT, and is not so favorably posted to resist an attack in the rear. It is fortunate for both of these excellent commanders that they have first-class naval officers to cooperate with them. Admiral FARRAGUT has been as uniformly successful and brilliant in all his naval operations as BANKS has been in his land operations in Louisiana; and Admiral PORTER's operations have only been less glorious than those of Gen. GRANT because they have been so very much smaller in their sweep and aim. Gen. BANKS and Gen. GRANT communicate with each other by means of couriers along the Louisiana bank of the river.
headline: {'main': 'The Mississippi River Operations of Gens. Grant and Banks.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mississippi River Operations of Gens. Grant and Banks.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A distinguished engineer officer, who took a prominent part in the bombardment of Fort Pulaski, has made a calculation based upon the destruction caused by the late powder explosion in Eighty-sixth-street, in this City -- that had our artillery succeeded in exploding the enemy's magazine at Fort Pulaski, to which its main effort was directed, the result would have been the annihilation of both the opposing forces. No man would have been left to tell the tale, no stone left upon another to mark the site of the contending foes.

PRIME, of the Journal of Commerce; PARKE GODWIN, of the Evening Post; Jas. BROOKS, of the Express; ANSON HERRICK, of the Sunday Atlas; HORACE GREELEY, of the Tribune, and ELI COMSTOCK, of the New-York Argus, having for its object a consultation upon the "nature, extent and rightful limitations (if any) of the liberty of public journalists to criticize the acts of those charged with the conduct of the Government in time of war and civil convulsion." HORACE GREELEY was called to the Chair, and ELI COMSTOCK appointed Secretary. Among the editors present were those who signed the call (with the exception of PARKE GODWIN) and Rev. Dr. PRIME, of the Observer; P.J. MEEHAN, of the Irish American; J. BEACH, of the Sun; JOHN CLANCY, of the Lender; Mr. OTTENDOFFER, of the Staats Zeitung; ROBERT MCFARLAND, of the Scientific American, and several others.

abstract: Those who believe that "republics are ungrateful" must hereafter tell it to the marines; certainly they cannot tell it to our soldiers with hopes of being believed. The reception which the metropolis yesterday gave to her returned braves, the Thirtyseventh and Thirty-eighth New-York. Voiunteers togehter with previous receptions on similar oc-  casions, demonstrated that the Empire City of the ...
lead_paragraph: Those who believe that "republics are ungrateful" must hereafter tell it to the marines; certainly they cannot tell it to our soldiers with hopes of being believed. The reception which the metropolis yesterday gave to her returned braves, the Thirtyseventh and Thirty-eighth New-York. Voiunteers togehter with previous receptions on similar oc- casions, demonstrated that the Empire City of the Empire State, at least, both appreciates and honors the noble efforts of her soldiers in the field. Nor was the reception less enthusiastic than might have been naturally anticipated from the multiplicity of military display which have??? enlivened the Metropolis curing the last two years. ??? deed, the very fact that curiosity could net draw forth such crowds, lent a heartiness to the welcome that could not attend a mere military parade. It was the consciousness that the brawny heroes who earned the National colors had defended them with their lives on many a hard- fought field, that made the occasion of such thrilling interest. The metropolitan pride which has so often swelled at the display of our citizen militia, was doubly heightened by the appearance of real veterans, fresh from the smoke of battle, many of them ma??? with honorable sc???, and proudly bearing them ???. Though deprived of its spontaneous by the balk in the arrangements of Saturday the welcome was in fact more complete in its details. There was perhaps less confusion from the multiplicity of those glad greetings of relatives and friends which have characterized other receptions; but the widely-extended notices of the arrangements, and the convenience of the hour named, enabled more of the bone and sinew of the City -- the immediate kindred of the honored guests -- to be present with the throng, and mingle their lusty cheers with the shouts of rejoicing that everywhere rent the air, and gladden the hearts of the soldiers by their presence. The streets along the line of march were alive with humanity and gaily decorated with the red, white and blue, forming almost a continuous triumphal arch of the national colors. The clerk of the weather must have been insulted by the bare supposition in the officially published programme, that aught but cloudless skies could greet such a memorable scene. Though warm, not hot; refreshing, yet not cold. The weather was all that could be desired, and was alike agreeable to citizens and soldiers.

abstract: There are three great Macs in the ever-victorious army of Gen. GRANT -- MCCLERNAND and MCPHERSON, each commanding a corps, and MCARTHUR, commanding a division. The North British character of many of the other names, including GRANT's own, in the same army, is noticeable. There is LOGAN, and WALLACE, and BLAIR, all Generals, and a host of others in subordinate positions. In the army of ROSECRANS there were the two famous brothers MCCOOK -- of whom only the duplicate Mac, MCDOWELL MCCOOK, is now left; and the two Macs who successively commanded the Army of the Potomac do not need to be named.

abstract: This morning the members of the family of WILLIAM STEELE, of East Hartford, on going to his oom, found his chamber deluged with blood, and Mr. STEELE lying dead on the floor, with his throat horribly cut, His wife was on the bed, with her throat cut from ear to ear, and an infant, six months old, had its head almost cut off. All were dead the child still warm.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, Conn., Monday, June 8.

abstract: Shortly after 12 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the three-story building No. 15 Baxterstreet, occupied as a dwelling and lodging-house. The flames were first discovered in a rear room on the second floor occupied by MARY DANIELS, and so...
lead_paragraph: Shortly after 12 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the three-story building No. 15 Baxterstreet, occupied as a dwelling and lodging-house. The flames were first discovered in a rear room on the second floor occupied by MARY DANIELS, and so rapidly did the fire spread that it cut off all means of escape for those persons living on the third floor, unless they saw fit to leap from the windows to the pavement below. Rather than perish in the flames, several persons jumped out, and were more or less injured, while four others were overcome by the heat and smoke, and were burned to death. Capt. JOURDON, of the Sixth Precinct, Sergeant WALSH and Roundsmen RYAN and HOPKINS and a platoon of men were early on the ground, as also were several fire engines, and rendered efficient service, doubtless saving several lives and much property. While the fire was raging furiously MARGARET KEATING, an Irishwoman, 50 years of age, leaped from the third story window of the tenement and was dangerously injured. By direction of Capt. JOURDON, Officer MORIARTY conveyed her to the New-York Hospital, but she was refused admittance, the officer being told that Bellevue Hospital was the proper place to take her. The woman was accordingly forthwith conveyed to that institution. ELLEN MCCONNELL, also an Irishwoman, 40 years of age, jumped from the third story window, but before reaching the ground Roundsman HOPKINS caught her in his arms, thereby in all probability saving her life. She was but slightly injured. JOHN SANDS, an Irish laborer, 32 years of age, was fearfully burned on his arms and back, while endeavoring to make his escape through the flames. He was removed to the New-York Hospital, where it is thought he cannot long survive. The fire was extinguished with all possible haste, after which Capt. JOURDON and his officers searched the ruins, and on the third floor found the charred remains of ALICE MURPHY, a widow woman, 35 years of age, and folded in her arms was MARY ALICE MURPHY, her little daughter, four years old. BRIDGET GRAY was found Iving dead almost beside Mrs. MURPHY, and in a rear room, Iving on a bed, was the dead body of MARY JANE MCMASTERS. All the bodies were so blackened and burned as to be almost past recognition. The women were all natives of Ireland, and from 35 to 40 years of age. The remains were conveyed to the Sixth Ward Station-house, where Coroner WILDEY subsequently held an inquest over them. The following is the substance of all the material testimony in the case:

abstract: We have advices from Europe four days later, by the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Africa.  She left Liverpool on the 30th, and Queenstown on  the 31st ult. The news is important.
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Europe four days later, by the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Africa. She left Liverpool on the 30th, and Queenstown on the 31st ult. The news is important. Four other vessels -- the ships Dorcas Prince and Union Jack, from New-York; Sea Turk, from Boston, and Nye, a whaler -- are reported to have been captured by the Alabama. The Australasian had arrived out with the announcement that Gen. GRANT had captured Vicksburgh, -- whereupon the Liverpool Post goes into a mediation spasm, urging immediate action by Lord PALMERSTON in that direction; but the London Post finds nothing in it but an indication that the National Commanders in the Valley of the Lower Mississippi, seem intent on solidly securing what, when the war ends, may be called lines of frontier -- the recognition of Southern independence by the National Government being regarded as a foregone conclusion! The rebel cotton loan fluctuated at from 2 1/2 to 1 1/2 discount. Mr. RO???BUCK had given notice of his intention to move in Parliament for negotiations with other Powers, looking to the recognition of the Confederates. Lord MONTAGUE was expected to move an amendment. According to the Paris correspondent of the London Herald, Mr. MASON's presence in Paris had strengthened the report of an approaching recognition of the South. The Paris correspondent of the London Post also reports that fresh efforts are being made by MASON and SLIDELL to obtain Southern recognition. The Liverpool cotton market was unchanged, and the tendency of the market was downward. Breadstuffs were quiet, and Provisions flat. Consols closed at 93 1/2 @ 93 5/8 for money.

abstract: COLLISION ON THE RIVER -- AN OFFICER BADLY INJURED. -- Yesterday morning the Williamsburgh ferry-boat Minnesota came in collision with the sloop Eliza, while going from this city up the river. A portion of her cabin was carried away, and Lieut. SCHWARTZFAVER, of the Third New-York volunteers, was badly injured in the side and hip. He was taken to his hotel in Chambers-street, in this City. Last evening he was suffering considerably from his injuries, as well as from a wound in his sword arm received in battle.
lead_paragraph: COLLISION ON THE RIVER -- AN OFFICER BADLY INJURED. -- Yesterday morning the Williamsburgh ferry-boat Minnesota came in collision with the sloop Eliza, while going from this city up the river. abstract: A letter from Folly Island, Charleston Harbor, dated June 1, states, a few days previously, it having been observed from the "Lookout" that James Island had a deserted appearance, a reconnoissance was ordered, which resulted in the demonstration that there were less than 1,000 rebel troops there. Their number had hitherto been estimated at from 10,000 to 12,000. The inference among our men was, that the bulk of the rebel forces had been sent off to operate against GRANT at Vicksburgh.
lead_paragraph: A letter from Folly Island, Charleston Harbor, dated June 1, states, a few days previously, it having been observed from the "Lookout" that James Island had a deserted appearance, a reconnoissance was ordered, which resulted in the demonstration that there were less than 1,000 rebel troops there. abstract: There are certain  persons in Washington who observe closely the President's countenance, and telegraph to the Press from time to time the result of their observations. If Mr. LINCOLN smiles and looks...
lead_paragraph: -- There are certain persons in Washington who observe closely the President's countenance, and telegraph to the Press from time to time the result of their observations. If Mr. LINCOLN smiles and looks joyful, it is evident he has some good news, which the public will learn by and by. If he looks glum and dismal, it is because he has ominous tidings locked up in his bosom. We always look upon such signs dubiously -- knowing that the President's facial muscles are much more likely to be affected by the state of his stomach than by the condition of the country. It appears they also have people in Richmond who watch JEFF. DAVIS' face, and, in lack of other news, report to the rebels what they find there. It is evident that they, too, sometimes make a fearful miss; for they report that on the 18th ult., the great traitor was seen to smile and heard to make a very gleeful remark concerning affairs at Vicksburgh. Now, of all the days in the present year, the 18th of May was the day when JEFF. DAVIS should not have smiled, if his smiles were to be taken as true indexes of his successes. For, on the day before, Gen. GRANT had defeated the rebel army at Vicksburgh, after having previously inflicted upon them a quartette of defeats; and on that very day he moved up to Vicksburgh, captured Haines' Bluff, and effected the investment of the place. We wish the reporter had told us on which side of his face JEFF. smiled, then or subsequently; and if our Washington friends would also be a little more particular as to the precise character of Mr. LINCOLN's "smiles," they would confer additional obligations on an anxious and distracted country.

abstract: The English Government and English rebel organs are occasionally thrown into undue excitement by an apprehension that English subjects (meaning Irishmen) are about being enlisted in their country to serve in the army of the United States. Whenever a stranger, wearing a moustache and...
lead_paragraph: The English Government and English rebel organs are occasionally thrown into undue excitement by an apprehension that English subjects (meaning Irishmen) are about being enlisted in their country to serve in the army of the United States. Whenever a stranger, wearing a moustache and carrying his head at all erect, appears in any City or remote corner of Ireland, a vigilant police force is at once on his track; and, in anticipation of his detection in violating the English neutrality laws. Her Majesty's Government are promptly advised that a "military-looking personage" has made his appearance in this or that place in Ireland, who is "doubtless a recruiting officer of the United States, seeking to make enlistments in Her Majesty's dominions." The situation of strangers and travelers in Ireland, under these circumstances, is not at all enviable, and it would be advisable for tourists to give the Emerald Isle the go-by altogether until the American war is closed. Or, if they do venture to visit it, they should go close-shaven and looking meekly, and as much like a member of the Peace Society as possible -- though it may be doubted if even this would save them.

abstract: We do not  think the rumors that have been current for some time, that the rebels were preparing for an extensive cavalry raid into Maryland and Pennsylvania, are entirely destitute of foundation. One of our Virginia correspondents gives this morning some striking...
lead_paragraph: -- We do not think the rumors that have been current for some time, that the rebels were preparing for an extensive cavalry raid into Maryland and Pennsylvania, are entirely destitute of foundation. One of our Virginia correspondents gives this morning some striking facts on this matter, and shows that the rebels have been making heavy preparations near Culpepper Court-house for a great raid. An expedition, consisting of cavalry, artillery and infantry, was sent out a few days ago by Gen. HOOKER to attack these rebels; and we learn that quite a brisk battle has already taken place -- with what fortune the War Department does not choose to let us know. Of course everybody will infer from this latter fact that we have been repulsed, but the inference may turn out to be an error.

abstract: The fall of Puebla
snippet: The fall of Puebla
lead_paragraph: Advices from Mexico, via Acapulco and San Francisco -- from the capital to the 19th of May, and from Puebla to the 18th -- have been received. They confirm the French report of the fall of Puebla, but differ materially as to the details of that event. It appears that on the 15th and 16th of May, the French were repulsed before the Fortress Carmen. Meantime the garrison and inhab???tants were reduced to a state of starvation, and their ammunition was entirely exhausted, Gen. COMONFORT having failed to cut his way through with supplies. On the 17th Gen. FOREY offered to for the Mexican officers and soldiers march out ???ho officers with their side-arms, provided they would give a parole not to serve against the French again. This was refused. Gen. ORTEGA then spike??? his cannon, burnt his gun carriages, destroyed the arms of his infantry, and surrendered himself and garrison as prisoners of war. Several prominent Mexican officers committed suicide by shooting themselves, rather than become prisoners. The advance of the French army was at Cholula, only six miles beyond Puebla. The Mexicans were much embittered. All Frenchman within the capital had been ordered to leave within eight days, and the approaches to the city were to be defended to the last.

abstract: Among the many curiosities, literary and other, which have been unearthed by our soldiers here and there throughout the South, we hardly remember to have seen any more curious than a couple of letters discovered by Gen. J.M. TUTTLE, in the house of the editor of the Jackson Mississippian, during the...
lead_paragraph: Among the many curiosities, literary and other, which have been unearthed by our soldiers here and there throughout the South, we hardly remember to have seen any more curious than a couple of letters discovered by Gen. J.M. TUTTLE, in the house of the editor of the Jackson Mississippian, during the short visit which GRANT's army made at Jackson. We have learned not to put implicit faith in everything which we hear or see, and it may ultimately appear that these letters are not what they purport to be. It is rather extraordinary that two letters so well calculated to do good service in fighting Copperheads throughout the West, should happen to fall into our hands; but the letters have intrinsic evidence of their genuineness, and so far their authenticity is undisputed.

abstract: Last night at the Turner Hall, on Orchard-street, a sumptuous dinner was given to the Twentieth New-York Regiment. (German) by the Municipal authorities. The hall was decorated magnificently with National, regimental and society colors, and...
lead_paragraph: Last night at the Turner Hall, on Orchard-street, a sumptuous dinner was given to the Twentieth New-York Regiment. (German) by the Municipal authorities. The hall was decorated magnificently with National, regimental and society colors, and everything passed off in the most quiet and satisfactory manner. The tables were excellently arranged, and the taste displayed in the selection of the viands did credit to the person in charge. The whole affair was presided over by Alderman REED, who was supported on either side by Aldermen MITCHELL, JEREMIAH and RYERS, and Councilmen WEBSTER, KEENAN and MCCONNELL. In opening the entertainment, Alderman REED made a brief speech in which he alluded to the gallant deeds performed by the men before him, and concluded by eulogizing the personal merits of Col. VON VEGESACK, of the Twentieth. At the conclusion of the gastronomic festivities, Alderman REED again made a few remarks, which he concluded by offering a toast to Col. VON VEGESACK. The Colonel responded in a brief and appropriate manner, and was followed by Alderman JEREMIAH, who made one of the most fitting and sensible speeches that any official has delivered on a similar occasion. It may be said of the dinner last evening, that of all the dinners thus far extended to the returning regiments, none has been so admirably and quietly conducted as that to the Twentieth regiment. No ill-feeling of any kind was exhibited, and the evening passed off to the satisfaction of all present. Col. VON VEGESACK seemed to have complete moral control of the regiment.

abstract: It has become an old story to "point the moral" of secession, as a political measure to secure the extension and perpetuation of Slavery, by the long patent fact, that the war inaugurated by secession is inflicting remediless wounds on the institution.
lead_paragraph: It has become an old story to "point the moral" of secession, as a political measure to secure the extension and perpetuation of Slavery, by the long patent fact, that the war inaugurated by secession is inflicting remediless wounds on the institution. Nevertheless, now and then a development of such magnitude is made in this direction, that we are obliged to treat it as a new and almost original proof of the utter ruin that Southern leaders have brought upon Slavery by their wicked attempt to rivet it more securely on the limbs of the black race.
