abstract: In regard to the case of KIRTLAND, who, in conformity with the order of Judge McCUNN, has been released from custody, we learn that Col. NUGENT, through Mr. GLASSEY, will appeal from the decision to the Supreme Court, and that they are determined to prosecute the matter, believing that KIRTLAND ought to be dealt with by military authority. It will be remembered that KIRTLAND was not examined, and it is said he positively refused to undergo an examination.

abstract: Puebla has fallen! After a heroic defence of sixty days remarkable in the annals of warfare the Mexican defenders of their first stronghold have been obliged to succumb, not ingloriously, but in obedience to the imperious necessity caused by the total failure of supplies and ammunition. Such is the intelligence received by telegraph, vi San Francisco, corroborative mainly of the report received vi Havana, eight days ago.

abstract: Intervention by once more
snippet: Intervention by once more
lead_paragraph: The Paris correspondents of the London journals periodically revive the prediction that France is about to recognize the inde- pendence of the Southern Confederacy. Just now, the rebel Commissioner to England, JOHN M. MASON, is in Paris, receiving the con- solations of his confederate, SLIDELL; where- upon the London Herald is quite sure "something will come of it." Its Paris correspondent, a thorough rebel sympathizer, declares it to be "the general impression that France will take the lead in the recognition of the South, and the rest of Europe will not be slow to follow."

abstract: We learn by  special telegram from Montreal that the principal members of the Canadian Government, Messrs. DORION and HOLTON, have been defeated in the contest for that constituency by overwhelming majorities. Mr. THOS. DARCY McGEE, who is an opponent of the Govern- ...
lead_paragraph: We learn by special telegram from Montreal that the principal members of the Canadian Government, Messrs. DORION and HOLTON, have been defeated in the contest for that constituency by overwhelming majorities. Mr. THOS. DARCY McGEE, who is an opponent of the Govern, was elected by a majority of 750 over Hon. JOHN YOUNG. This indicates that the newly-formed Ministry -- from whatever cause -- is extremely unpopular in Lower Canada. And the chances are that the Conservative party will shortly return to power. The contest in Montreal closed on Tuesday evening, and it is presumed the result there will have a strong influence on the elections still in progress in other parts of the country.

abstract: When the  Richmond Examiner, or the Richmond Whig, or the Richmond Sentinel, comes out with violent tirades in regard to the war, and the manner and spirit of conducting it, we republish them for what they are worth, which is in most cases not much. The Examiner de  lights in fine writing, in extravagant sentiments, in hyperboles, and startling figures of ...
lead_paragraph: When the Richmond Examiner, or the Richmond Whig, or the Richmond Sentinel, comes out with violent tirades in regard to the war, and the manner and spirit of conducting it, we republish them for what they are worth, which is in most cases not much. The Examiner de lights in fine writing, in extravagant sentiments, in hyperboles, and startling figures of speech. It is democratic, but delights to poke the Administration of JEFF. DAVIS between the ribs. The Whig is a duller paper, but Whig in politics, and quite as unamiable as the Examiner toward the rebel powers that be. The Sentinel is a new organ at Richmond, lately transferred from Fredericksburgh, and seems to represent the sovereignty of the Old Dominion, rather than the Administration or the opposition. When these papers speak of the Confederacy, it is not "by authority." They receive none of the confidence of the rebel chiefs at Richmond. This honor is reserved to the Enquirer and the Dispatch, but the former more especially. When the Enquirer, therefore, writes such a despairing and demoniac article as the one we quoted yesterday, bewailing the "raids" that are daily making in rebel territory, and threatening "bloody retaliation" and reprisals, we may know that the shaft of Northern military power is touching the marrow in JEFF. DAVIS' bonos.

lead_paragraph: -- Our military letters this morning will be found of deep interest. We have a full account of the gallant cavalry fight on Tuesday a soldier's description of the late battle of Port Hudson -- a letter giving the details of GRANT's late operations at Vicksburgh, and army correspondence from other points. Things are busy everywhere except in HOOKER's main army and the army of ROSECRANS; and from the latter of these armies we are likely, also, soon to have news and descriptions of operations.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met specially at 1 o'clock yesterday, to take action in regard to the subject of street-cleaning, A communication was  presented from the Mayor, Comptroller, City In- spector and Corporation Counsel, jointly, reporting that, pursuant to request of the Common Council, they had considered the subject of cleaning the streets, and concluded to recommend.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met specially at 1 o'clock yesterday, to take action in regard to the subject of street-cleaning, A communication was presented from the Mayor, Comptroller, City In- spector and Corporation Counsel, jointly, reporting that, pursuant to request of the Common Council, they had considered the subject of cleaning the streets, and concluded to recommend that the Hackley contract be abrogated; that the City Inspector, or some other official, be authorized to proceed with the work; and that the men employed up to this time by the City Inspector be paid. Mr. JONES proposed resolutions giving the Comptroller full power and authority to proceed to clean the streets, and authorizing the payment of the men employed up to this time by the City Inspector. After some discussion, the whole matter was postponed until the meeting to-day.

abstract: We have received no confirmation of the rebel report, published yesterday, that the garrison at Vicksburgh had surrendered. The latest news we have from our own sources of information, however, is only to the 4th inst. It is not unlikely that the next news we receive will be of the surrender. The Government, we understand, hourly expect such news.

abstract: The Question Settled
snippet: The Question Settled
lead_paragraph: We have from the outset avoided all discussion of the question of employing negro soldiers, because we have regarded it as a purely military question, which it was the province of the military authorities alone to settle. The political bearings of the policy we have steadily refused to recognize. The have steadily refused to recognize. The efficiency of our armies has been our paramount concern; for on that alone depends the suppression of the rebellion, and without that suppression the nation is ruined, and all politics are worthless.

abstract: Reunion by Expansion; Burritt, Elihu, Scheme of Union by Expansion
snippet: Reunion by Expansion; Burritt, Elihu, Scheme of Union by Expansion
lead_paragraph: It was said by MACAULAY that "an acre in Middlesex is worth a principality in Utopia." This is specially true in war-time. It is then supremely necessary to live where you can touch bottom. You can't plant batteries in mid-air. But our old friend, ELIHU BURRITT, now on the other side of the water, has taken a little excursion into Utopia, and brought back a project of "Reunion by Expansion," which our readers can see for themselves in another column. He has discovered that it is time to close "this great and terrible civil war," and that the true mode of closing it is to acknowledge the nationality of the Confederacy, and then form relations with it and with Mexico and Canada, whereby there should be a Quadruple Union of Nations, which should have one representative at foreign Courts, one army and navy, one postal system, one revenue system, one currency, and entire freedom of internal commerce, and yet each have a separate Congress and separate local government. It is somewhat curious that Judge EDMONDS contributed a day or two since, to one of our cotemporaries, a scheme very similar -- hit upon somewhere, we suppose, in "the spirit land."
headline: {'main': 'Reunion by Expansion."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reunion by Expansion."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The report  telegraphed to an Ohio paper, two days ago, that VALLANDIGHAM had been cast into prison by the rebels, is contrary to the universal manifestations of sympathy for him with which his presence within their lines was greeted. We are constrained to believe that the story is wholly false, and that it was invented to aid in procuring for him the Demo- cratic nomination for Governor of Ohio.
lead_paragraph: -- The report telegraphed to an Ohio paper, two days ago, that VALLANDIGHAM had been cast into prison by the rebels, is contrary to the universal manifestations of sympathy for him with which his presence within their lines was greeted. We are constrained to believe that the story is wholly false, and that it was invented to aid in procuring for him the Demo- cratic nomination for Governor of Ohio. Too much rebel sympathy might be dangerous in alienating the support of the great body of war Democrats still to be found in Ohio.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The Siege of
snippet: The Siege of
lead_paragraph: The public have grown familiar with the diurnal telegraphic announcement that "everything is progressing favorably in the rear of Vicksburgh." For more than a fortnight we had the encouragement that this general assurance is calculated to give, and sometimes the effect has been heightened by the additional information that "Gen. GRANT is in excellent spirits." We have been led to regard the immediate capture of Vicksburgh as a foregone conclusion, the people generally have accepted the quick fall of that stronghold as a certainty, and the stock speculators have discounted its full effect in the complete reopening of the Mississippi River on the values of Western railroad shares.

abstract: K. C. G.'s, Rumors of Organizations of
snippet: K. C. G.'s, Rumors of Organizations of
lead_paragraph: A mass meeting was held last evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, under the auspices of the Kings County Democratic Club, to protest against "all usurpations of arbitrary power," and in favor of the "Union, the Constitution and the laws." Mayor KALBELEISCH occupied the Chair, and speeches were made by himself, Hon. AMASA J. PARKER, ALONZO C. PAIGE and others. Resolutions were adopted protesting against the Emancipation Proclamation, arbitrary arrests, and the suppression of free speech and the Press, and pledging the Democracy of Kings County to the Union and the Constitution against all enemies. The meeting was respectable in point of numbers, though the house was by no means full -- perhaps on account of the unfavorable weather.

abstract: Veteran Observer on Development of the American Race
snippet: Veteran Observer on Development of the American Race
lead_paragraph: -- The "Veteran Observ- er" of the TIMES furnished an interesting disquisition on Tuesday upon the position of the American Man among the races of the world. Basing his remarks upon statistics of the State of Ohio, he showed that in height the American man surpassed the men of other nations; that in measurement round the chest he was surpassed by only one European people; that the solid contents of his body were nearly as great as that of the larger-chested man, and much greater than of most other peoples; and from these facts the corollary was drawn that, in strength and capacity for labor, the American man is superior to the European. This is a topic of very great interest, and we could wish that the collated statistics from which to form conclusions were much more extensive than they are. There never was such an opportunity as now to obtain data on the subject, from military sources; and we hope some of our statisticians or statistical societies will embrace it, and work up the material. Probably the conclusions our correspondent draws from the Ohio man are not applicable to the people of all the other sections of the country -- not, for instance, to some of the Eastern States. Travelers and observers have noticed the remarkable development in stature and bulk of the people grown in some of the Western and Southern States, especially the agricultural classes, in Ohio. Kentucky, East Tennessee and Northern Georgia; and, as all these regions were largely populated from Virginia, the same remark may apply to that State. Hoosiers and Vermonters are also noted for their vast length, and perhaps with good reason. On all these points information might be gathered from regimental records, and the offices of the Adjutants-General of States.

abstract: The Government has received dispatches from Gen. GRANT, dated as late as the 8th inst. The tone of the dispatches shows that he fears neither the enemy in his front nor in his rear. He believes himself able to protect his lines under any circumstances likely to arise. He states that Gen. JOHNSTON is concentrating troops to operate against him, and mentions a report that three divisions have been detached from BRAGG's army to reinforce JOHNSTON. BRECKINRIDGE is known to have already joined him. Gen. GRANT is in communication with Gen. BANKS, and has advices from Port Hudson as late as the 4th inst. Everything there looks favorable to our final success. This sets at rest the rebel report that Gen. BANKS had been repulsed, and proves the KIRBY SMITH story to have been entirely false. An unofficial telegram received in Washington, states that a small force of rebels attacked Milliken's Bend and Young's Point on the 6th, but were decisively repulsed at both points. The colored troops at the former place at first gave way, but upon hearing that three of their number who were captured had been killed, they rallied with great fury and routed the rebels. Another unofficial telegram states that Gen. KIMBALL, who had been sent up the Yazoo River to Sartaria, 30 miles below Yazoo City, with 3,000 men, on the 4th inst., encountered a rebel force under Gen. WIRT ADAMS, and after a fight of thirty minutes routed them totally, with considerable loss in killed, wounded and prisoners.
lead_paragraph: The Government has received dispatches from Gen. GRANT, dated as late as the 8th inst. The tone of the dispatches shows that he fears neither the enemy in his front nor in his rear. abstract: EXHIBITION OF PUBLIC SCHOOL No. 6. The Academy of Music was crowded Wednesday evening to the gallery on the occasion of the first public exhibition of the Ward School No. 6, S.M. PERKINS, Principal. The exercises consisted of singing, tableaux, declamation, drills by the boys, calisthenics by the girls, and special addresses. Not for a long time has a more interesting entertainment been presented in our sister city.
lead_paragraph: EXHIBITION OF PUBLIC SCHOOL No. 6. The Academy of Music was crowded Wednesday evening to the gallery on the occasion of the first public exhibition of the Ward School No. 6, S.M. PERKINS, Principal. The exercises consisted of singing, tableaux, declamation, drills by the boys, calisthenics by the girls, and special addresses. Not for a long time has a more interesting entertainment been presented in our sister city. The pupils, though generally quite young, performed their various parts with a promptitude, a precision, and a spirit that would have done credit to any age. The Primary (youngest) Department, especially excited admiration. Nothing could be more charming than some of their singing, their tableaux, and their calisthenic performances. The excellence of the older girls in elocution, who are under the charge of Miss TUTHILL, now and for the last seven years Principal of the Female Grammar Department, also evoked great applause. One performance in this department was particularly effective -- a representation of the States by thirty-five girls in white, arranged in groups -- the seven loyal and the four disloyal of the original thirteen, the fifteen loyal and seven disloyal of the later States. A most pathetic appeal was made by Western Virginia to Old Virginia to return to the old altars; then a classic, yet unsparing rebuke by Massachusetts to the four faithless ones of the old family; then a rougher admonition by "Old Kentuck," directed to the other recreants; and, finally, a magnanimous address by New-York, as the Empire State, to all, in the spirit of prophecy. The elocution of each of the four misses who sustained these parts was remarkably fine, and could hardly be excelled in any institution of the country, however high its grade. The patriotic spirit that pervaded all the exercises was very marked, and attested that the teachers are fully alive to the duty they owe the country. Brooklyn has reason to be proud of this school, and all the more so because its pupils are mainly drawn from the poorer classes of the city. The constant improvement and elevation of our free public schools of this character is one of the most encouraging developments of the times; and every citizen should feel in it both an individual interest and a personal pride.

abstract: A Lady's Experiences at
snippet: A Lady's Experiences at
lead_paragraph: While at Alexandria I met a correspondent of your paper, who, upon hearing an account of my experiences in Texas, desired me to state them in the columns of the TIMES, believing they would be of interest to some few of its many readers. Arriving in Texas before the inception of this war -- indeed, before our last Presidential election -- I had an opportunity of watching the rise and progress, but unfortunately, not the fall, of the secession sentiment in the State; and I shall endeavor to give succinctly, after stating the particulars of my trip to New-Orleans, what I believe to be the condition of the country and people.

abstract: We have stupendous stories  every few weeks of the discovery and unearthing in some State or other, mainly in the Northwest, of some new, secret, treacherous and wide-spread organization of the Knights of the Golden Circle. The biggest story we have had of late, and which was widely published and believed, was that of the discovery of an organization in Pennsylvania, which comprised nearly the whole able-bodied.
lead_paragraph: -- We have stupendous stories every few weeks of the discovery and unearthing in some State or other, mainly in the Northwest, of some new, secret, treacherous and wide-spread organization of the Knights of the Golden Circle. The biggest story we have had of late, and which was widely published and believed, was that of the discovery of an organization in Pennsylvania, which comprised nearly the whole able-bodied population of that State, and which had for its object the overthrow of the Government, the capture of Washington, and the seizure and decapitation of Mr. LINCOLN. Within the last few weeks, equally great and infamous organizations have been discovered, for the third or fourth time, in Indiana, Illinois and Ohio; and it has even been asserted that the whole Northwest is honey-combed with secret treasonable societies. No wonder that the nerves of a good many people beside old women are shaken by these revelations; no wonder that they destroy confidence and produce suspicion and uneasiness in many communities; for if whole counties and districts whole States and tiers of States, usually classed as loyal, are as full of secret treason as the rebel States are of overt treason, then the existence of government or of civil order cannot long be counted upon.

abstract: Speech at Brooklyn; Democratic Meeting; Speech at Brooklyn Democratic Meeting; Democratic Mass Meeting
snippet: Speech at Brooklyn; Democratic Meeting; Speech at Brooklyn Democratic Meeting; Democratic Mass Meeting
lead_paragraph: A mass meeting was held at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn, last evening, under the auspices of the Kings County Democratic Club. By the terms of the call, it was to be a meeting of "all conservation citizens in favor of the Union, the Constitution and the laws, and opposed to all usurpations of arbitrary power;" but either on account of the rain, or because the people of Brooklyn are not so fully alive to the dangers which threaten their liberties as the Kings County Democratic Club, there was not so full an attendance as might have reasonably been expected. The house was a little more than two-thirds full. About 8 1/2 o'clock the Mayor, accompanied by Hon. AMASA J. PARKER, made his appearance on the stage, and was received with applause. Capt. RYNDERS entered about the same time, and was greeted by a portion of the audience with much more noisy, if not quite so unanimous demonstrations of welcome. The meeting was immediately thereafter called to order by ANDREW R. CULVER, President of the Kings County Democratic Club, who nominated for Chairman MARTIN KALBFLEISCH, Mayor of the City. The nomination was unanimously indorsed, and Mayor KALBFLIESCH returned the compliment in the following speech:

abstract: Our Vicksburgh  correspondent photographs Gen. GRANT and the leading Generals of his army. GRANT has been peculiarly fortunate in the brilliant array of officers he has gathered around him. lead_paragraph: -- Our Vicksburgh correspondent photographs Gen. GRANT and the leading Generals of his army. GRANT has been peculiarly fortunate in the brilliant array of officers he has gathered around him. There have been few changes in the chief officers of his army. He selects them with sagacity, puts them in their proper positions, and retains them there. Even Gen. SHERMAN, who has been one of the most unfortunate officers, he retains in high command knowing, probably, that his ill-luck has not been the result of his personal qualities, but has been in spite of the most soldierly qualifications. We hear of no quarreling and intriguing among the officers of Gen. GRANT. All work harmoniously together, and all look up to him as their proper chief. It is pleasant to know that we have one army in which all the officers are as united and efficient as they are devoted, patriotic and brave.

abstract: There is an old saying that a certain very mischievous personage always finds work for idle hands. Our Generals out of the field seem to have fallen into his keeping. A very fierce controversy has been started between Gens. BUTLER, FREMONT and MCCLELLAN, as to their relative rank in the army. Gen. BUTLER claims that although his commission is dated two days later than the others, it was the President's intention to put him ahead. The question has been referred to a Board, and each of the Generals has been called on for a written argument on the subject. Why will not the President set these officers at work, and thus postpone their controversies about rank until the country has nothing better to do than examine them?

abstract: New-York Yacht Club Regatta
snippet: New-York Yacht Club Regatta
lead_paragraph: Water is a desirable element for yacht racing, as well as for canals, aqueducts and navigation generally. It is not, however, so essential over, as it is under the yachts. Therefore, as far as the rain of yesterday concerned the yacht race, it may be considered out of place. But, after all, it was "only a shower," and brought its compensation in a fair breeze that filled the sails of the white winged coursers in the lower bay until their speed vied with the steam tugs, so that upon the whole the yachtsmen have no complaints to make of Jupiter Pluvius. The day was fair enough for the veriest landlubber to keep his sea legs, and still the breeze was one which the Club would be glad to insure for the next year. To be sure, only fifteen of the half a hundred yachts of the Club entered for the race, and a contest with the Julia, Una, Rebecca, America, Henrietta and Widgeon left out, is much like "Hamlet" with the part of Hamlet left out, or the TIMES without its editorial page; still, the dozen boats that did sail afforded a fair day's amusement. It is likewise a fact that the Regatta Committee, Messrs. HASWELL, ROLLINS and WESTRAY, did not succeed in enabling the representatives of the Press to see either the start or the close of the race, but they performed wonders in the line of duty. They did all the ciphering beforehand, so that the dear public knew, what it never knew before, that the first three boats reaching the home stakeboat, would take the first three prizes. This was a great advance, because, heretofore, it appeared to be the fact that races were won by ciphering and not by sailing, "the allowance of time" often making an apparently late boat really the winner. The Committee did all their ciphering before the start, which simplified matters much. To be sure, no opportunity was furnished the press, to ascertain what was "the allowance of time influenced by the wind at the time of starting." But, as Mr. TOOTS philosophically remarked, it's of no consequence, we know who won, as the sequel will show. It was an excellent regulation of the Committee, that each yacht sailing in the race should carry her signal at her peak; but the Committee cannot be blamed because some yachts carried signals not down in the flagbook, another, a signal that belonged to different yachts, and others didn't carry any signals at all. In fact, there was every proof that the Club would have done the spectators a great service had it adopted the sensible suggestion of Mr. GODWIN, made about ten years since, that each yacht shall carry a plain distinguishing mark like the numbers on the sails of the pilot boats. With the exception, therefore, of an opportunity to see all the race, or to know much about what they did see, the members of the Press were well cared for by the Committee. Certainly they could ask no better attention to their creature comforts, and, if they had gone to the Regatta to eat, drink and be merry, instead of to report, they could have no cause for complaint. It is not intended hereby to suggest that the eating, drinking, or being merry should be curtailed, but, that the facilities for reporting should be increased.

abstract: The annexed list of losses of Boston offices, caused by the depredations of the Anglo-Rebel pirates Alabama and Florida, shows that the risks of capture have not been underrated. The Navy Department were long since notified of the apprehended trouble on the line, and what seven United States vessels of war found to do in St. Thomas about the time of these captures and at latest dates, May 4, is more than we can imagine. It has been said by some ill-disposed persons that our national vessels were more willing to encounter the perils of a stay in port than the chances of a desperate fight with the rogues. We hope they are mistaken. Probably, on the receipt of the next news, the risk will be considered so great, as to materially advance the war premiums, or cause a cessation of war writing altogether.

abstract: Freedom of the and Gen. Burnside; And the Freedom of the Press
snippet: Freedom of the and Gen. Burnside; And the Freedom of the Press
lead_paragraph: -- Some of our neighbors comment in a tone of censure upon the neglect of the TIMES to be represented at a recent meeting of Editors, held to discuss the restrictions, if any, proper to be placed on the discussions of the Press during the war. We did not attend, because we regard this whole matter as one upon which each individual Editor must exercise his own judgment and act accordingly. Any attempt to lay down a code of rules for the government of all journalists will fail, -- as indeed all attempts to secure unity of action among newspapers on any subject will fail, and ought to fail. The utility of the Press depends entirely on its independence -- by which we mean not its power as a combination to defy hostility, but the complete freedom of each individual editor to express, without dictation from Government, or from any class or profession, even his own, as such, the views on public affairs of those for whom to a certain extent he speaks. He is entitled, like any other citizen, to the protection of the law in so doing; and if he infringes the rights of others, or is reckless of the public good, he may and should be held responsible to the legal tribunals -- just as is any other citizen for any other offence.

abstract: A Cincinnati newspaper  NEGRO NEWS. A Cincinnati newspaper contains the important announcement that an intelligent contraband who lately came within Gen. GRANT'S lines, brought the news that he had overheard PEMBERTON remark that there were six months' provisions in Vicksburgh. This settles the question as to the leugth of time it will take Gen. GRANT to starve out Vicksburgh. It will be effected about December next.
lead_paragraph: A Cincinnati newspaper NEGRO NEWS. A Cincinnati newspaper contains the important announcement that an intelligent contraband who lately came within Gen. GRANT'S lines, brought the news that he had overheard PEMBERTON remark that there were six months' provisions in Vicksburgh. This settles the question as to the leugth of time it will take Gen. GRANT to starve out Vicksburgh. It will be effected about December next. We give the statement, as it will tend to modify popular expectation of immediate results at Vicksburgh. Seeptical persons might be inclined to doubt the veracity of the contraband and the rebel commander; but let them wait patiently for a half year, and see if they be not reliable.

abstract: Yesterday the Sixth New-York Volunteers (WILSON's Zouaves) were publicly received by portions of the military and civic authorities of this City. In conformity with orders, the Zouaves assembled at the Park Barracks at 9 A.M., where they remained till nearly the hour appointed for the review. Throughout the day the space in the vicinity of the Barracks was crowded with the friends and relatives of the regiment, and late in the afternoon the iron paling inclosing the buildings was mounted by scores of urchins who had taken that position to get an advantageous view of the regiment as it formed in line. At noon, a slight rain commenced falling, and the sky betokened copious quantities of that element for the remainder of the day. But, fortunately, the afternoon passed with only a sprinkling of rain at intervals. At 5 P.M. the Eleventh and Twenty-second regiments N.Y.N.G., marched down Broadway, and halted in front of the Astor House.

abstract: ANOTHER VICTIM OF THE BAXTER-STREET FIRE. -- MARGERET KEATING, another of the victims of the Baxter-street fire which occurred in Baxter-street on Tuesday morning last, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, whither she had been conveyed after having been turned away from the City Hospital on the night of the accident. The deceased was about fifty years of age, and resided at No, 15 Baxter-street. The Coroner's jury rendered a verdict that the deceased came to her death from injuries received by jumping from a second story window to escape from the flames.

abstract: Chicago Times, Hon. I. N. Arnold and Senator Trumbull on Suppression of the
snippet: Chicago Times, Hon. I. N. Arnold and Senator Trumbull on Suppression of the
lead_paragraph: -- We publish elsewhere a letter from Hon. J.N. ARNOLD and a speech by Senator TRUMBULL., on the recent attempt to suppress the Chicago Times by military authority, in a State which has not yet been subjected to martial law. Both these gentlemen are well-known Republicans, and cannot, by any possibility, be suspected of the slightest sympathy with Secession, or with any of its aiders or abettors. They are both warm friends of the President and of his Administration, and cannot, therefore, be suspected of any wish to promote the progress and triumph of the Democratic party. Yet both condemn, in the most unequivocal terms, the attempt of Gen. BURNSIDE to substitute a file of soldiers for the ordinary process of law, and to make the property and liberty of individuals subject to the caprice of a military commander, rather than the requirements of the civil law.

abstract: We think there are signs  that the armies of HOOKER and of ROSECRANS are not likely to remain long inactive. Pre- cisely what all these signs are, it may be as well not to publish. In both of the armies on the Rappahannock things look unsettled and stormy.
lead_paragraph: -- We think there are signs that the armies of HOOKER and of ROSECRANS are not likely to remain long inactive. Pre- cisely what all these signs are, it may be as well not to publish. In both of the armies on the Rappahannock things look unsettled and stormy. HOOKER's late infantry movement to the other side of the river, just below the rebel lines, and his cavalry movement to Culpepper Court-house, in the opposite direction, show that he is closely watching the enemy, either with designs upon him or to learn his designs. The movement of a heavy rebel force to Culpepper Court-house, consisting of detachments of two arms of their service and the whole of their cavalry arm, -- and the reconnoissances of the rebels toward the Potomac, indicate their projects if not their plans; while the fact that all the able-bodied citizens of Pennsylvania have been summoned to arms by Gen. COUCH, shows the deep and pervading apprehension of invasion. Gen. ROSECRANS, in the West, has received some newspaper censure for remaining so long inactive, while GRANT was waging his heroic battles around Vicksburgh. It is altogether unjust, as those who give it would admit, if they comprehended ROSECRANS' position and his assigned duty. His half-year's inactivity, however, is likely to be broken very soon, and that, too, by his own act. The month of June may yet prove as stirring a month for ROSECRANS as May was for GRANT.

abstract: Every true patriot has reason to rejoice in the nomination of VALLANDIGHAM to be Gov- ernor of Ohio. It is the third great step toward establishing the true line between the loyal and the disloyal men of the North. The first was taken by the Copperheads of Connecticut in their attempt to make THOMAS H. SEYMOUR, an open and unqualified opponent...
lead_paragraph: Every true patriot has reason to rejoice in the nomination of VALLANDIGHAM to be Gov- ernor of Ohio. It is the third great step toward establishing the true line between the loyal and the disloyal men of the North. The first was taken by the Copperheads of Connecticut in their attempt to make THOMAS H. SEYMOUR, an open and unqualified opponent of the war from the outset, Governor of that State. The second was taken by FERNANDO WOOD and his coadjutors in this State, in their late inauguration of a distinctive peace party, with clearly-defined peace principles. This third step, by the Copperheads of Ohio, is precisely in the same line, and tends to just the same gratifying result. We hail it, as we did the others.

abstract: We are ena-  bled, this morning, to give the first full account we have had of a battle, about which, thus far, we have known so little the late battle at Port Hudson. The narrative is truly thrilling. The heroism of our troops, black and white, never was surpassed.
lead_paragraph: We are enabled, this morning, to give the first full account we have had of a battle, about which, thus far, we have known so little -- the late battle at Port Hudson. The narrative is truly thrilling. The heroism of our troops, black and white, never was surpassed. The conduct of the blacks is most noticed, as it is the first real battle of the war in which they have been engaged. No body of troops -- Western, Eastern, or rebel -- have fought better in this war. We wish that the story of their exploits may be read by every patriot, copperhead, and traitor in the land.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Mississippi, which left New-Orleans on the 6th inst., we receive our Port Hudson correspondence to the 3d, and our New-Orleans correspondence to the date of sailing. The siege of Port Hudson was progressing satisfactorily our correspondent fully expecting the place to be in our possession before his letter could appear in print.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Mississippi, which left New-Orleans on the 6th inst., we receive our Port Hudson correspondence to the 3d, and our New-Orleans correspondence to the date of sailing. The siege of Port Hudson was progressing satisfactorily our -- correspondent fully expecting the place to be in our possession before his letter could appear in print. The full description of the assault of the 27th inst. -- the first reliable one which has been published -- will be read with interest. A very full list of casualties is also given. From our New-Orleans correspondent we learn that Gen. SHERMAN was still alive, though in a critical condition. His leg had not been amputated. The Era of June 3, publishes an important order from Gen. BANKS, to the effect that no interference is to be allowed with plantation property. Articles heretofore taken are to be restored. The guerrillas were again making some trouble in the Teche Country, but no s???s damage had been done.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Corswa arrived at this port yesterday from Havana, bringing the particulars of the capitulation of Puebla, brought from Vera Cruz by the steamer Trent. It will be seen that the Mexican account of the surrender, as received by way of Acapulco and San Francisco, is fully substantiated by the reliable details which we now publish. COMONFORT having failed to relieve the garrison, ORTEGG was forced to surrender by sheer starvation -- the mules, artillery horses, and even the dogs in the city having all been devoured -- and by the want of ammunition.

abstract: One of our neighbors  affects great alarm over the "fearful danger of a centralization and consolidation of the Government." Just at this moment this sounds like a rather dismal joke. With one section of the Union doing everything in its power to destroy the Government, with half a million of armed men in the field fighting to rend the Union asunder, with men scattered....
lead_paragraph: -- One of our neighbors affects great alarm over the "fearful danger of a centralization and consolidation of the Government." Just at this moment this sounds like a rather dismal joke. With one section of the Union doing everything in its power to destroy the Government, -- with half a million of armed men in the field fighting to rend the Union asunder, -- with men scattered throughout the North aiding them in the effort, and every foreign hater of free institutions giving them the benefit of moral sympathy and material aid, there would not seem to be any danger of "centralization" fearful enough to alarm the soul of an average patriot. The terrified democracy must have been reduced to a very feeble state, if it is thus affrighted at imaginary dangers. The danger that threatens the country now is disunion not consolidation. The fear is lest we should fall to pieces, -- lest the Southern States should break away from the Union, and set the example of successful revolt to other States When that peril shall have been averted we can attend to others; but while it continues to overhang the nation, all others are comparatively insignificant.

abstract: The fall of Puebla
snippet: The fall of Puebla
lead_paragraph: In the siege and fall of Puebla another extraordinary chapter is added to the ex- traordinary history of Mexico. The official documents and circumstantial details, received via Havana, and published this morning, relative to the termination of the siege and the capitulation of Gen. ORTEGA, deserve and will command universal attention. The account is evidently truthful, and disproves much of the statement originally put forth by the French.

lead_paragraph: The United States steamship Mississippi, Capt. BAXTER, from New Orleans on the 6th Inst., arrived at this port yesterday. She crossed the bar at the Southwest Pass at 5:15 P.M., and made the passage to this port in five days and seventeen hours. She did not bring any mails, but through the courtesy of the Purser, we are placed in possession of our correspondence from Port Hudson and New Orleans, and full files of the New-Orleans papers.

abstract: EXPLOSION IN A PERCUSSION CAP MANUFACTORY. An explosion occurred in the percussion cap manufactory of JOSEPH GOLDMARK, Carroll-street, near Third-avenue, about 10 o'clock on Friday morning. It was caused while charging the caps, and resulted in serious injuries to Miss MARY CUNNINGHAM, one of the girls employed there.
lead_paragraph: EXPLOSION IN A PERCUSSION CAP MANUFACTORY. -- An explosion occurred in the percussion cap manufactory of JOSEPH GOLDMARK, Carroll-street, near Third-avenue, about 10 o'clock on Friday morning. It was caused while charging the caps, and resulted in serious injuries to Miss MARY CUNNINGHAM, one of the girls employed there. The damage to the building was slight, precautions having been taken, in consequence of several accidents heretofore, to keep as small an amount of combust???ble material as possible in the work rooms. This is the third or fourth explosion that has occurred on these premises within as many years.

abstract: Reynolds vs. Bark Simoon; Seamen's Wages
snippet: Reynolds vs. Bark Simoon; Seamen's Wages
lead_paragraph: David Selling vs. William A. Kobbe and Edward L. Corlies. -- This was a common law action, brought in this Court because the defendant, Kobbe, was a Consul of one of the German States. The suit was brought to recover for damages alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiff on account of the defendant negligently allowing water to run from his premises upon the plaintiff's goods. Both parties occupied parts of the building No.39 Murray-Street. In June, 1862, when the plaintiff came to his store on Monday morning, he found that the water had run down, from defendant's premises and injured his goods, and he claimed that the defendants had left a stopcock open. The defendants, on the other hand, claimed that the damage was occasioned by the plaintiff himself failing to turn off the water in a closet to which both parties had access.

abstract: IMPORTANT ARREST OF BURGLARS. For several weeks past, burglaries, some of them of an exensive character, have been perpetrated upon the citizens of the Twentieth Preoinct. On the 21st ult, the store of MAURIOE SIMON, No. 521 Eighth-avenue, was forcibly entered in the night time, and over $100 worth of hats stolen therefrom.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT ARREST OF BURGLARS. -- For several weeks past, burglaries, some of them of an exensive character, have been perpetrated upon the citizens of the Twentieth Preoinct. On the 21st ult, the store of MAURIOE SIMON, No. 521 Eighth-avenue, was forcibly entered in the night time, and over $100 worth of hats stolen therefrom. A few nights subsequent, the store of Mr. NATHANIEL C. BETTS was entered in some manner, and the thieves made good their escape with a large quantity of boots and shoes Detective IRVING, of the Twentieth Precinct, although he used due vigilance to ferret out the guilty parties, was for many days wholly unsuccessful. Meantime the number of burglaries increased, and almost nightly reports were made of depredations committed. Officer IRVING, on Friday night, arrested FREDERICK LALOR, alias Smith, who, in company with JAMES CAVERN and RICHARD MEAD, was at the time engaged in a burglary in Eighth-avenue. LALOR was the only man secured, the confederates having speedily escaped, as soon as the officer made his appearance. LALOR was taken to court, and identified as one of the persons engaged in stealing the hats and boots above referred to. Justice QUACKENBUSH committed him for trial.

abstract: -The  Chattanooga Rebel says: "On the fate of Vicksburgh hangs the fate of Middle and East Tennessee. If we play eternal smash with GRANT, good bye to poor ROSECRANS; but if GRANT gives PEMBERTON his quietus, then farewell, a long farewell, to the proposed reoccupation of Nashville and southern Kentucky."
lead_paragraph: -- The Chattanooga Rebel says: "On the fate of Vicksburgh hangs the fate of Middle and East Tennessee. If we play eternal smash with GRANT, good bye to poor ROSECRANS; but if GRANT gives PEMBERTON his quietus, then farewell, a long farewell, to the proposed reoccupation of Nashville and southern Kentucky." The Rebel is right in its speculations on the vast bearings of the campaign against Vicksburgh, and the results likely to follow upon the success or failure of either side. It is not merely Vicksburgh -- not merely the Mississippi River -- it is the whole Southwest whose fate will be decided, for some time at least, by the fortunes of GRANT. The fall of Fort Donelson, far north on the Cumberland River, carried our arms to Nashville, to the southern line of Tennessee, to Florence in Alabama, and subsequently to Memphis and to Vicksburgh itself. Hardly less far-reaching could be the results of a success at Vicksburgh. We doubt whether the rebels would try to make a stand anywhere west of the Tombigbee River, and they might even find it necessary to retreat to Montgomery or Atlanta. It would probably also compel BRAGG to evacuate Shelbyville by making an attack on his rear feasible, and might give us possession of East Tennessee, and plant us on the line of Georgia, and close to the Southwestern line of Virginia. The fall of Donelson not only gave us half the rebel territory this side of the river, but, in its consequences, it may be said to have given us the whole country west of the Mississippi; for no great rebel armies have latterly existed in that region; and the occupation of its stragetic points is simply a matter of our convenience. If we obtain the States of Mississippi and Alabama by the fall of Vicksburgh, that section would probably be for some time in the same condition in which the trans-Mississippi region has been -- haunted by guerrillas and having small rebel bodies stationed here and there to give us trouble. But the war there, in its larger features, would be closed.

abstract: -Some fears are ex-  pressed for Gen. BANKS fears lest a rebel force of 10,000 men, less or more, gathered from Mobile and elsewhere, or a detachment from JOHNSTON's army, might suddenly march to his rear and make an assault, while the rebel garrison sallied out and attacked his line of investment.
lead_paragraph: -- Some fears are expressed for Gen. BANKS fears lest a rebel force of 10,000 men, less or more, gathered from Mobile and elsewhere, or a detachment from JOHNSTON's army, might suddenly march to his rear and make an assault, while the rebel garrison sallied out and attacked his line of investment. The main value of Vicksburgh is that it gives the rebels command of the Mississippi, and Port Hudson would effect the object as well. If JOHNSTON finds it impossible to operate in GRANT's rear, he will relinquish that object, fall on BANKS' rear and capture his army, which will make up for the inevitable loss of Vicksburgh. At Port Hudson, also, he would be within striking distance of New Orleans, where we have no army now that could for a moment withstand him.

abstract: TIONS. Several new and valuable military institutions are at this moment rounding themselves into form. There is the Soldiers' Home, for such soldiers of this State as have faithfully served their country, and are disabled from further service.
lead_paragraph: -- Several new and valuable military institutions are at this moment rounding themselves into form. There is the Soldiers' Home, for such soldiers of this State as have faithfully served their country, and are disabled from further service. There is the Invalid Corps, for such disabled soldiers as are unfitted for hard field service, yet are anxious to spend their lives in the lighter military labors, such as garrison duty, etc. This furnishes a splendid opening for our wounded veterans who are now daily coming out of the hospitals convalescent. Only those men disabled in the service, whether still in the army or honorably discharged, will be received in this Corps of Honor. Those capable of performing guard duty and light marches will be assigned to duty in the First Battalion; those who have lost an arm, to the Second Battalion; those who have lost a leg, and are least effective, to the Third Battalion. Provision is also made, to some extent, for the education and maintenance of the families of those of our soldiers who may be left unprovided for by the casualties of war. One institution, the "Union Home School," held its anniversary on Wednesday evening at the Academy of Music, which was honored by the presence of the Mayor, the Board of Aldermen, the Board of Education, and a vast and wealthy audience. It now has in charge 175 soldiers' children, all of whom are fed, clothed and cared for; and application has been made for the immediate admission of 100 more. They will be admitted as soon as this liberal and patriotic community furnishes the means, which no doubt will be done as soon as they are informed that the means are needed.

abstract: -The Reformed  Dutch Church, less considerable in size than many of the Christian denominations of the country, is inferior to few in intelligence, wealth, and social influence.
lead_paragraph: -- The Reformed Dutch Church, less considerable in size than many of the Christian denominations of the country, is inferior to few in intelligence, wealth, and social influence. It is a homogeneous, conservative body, embracing many clergymen of distinction. At the recent meeting of the General Synod at Newburgh, of which the Rev. Dr. CHAMBERS, of this City, was President, the Report on the State of the Country gave expression to the loyalty of the body in terms singularly dignified and appropriate. Without a word of discussion, the vote was taken -- an earnest, rousing aye, attesting the Christian patriotism of the Church. The call for negative votes was responded to by a solitary tenor voice. The President declared the vote to be almost unanimous, when the owner of the "No" arose and inquired if he might explain his vote? "No, Sir," said the President. "Can't I, with the leave of the house?" "Yes," said the President, "does any one move for leave?" Not, a member stirred to take the parliamentary clamp from the jaws of the only avowed "Copperhead" in a body of one hundred and thirty members. Poor encouragement that for Northern secession sympathizers.

abstract: The cavalry battle on Tuesday last was far the greatest cavalry engagement we have had in this war, and one of the most noteworthy on record. Our correspondent's account of it was the most extended, lucid and vigorous, that has been anywhere published. There were about twenty-five thousand horsemen engaged on both sides, or about twelve thousand on each, with infantry and artillery supports; and the fighting, much of it hand-to-hand, lasted for ten hours. Our troopers behaved splendidly, and furnished another proof of the efficiency of our cavalry arm. The Superiority of the rebel horsemen is a thing of the past. The Government, it will have been noticed from our advertising columns, is specially inviting troops for the cavalry, through the Provost-Marshals, and there is no more inviting work than this for the chivalry of the North.

lead_paragraph: -- The Enrollment in the Fourth Congressional District in this City will probably be completed, so far as taking the names, in about a week's time. The Enrollment has been effected in the most thorough manner -- people being called upon at their places of business and labor as well as at their residences, that no one possibly escape. Notice is given in the TIMES, to-day, that if any one knows any name not enrolled, he should report it to the Deputy Provost-Marshal. The names of all persons are taken and arranged in alphabetical order, and the names of those residing out of the City, or in another district, are respectively sent to the district in which they reside, and compared, so as to prevent a double Enrollment.

abstract: Protection of our Troops
snippet: Protection of our Troops
lead_paragraph: There is an absurd attempt being made in certain quarters to throw doubts on the ability, and even on the right of the Government, to protect, by retaliation, negro soldiers, who may happen to be made prisoners, from being put to death by the rebels. One writer, in the columns of one of our cotemporaries, declares that whatever the law of nations may say as to the propriety of our recruiting our armies from amongst the slaves, it says nothing whatever against the right of the South, or of any other Government, to punish its own subjects or deserters for treason when found arrayed in arms against it; so that, though the black prisoners may not be hanged as blacks, they may be hanged as traitors or mutineers.

abstract: Closing of the Chambers by the King
snippet: Closing of the Chambers by the King
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM of Brandenburgh has just put an end to the controversy between his Government and the Lower Chamber, by closing the Diet. The reasons assigned in the royal speech for this arbitrary proceeding cannot justify it. The addresses of the national representatives to the King, denouncing the illegal acts of Ministers; their opposition to the cartel conventions; their refusal to suffer the privileges of their President to be curtailed, afford but a poor basis for such a course; and if the people should conclude that their deputies have been dismissed because they dared to discharge their public duties, the conviction will not tend to strengthen the Court party at the next election. The sudden closing of the Chamber could not indeed have occurred at a more favorable period for the interests of liberty. Had the session been prolonged, the popular branch of the Diet, by factious obstruction of some beneficial measure, might have given the Cabinet a plausible pretext for getting rid of them. But now the Representatives can return to their constituents, and say, "We have been dismissed, ere the public business had well commenced, because we have stood up for your rights and ours, because we have attempted to shield Prussia from dishonor." Under these circumstances the people are likely to give the Liberal party an overwhelming majority in the next Chamber.

abstract: -- In continuation, from the Intelligencer of the 1st instant, of the details of Gen. These letters furnish the latest intelligence received by mail from our lines in front of Vicksburgh, and confirm the impressions produced by prior accounts, that at no time since the opening of this unfortunate war has our army performed a greater amount of labor within the same time than has been recently performed by that under Gen. abstract: We have the starting news this morning that the brig Clarence, "tender" of the pirate Florida, before reported as having captured the bark Whistling Wind, has made five captures in addition to that one all between the 7th and 12th inst., and three of them in latitude 37  18', longi-
lead_paragraph: We have the starting news this morning that the brig Clarence, "tender" of the pirate Florida, before reported as having captured the bark Whistling Wind, has made five captures in addition to that one all between the 7th and 12th inst., and three of them in latitude 37° 18′, longitude 75° 04′, only forty-five miles from Cape Charles, and consequently in close proximity to Fortress Monroe. Four of her captures were burned and two released on bond. The vessels captured were, in addition to the Whistling Wind, the brig Mary Alrina, the bark Tacony, the schooner M.A. Shindier, the schooner Kate Stewart, and another, name unknown.

abstract: Chicago on the Rampage--Conventions,>amp;c.
snippet: Chicago on the Rampage--Conventions,>amp;c.
lead_paragraph: We have ever held the young City of Chicago in fair esteem as a representative of Western enterprise and prosperity. Its natural position at the extreme southern point of Lake Michigan, made it the gateway of a large commerce seeking water transportation to the East, and its bifurcated little river could not have been planned better by art to accommodate the trade that the young city was destined to control. These facts, aided by Eastern wealth invested in numerous converging railroads, soon pushed Chicago into importance as a Western town; and by the year 1860, it contained over 100,000 inhabitants and several good hotels.

abstract: Mr. BIGELOW, our Consul at Paris, has prepared and published, in a volume of 500 pages, a history of the mineral, agricultural, industrial and commercial resources of our country, together with a review of the causes which produced the existing Rebellion, and an account of its progress and results. This work is designed to furnish Europe with needed information, and from the attention it is attracting, is evidently in the way of accomplishing its object. The London Saturday Review, a widely circulating and influential journal, of the 23d ultimo, contains an elaborate and impartial notice, from which we extract the opening and concluding paragraphs;

abstract: We have KIRBY SMITH in a new region this morning, playing havoc all round, and this time with the army of Gen. BANKS. During the last week he has cavorted up and down the Mississippi River on both its banks, (wonder how he crossed and recrossed;) -- up and down the Red River, and up and down generally. He has been at Mihiken's Bend, Young's Point, Point Coupee Semmesport, and Port Hudson. He has waded through swamps, forded rivers, swam bayous, and swept from point to point, hundreds of miles apart, with the velocity of lightning. Had the name been John Smith we might have supposed there were two or twenty different persons; but there can only be one KIRBY SMITH. Having devoured Gen. BANKS' army, he can now turn his attention to Gen. GRANT, and after that ROSECRANS and HOOKER may lie on his route. As he seems to be everywhere at the same moment, it may be doubted whether he is anywhere at any one moment.
lead_paragraph: We have KIRBY SMITH in a new region this morning, playing havoc all round, and this time with the army of Gen. BANKS. During the last week he has cavorted up and down the Mississippi River on both its banks, (wonder how he crossed and recrossed;) -- up and down the Red River, and up and down generally. He has been at Mihiken's Bend, Young's Point, Point Coupee Semmesport, and Port Hudson. He has waded through swamps, forded rivers, swam bayous, and swept from point to point, hundreds of miles apart, with the velocity of lightning. Had the name been John Smith we might have supposed there were two or twenty different persons; but there can only be one KIRBY SMITH. Having devoured Gen. BANKS' army, he can now turn his attention to Gen. GRANT, and after that ROSECRANS and HOOKER may lie on his route. abstract: News from Japan to the 11th of May has been received by way of San Francisco. There were thirteen British war vessels at Kanagawa. The English Admiral had demanded of the Japanese Government a large indemnity, and the surrender of the murderers of Mr. RICHARDSON, the British Consul. Should the demand be refused, England and France would declare war against Japan. The native inhabitants had nearly all left Kanagawa, and all merchant vessels had been detained to take on board the foreign residents in case war ensued, which was considered probable.

abstract: The samples of "Union" tyranny in the Confederate towns that have fallen into the hands of the enemy, have evidently had their effect in Mobile, and, the Register says. have aroused a determination in the people to take their posts alongside of the Confederate troops, and defend the city to the last. Happily, two years of almost daily expectation of an attack by land and water have enabled the vigilant military authorities to place the city in a complete ??? of defence. While the harbor is impregnably ??? against gunboat attacks, the land defences ??? constructed that it would require a powerful army to carry them against even a feeble garrison.
lead_paragraph: The samples of "Union" tyranny in the Confederate towns that have fallen into the hands of the enemy, have evidently had their effect in Mobile, and, the Register says. have aroused a determination in the people to take their posts alongside of the Confederate troops, and defend the city to the last. Happily, two years of almost daily expectation of an attack by land and water have enabled the vigilant military authorities to place the city in a complete ??? of defence. While the harbor is impregnably ??? against gunboat attacks, the land defences ??? constructed that it would require a powerful army to carry them against even a feeble garrison.

lead_paragraph: -- Hon. Samuel A. Brown died in Jamestown, Chautauque County, on June 7, 1863. He was the son of a Revolutionary soldier, and was born in Hebron, Conn., Feb. 20, 1795. He commenced the study of the law in his 18th year, and having completed his course, started for "the West," ultimately settling at Jamestown. He was admitted to the bar in 1817, and in the next year commenced practicing in the Supreme Court. He was elected to the Assembly in 1826, and was appointed District Attorney for the county in 1828. In 1843 he wrote a history of Chatauque County, and in 1844 was again elected to the Legislature. He died of typhoid fever.

abstract: The season is drawing languidly to a close, and the hardy provincials who seize upon the metropolis in the dog-days have not yet made their appearance. The "managers" who have a reputation with these...
lead_paragraph: The season is drawing languidly to a close, and the hardy provincials who seize upon the metropolis in the dog-days have not yet made their appearance. The "managers" who have a reputation with these classes, and expect to bag them, are chaffering with the proprietors of the various theatrical establishments, and will burst into full-blown direction in the course of a week or two. As to the theatrical profession of the City, the leading members of it will go to the country, and the rest, less provident, if not less gifted, will appear, with fitful industry, at all sorts of establishments. There are indications of a very active Summer season; let us hope that it will also be a profitable one. Miss MAGGIE MITCHELL and the WEBB sisters will soon open the campaign, and Mr. MARK SMITH, with a well-selected company, will follow suit. At Niblo's Garden the new play will probably run until the commencement of Mr. FORREST's engagement, in September, so that the artists we have named, and others who may come, will be divided between the Winter Garden and Laura Keene's, for Mr. WALLACK's handsome establishment will not, we understand, be sublet for dramatic purposes.

abstract: The Albion denies  with a profusion of emphasis and epithets, a recent statement in the TIMES that England has any desire to "break down the great and growing power of the United States." We are delighted to hear it.
lead_paragraph: -- The Albion denies with a profusion of emphasis and epithets, a recent statement in the TIMES that England has any desire to "break down the great and growing power of the United States." We are delighted to hear it. We are under deep and lasting obligations to the, Albion for correcting our mistake, and for reassuring our perturbed souls as to the designs of England. Instead of "persistently and atrociously misrepresenting" that respectable nation on this point by "scandalous perversions of truth and falsifications of history," we put on record the consoling and conclusive assurance of our weekly cotemporary. We trust England will regard this as entirely satisfactory, and accept the assurances of our distinguished consideration.

abstract: -The Legislature, at its last ses  sion, enacted that the Mayor and Comptroller of this City "shall designate four papers having the largest daily circulation, and any six others in their discretion--not to exceed ten in all "--and that the Corporation advertising shall be done in those papers and in no others. One would think this reasonably explicit and imperative;
lead_paragraph: -- The Legislature, at its last session, enacted that the Mayor and Comptroller of this City "shall designate four papers having the largest daily circulation, and any six others in their discretion -- not to exceed ten in all " -- and that the Corporation advertising shall be done in those papers and in no others. One would think this reasonably explicit and imperative; but the ingenuity of City officials is adequate to any emergency. Under the law a circular was issued to the papers of the City, from the replies to which it appeared that the TIMES, Herald, Tribune and Sun were the four papers having "the largest daily circulation." The Comptroller then raised the point that City circulation alone was intended by the law, and declined to concur with the Mayor in "designating" the papers named. The Mayor applied for a mandamus, and obtained it; but, instead of obeying it, the Comptroller announces his intention of carrying the question to the Court of Appeals -- which he, doubtless, has a perfect right to do.

abstract: The Sea Lark sailed from Boston March 28, bound to San Francisco,n and when in lat. 24' south,  to the burning ship, and when about twe miles from her, saw a steamer's light, it being night. I put my ship on the other tack and stood to the eastward for eight hours, and so escaped.
lead_paragraph: The Sea Lark sailed from Boston March 28, bound to San Francisco,n and when in lat. 24' south, to the burning ship, and when about twe miles from her, saw a steamer's light, it being night. I put my ship on the other tack and stood to the eastward for eight hours, and so escaped. On the 3d of May, when in lat. 9° 35' south, lon. 31° 20' west, made a sail on the weather bow, steering west; was soon aware that she was a steamer and trying to intercept the ship; kept her off two points, but the wind being light, the steamer was soon up with me, showing the American colors; fired a gun and ordered me to heave to; brought the ship to the wind at once. Was soon boarded by a boat from the steamer, who informed me my ship was a prize to the Confederate ship Alabama. After allowing me to take a small portion of my clothing, they sent me on board the steamer, where they put my officers and crew in irons, and I was forbidden to speak to them. They took our chests, trunks, and so much or the cargo as they wanted, and then set the ship on fire. The same day they took the bark Union Jack and burned her. Capt. MELCHER, of the ship Dorcas Prince, I fourid on board, his ship having been captured the previous week. We were kept on board until May 12, when we were landed at Bahia, where we were joined by the captain and crew of the ship Dictator, burned by the steamer Georgia, when we all took passage in the British ship Bucephalus, for New-York.

abstract: Many will regret the retirement of Prof. E. N. HORSFORD from his Professorship in Harvard University. His long and successful services in founding and developing the Lawrence Scientific School, and...
lead_paragraph: Many will regret the retirement of Prof. E. N. HORSFORD from his Professorship in Harvard University. His long and successful services in founding and developing the Lawrence Scientific School, and recently in the Rumford Professorship of Chemistry applied to the arts, have earned for him a well based reputation, which will follow him in the more private sphere to which he now withdraws. We anticipate and hope that the active habits of research formed during his past years of professional duty, will be rather expanded than suspended by the greater leisure which he may expect in applying chemistry to manufactures as a private citizen.

abstract: --We find the  name of " Mr. S. G. LYNCH " signed to a card avowing himself the "acting supervisor" on behalf of the Government of telegraphic dispatches from Washington to the newspaper Press.
lead_paragraph: -- We find the name of " Mr. S. G. LYNCH " signed to a card avowing himself the "acting supervisor" on behalf of the Government of telegraphic dispatches from Washington to the newspaper Press. We welcome this tardy revelation of the person who is responsible for the extraordinary performances in the matter of transmitting news, which have so long excited the wonder of the outside world. We have felt his existence and activity for a long time. He has done more to mislead the country, damage the reputation of the Press, and encourage profanity among its members, than all other departments of the Government -- which is saying a good deal. We never expected to know his name: but the age which witnessed the discovery of the head of the Nile has revealed it. We are not surprised to find that it is Lynch. A little reflection would have assured us of that in advance. We feel emboldened to ask a favor at his hands. Now that he stands before the world, personally responsible for his suppressions and manipulations of army news, we beg him, for his own sake as well as for ours, to exercise, if it be not too much trouble, a little common sense. The merest trifle of that commodity would raise his reputation immensely, and would put the whole newspaper world and the rest of mankind under everlasting obligations. Try, Mr. LYNCH -- just once, do!

abstract: Card of Invitation to the South
snippet: Card of Invitation to the South
lead_paragraph: We must leave it to our readers to imagine what the sensations of our fellow-citizens in the seceded States will be, when they learn that the Democratic Convention of Ohio " will hail with delight a desire on their part to return to their allegiance," and that the Convention aforesaid " will cooperate with them to restore peace." The joy which this intelligence will diffuse through the Confederacy will be, we need hardly say, as intense as it is pure, for it will, of course, at once put a stop to hostilities, and relieve the South from the pressure of misery and privation under which it has so long labored. The only sad reflection which this happy event is calculated to inspire is the thought that it should not have happened sooner. Nobody who possesses a spark of humanity can avoid deploring the unnatural reticence which led the Democratic party to conceal their real sentiments so long, when the utterance of them was all that was needed to put an end to "this dreadful war." It is well known that the sole reason for which the Cotton States left the Union was their mistaken notion that nobody at the North wanted them in it, and the citizens in those parts being men of sensitive and retiring dispositions, of course got out of it as fast as possible, and now resolutely persist in staying out, and are fighting in the conviction that the aim of the radicals is simply to cut the throats of all the adult males, and lead the women and children into captivity. Now we cannot help saying that under these circumstances, the Democratic party has been guilty of culpable negligence in not coming forward at the outset, and in a frank and manly way telling JEFFERSON DAVIS and his friends that they would prefer that the South would not leave the Union; and that it was heartily welcome to remain in it as long as it pleased.

abstract: A few of the followers of FERNANDO and BEN WOOD are trying hard to get up a "peace meeting" in Brooklyn, after the manner of the one held in New-York, but the organ of the Democracy -- the Eagle -- throws cold water on the enterprise, and thinks, in view of the prospective rebel raid into the Northern States, they had better postpone it for the presents. The Eagle thinks that, incase the rebels should march, through Pennsylvania to Buffalo, as they propose, if would not look well, while they are waging war in one end of the State, for the Democrats at the other end to hold a peace meeting at Fort Green.

abstract: Streets, the Execrable Condition of
snippet: Streets, the Execrable Condition of
lead_paragraph: Those citizens who have not been in Cologne, and have, consequently, not had an opportunity of sniffing the three hundred and sixty-five " well-defined and separate stinks." which COLERIDGE declared that city of perfumes to possess, may form an excellent idea of the atmosphere of the place from the olfactory experience of the last week in this city. In fact Cologne, in its foulest days, could not compare for one moment to New-York as it is to-day. We count our bad smells by the thousand, not by the hundred. Every second house has a barrel or two of abomination in front of the door, and every barrel emits a stench of its own -- distinct, peculiar, disgusting and dangerous. How long the nuisance is to last, it is impossible to say. The ways of the municipality are inscrutable, and it would always be safer to predict the close of the war, or the breaking of "the back of the rebellion," than what the City rulers will do next. But we must do them the justice to say that, in this matter, they seem at last in earnest, and, during the last two or three days, have been making praiseworthy and heroic efforts to have our pest barrels removed, and the reign of decency restored. What success will attend their efforts we shall, however, not know for a few days.

abstract: The steamship Ocean Queen, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Aspinwall on the 6th inst., brought $304,027 in treasure, and later news from the Isthmus and from Central and South America.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ocean Queen, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Aspinwall on the 6th inst., brought $304,027 in treasure, and later news from the Isthmus and from Central and South America. The news of the action of the National Convention of Colombia, received by the previous arrival, is confirmed. MOSQUERA was elected Provisional President, and an election by the people is to take place in April next. From Central America we hear that CARREA had organized another expedition against Salvador, and was said to be on his way to the frontier. There was a report from Callao, brought by passengers on the South American mail steamer, that a rebel pirate steamer had made her appearance off Cape Horn.

abstract: At 1  o'clock yesterday morning Officer HAMMOND, of the Eighteenth Precinct, discovered flames issuing from the windows of the Exchange Stables, situated at No. 82 East Twenty-fourth-street, between Lexington and Third avenues.
lead_paragraph: At 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning Officer HAMMOND, of the Eighteenth Precinct, discovered flames issuing from the windows of the Exchange Stables, situated at No. 82 East Twenty-fourth-street, between Lexington and Third avenues. That officer promptly gave the alarm, but owing to the cumbustible nature of he contents of the building the fire spread through the establishment with great rapidity, so that by the time the firemen arrived on the ground it was nearly destroyed. There were about two hundred horses in the stables; twenty-nine of which were burned to death. Through the efforts of the Police, firemen and citizens, the animals were mostly released from their confinement, and thereby a great destruction of property was prevented. Ten of the released horses were afterwards taken up as strays by the Police of the Twenty-ninth Precinct. The loss upon building and stock will amount to over $6,000; no insurance. The stables were occupied by Messrs. POST & NICHOLS. From all the evidence which can be gleaned at present, the fire is believed to have been the work of an incendiary. Fire-Marshal BAKER will investigate its origin to-day. A reserve force from the Twenty-first and Twenty-ninth Precincts were promptly on the ground and rendered valuable assistance in saving property.

abstract: We observe that  Alderman FARLEY has brought forward a proposition in the City Councils to appropriate a sum of money to aid Capt.HALL in his projected renewal of his explorations in the Arctic regions. We trust the City Government will confirm this proposal.
lead_paragraph: -- We observe that Alderman FARLEY has brought forward a proposition in the City Councils to appropriate a sum of money to aid Capt.HALL in his projected renewal of his explorations in the Arctic regions. We trust the City Government will confirm this proposal. The money of the public may be used in this way to much better advantage than it is likely to be in any other. Capt. HALL is a man of great intelligence and ability, and is devoted heart and soul to the work of exploring the unknown regions which surround the North Pole. Unlike the English adventurers who have undertaken the same task, he relies exclusively for aid on the Esquimaux whom he finds en route, and with whom he has established relations of mutual confidence and friendship. He brought several of them with him to this country on his return from his recent voyage. He finds them much more serviceable than any Europeans or Americans whom he could take with him. They are accustomed to the climate, understand the ways of overcoming the obstacles encountered by such an expedition, and are heartily devoted to those in whose service they enlist. Capt. HALL is encouraged in this enterprise by the active sympathy and efforts of some of our most influential citizens, and any aid that may be given him by the City Government will be well bestowed.
