abstract: Information reached this City yesterday from Washington that LEE's army, 90,000 strong, was on this side of the Rappahannock, marching northward, and that HOOKER's army also had left its camping ground, and
lead_paragraph: Information reached this City yesterday from Washington that LEE's army, 90,000 strong, was on this side of the Rappahannock, marching northward, and that HOOKER's army also had left its camping ground, and was hastening North to prevent the advance of the rebels. LEE, it would seem, had his army massed in preparation for a movement in the early part of last week, and before its close crossed the river by the fords above Fredericksburgh, and was apparently pushing for the line of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad -- after reaching which we can but conjecture the line or the route by which he would attempt to reach the Potomac. In the meantime, by Friday last, HOOKER's whole army was on its northward march, following on that day a line between, Warrenton and Catlett's Station, for the Orange and Alexandria road,) with a view to bar LEE's progress, in whatever direction it should be. All our commissary stores have been embarked from Aquia Creek.

abstract: We have news  of serious wounds received by two former attaches of the TIMES, now holding responsible official positions in the army.
lead_paragraph: -- We have news of serious wounds received by two former attaches of the TIMES, now holding responsible official positions in the army. At the recent attack on Port Hudson, it is stated that Major G.C. CARR, of the second battalion of Duryee's Zouaves, was very severely wounded while leading his regiment into action; and Capt. ADAM BADEAU, of Gen. SHERMAN's Staff; also received a severe wound in the foot. Both these gentlemen left the TIMKS establishment to enter the army and both have rendered most honorable and effective service. Major CARR took the field at the very outset of the war, as Lieutenant in the original regiment of Duryee's Zouaves, and took part in nearly all the engagements from Big Bethel down until the formation of the Second regiment, which was due largely to his personal efforts. Capt. BADEAU joined the army at Port Royal, and, after a brief transfer of service to the West, went with Gen. SHERMAN to the Lower Mississippi. Both are young men of ability, energy and promise, and will, we trust, recover from their wounds and add largely to the service they have already rendered. Capt. BADEAU is a brother-in-law of Gen. BUSTEED.

abstract: Emancipation in
snippet: Emancipation in
lead_paragraph: To-morrow the State Convention of Missouri meets, under the call of Gov. GAMBLE, to consider the subject of Emancipation. The present Convention was elected more than two years ago, and it was composed at that time of uncompromising Unionists, but in large part of equally uncompromising ProSlavery men, STERLING PRICK, for instance, of rebel fame, was a member; and so was URIEL WRIGHT, of St. Louis; and several others of marked ability and influence, who have long since abandoned the Union cause because they could not love it more than they did Slavery, and have cast their fortunes with the seceded States. This purgation, together with the hard lessons and incalculable losses that two years of war have inflicted on Missouri, has effected a great change in the opinions of the members of the Convention, and in the public sentiment of the State. There is not a reasonable doubt that a majority of the people now demand the adoption of some system by which Slavery shall be abolished as speedily as is compatible with the good order of society. And it would be unjust to the members of the Convention who have shared in the lessons of the past, to suppose that they will not respond to the manifest expressions of the popular will. Nevertheless, it is proper to advise the Eastern friends of emancipation in Missouri that a so-called “radical party” has sprung up in St. Louis, and has some sympathy throughout the State, which demands “immediate and unconditional emancipation,” and seems willing to abide no other policy. The Convention will not be inspired by the counsels of this new party. Nor is it well that it should, for a more Quixotic party, if it should be dignified by such an appellation, has seldom illustrated the fierce politics of the fecund West. It is this same modest organization that recently demanded of President LINCOLN the expulsion of Mr. SEWARD and several others from his Cabinet, and the general reorganization of public affairs on a basis of radical Missouri ideas.
headline: {'main': 'Emancipation in Missouri.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Emancipation in Missouri.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There has long been great doubt in the minds of intelligent and conscientious citizens whether any confiscation act should be passed to take hold of the property of convicted rebels, or whether any act, if passed, could, under the terms of the Constitution, be effectually enforced.
lead_paragraph: There has long been great doubt in the minds of intelligent and conscientious citizens whether any confiscation act should be passed to take hold of the property of convicted rebels, or whether any act, if passed, could, under the terms of the Constitution, be effectually enforced. This doubt has arisen out of what seemed a practical difficulty in the matter, owing to the form of Constitutional limit: “No attainder of treason shall work corruption of blood, or forfeiture, except during the life of the person attainted.” How was it possible to confiscate a rebel's corn, flour, money, bank-stock, ships, houses or lands only “during his life?” Who would be entitled to this property after his death? and how would it be restored?
headline: {'main': 'Constitutionality of Confiscation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Constitutionality of Confiscation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is something decidedly undignified in the periodical and prodigious panics which are communicated to the country by telegraph from Washington and the most sudden and tremendous of all of which is now sweeping over Pennsylvania, Maryland and the whole land.
lead_paragraph: There is something decidedly undignified in the periodical and prodigious panics which are communicated to the country by telegraph from Washington -- and the most sudden and tremendous of all of which is now sweeping over Pennsylvania, Maryland and the whole land. They come like a sudden storm upon a calm sea; and the rage and fury of the tempest is proportioned to the depth of the preceding calm and confidence. If the country does not get shipwrecked in one of these panics, it will be because we have a reserve force whose hearts are undaunted, whose arms are strong and their nerves steel. It is disgraceful that a great nation should thus appear as poltroons in presence of a rebel army which it ought to be able to devour, body and boots. One such scare would be bad enough, but in two years we have had half a dozen. If we ever get over this one, it will doubtless be repeated in about four months. We have now a double panic -- one for sea and one for land; the privateers are on our coast and LEE is in Pennsylvania! We are sure that rather than these, the people would welcome a universal conscription -- would sustain an army two millions strong, and let the Government make arbitrary arrests and suppress newspapers at pleasure. The rebels laugh at these panics of ours; they themselves seem never to indulge in them. Foreign nations laugh at them, and sneer at us; and NAPOLEON said that the contempt of foreigners was the greatest of insults in the eyes of a proud people. If we were accustomed steadily and manfully to look all our difficulties in the face -- to study the situation calmly and understandingly -- and if the Government, instead of treating the people as children, would treat them as intelligent citizens, we should not so often disgrace our country and ourselves by these panics.
headline: {'main': 'Our Dreadful Scares.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Dreadful Scares.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Brough, John, for Governor of Ohio
snippet: Brough, John, for Governor of Ohio
lead_paragraph: -- Ohio Unionism is likely to have an able and worthy champion in the person of JOHN BROUGH, in the coming canvass for Governor. Mr. BROUGH has not been prominent recently in politics. He was, a great many years ago, an editor in the City of Cincinnati, of the Jacksonian-Democratic type. He won an enviable fame for honesty, directness, clearness and logical power. But he was too sincere a man to be a partisan editor and after a while relinquished his position and be took himself to the pursuits of private life. Being of an enterprising turn, and with a mind for comprehensive combinations, he identified himself with the railroad work of the West, and for twenty years has been in the lead of the great internal improvements of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois. He has achieved a more indisputable success as a builder and operator of railroads than any other man in those States, and has a reputation for integrity, sagacity and business habits, that is known and appreciated, and that makes his name a household word in every hamlet in Ohio. In addition, he is a War Democrat of the most unblenching sort. He has never slackened or varied in his support of the Government in its first duty to suppress the rebellion. He has not shared with Mr. VALLANDIGHAM in sympathy for the “persecuted South,” but gives all his sympathy to his country imperiled, by a wicked and desperate treason. A better and abler champion the Union men of Ohio could not have

abstract: The recent depredations in our commerce by the rebel pirates have stirred up the Navy Department to such an extent that all the navy yards are perfectly revolutionized by the amount of work ordered to be done within a few days.
lead_paragraph: The recent depredations in our commerce by the rebel pirates have stirred up the Navy Department to such an extent that all the navy yards are perfectly revolutionized by the amount of work ordered to be done within a few days. On Saturday, orders were received by Admiral PAULDING to complete at once all crafts nearly ready for sea, and to dispatch immediately those in commission, and seaworthy. He was not to stand upon the order of going, but to go at once. Similar instructions were sent to Philadelphia and Boston. The excitement occasioned by this unexpected energy was remarkable, and has increased every hour since, for fresh dispatches, each containing; new commands have succeeded each other rapidly for 70 hours. The resources of New-York may be judged from the fact that, 24 hours after the receipt of the first orders the following fleet was outside the light:

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The situation of  the State of Pennsylvania is, at this moment, a most painful one. With or without cause, there is a wide-spread and startling rumor and dread of rebel invasion.
lead_paragraph: -- The situation of the State of Pennsylvania is, at this moment, a most painful one. With or without cause, there is a wide-spread and startling rumor and dread of rebel invasion. One after another her border towns have been evacuated by the small forces stationed in them, and the inhabitants left unprotected, to flee and leave their property to be ravaged, if the enemy comes, or to stay and be insulted and robbed, without ability to resist. Even the Capital of the State is held to be in great danger, and the Governor is constrained to call from every quarter that help may be sent up to protect it and drive back the invaders.

abstract: Pursuant to the call the Board of Sachems met at the Council Room at 3 o'clock P.M., yesterday. Sachem DELAVAN reported progress, and Sachems DELAVAN, DOUGLAS, TAYLOR and MATTHEW T. BRENNAN ...
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to the call the Board of Sachems met at the Council Room at 3 o'clock P.M., yesterday. Sachem DELAVAN reported progress, and Sachems DELAVAN, DOUGLAS, TAYLOR and MATTHEW T. BRENNAN were appointed a Committee on Finance, to raise funds for an adequate celebration of the Fourth of July. Each Sachem assessed himself $20 toward defraying expenses. Grand Sachem PURDY, with the Sub Committee appointed at the last meeting, will visit Gov. SEYMOUR on Saturday next, to receive his reply to the invitation to be present at the celebration.

abstract: It will be seen that beside the hundred thousand troops called for from Pennsylvania, Maryland, Ohio and West Virginia, the Government has called upon the State of NewYork for twenty thousand militia men immediately.
lead_paragraph: It will be seen that beside the hundred thousand troops called for from Pennsylvania, Maryland, Ohio and West Virginia, the Government has called upon the State of NewYork for twenty thousand militia men immediately, They are to serve for six months, and will be credited to the State under the Conscription. All the militia regiments of the State will be filled up to their maximum number under the State drafting law. The men will be raised under the auspices of the State authorities; and very properly, no bounties will be given.

abstract: If the rebel  cavalry, now supposed to be on a grand raid into Maryland and Pennsylvania, should be so successful as to penetrate either State, we venture a prediction or two as to the result. 1. They will utterly fail to be impressed by ...
lead_paragraph: -- If the rebel cavalry, now supposed to be on a grand raid into Maryland and Pennsylvania, should be so successful as to penetrate either State, we venture a prediction or two as to the result. 1. They will utterly fail to be impressed by the services in their behalf of men claiming to be “Peace Democrats,” but will snatch the horses, kill the cattle, and burn down the houses of all alike who come within their destructive sweep. 2. After they have come and gone (for their visit will be as brief as a thunder-storm in Summer,) the once “Peace Democrats” of the States invaded will be found picking their flints, whetting their knives, rallying to common centres and asking to be led on an avenging campaign against the traitors to their country and the ravagers of their homes. 3. The political atmosphere will be purified by the rebel fire, blasting its way through the green and beautiful North -- “peace meetings” will cease to be held; party names will be discontinued and forgotten; the conscription will no longer be opposed; the name and sorrows of VALLANDIGHAM will not be strongly pressed for sympathy, and possibly, for a third time, we shall behold a “united North,” and a great uprising of the people.

abstract: The rebels are endeavoring to execute their threat to invade the loyal States, and to carry fire and sword to Northern firesides. In fact, two of the loyal States are already invaded; but whether the movement will result in success or failure, remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: The rebels are endeavoring to execute their threat to invade the loyal States, and to carry fire and sword to Northern firesides. In fact, two of the loyal States are already invaded; but whether the movement will result in success or failure, remains to be seen. We find in the Baltimore papers of yesterday morning, an account of the movement up the Shenandoah Valley of a large rebel force, ascertained to be the corps of LEE's army, lately under command of Stonewall JACKSON, but now commanded by Gen. EWELL. This force, estimated at from ten to eighteen thousand men, was discovered on Friday last, moving up on the Strasburgh road. On approaching Winchester, on Saturday morning, they were met by the National forces, under Gen. MILROY, and a severe battle ensued, resulting in the repulse of the rebels. The engagement was renewed during the afternoon, and again on Sunday, and was in progress at last advices. The National force, at Berryville, in Clerk County, eleven miles from Winchester, were also attacked on Saturday, but it is believed that they succeeded in cutting their way through and joined Gen. MILROY at Winchester. On Sunday, a body of rebels, estimated at from three to live thousand, appeared in the vicinity of Martinsburgh, having passed around Winchester, and demanded, the surrender of the place, which was refused and a battle commenced, which was still in progress at 7 o'clock, when telegraphic communication beyond Harper's Ferry ceased. The National cavalry force stationed at Kearneysville, eight miles east of Martinsburgh, fell back to Duffield's depot, five miles west of Harper's Ferry. Some severe skirmishing also occurred at Middletown on Friday, between the rebel advance and our cavalry and artillery, in which the rebel troops suffered severely. This much we learn from the Baltimore papers. For a knowledge of subsequent events we have to rely upon such telegrams as have been allowed to come over the wires. From them we gather that the rebels have succeeded in crossing the Potomac, in forcing their way across the narrow part of Maryland, and have penetrated Pennsylvania. It was judged from this fact yesterday that Gen. MILROY had been finally overpowered at Winchester on Sunday, and forced to surrender: but a dispatch received last night from Baltimore brings as the assurance that, though surrounded by 18,000 men, he succeeded in cutting his way out, and uniting with our forces at Harper's Ferry. The force at Martinsburgh also succeeded we are assured, in reaching Harper's Ferry. Dispatches received yesterday afternoon from Greencastle and Bolton's Station, Penn., announced that Hagerstown, Md., had been evacuated, the troops falling back to Chambersburgh had probably been captured, but about the latter there appears to be no certainly. In the meantime we hear nothing of Gen. HOOKER, who is undoubtedly operating somewhere against the main army of LEE.

abstract: We saw at BARNUM's Museum, yesterday, a cat from whose breast two little minks were drawing the milk of sustenance and contentment. The cat is an ordinary feline, and the minks are extraordinary only in the extent of their appetite and the peculiar selection they have made as the medium through which they obtain their support.

abstract: An arrival at this port from Havana announces the arrival there of a steamer which left Vera Cruz on the 6th of June. The only Mexican news, however, is a confirmation of the report that Gen. ORTEGA, lately commanding at Puebla, had  succeeded in making his escape from the French at Orizaba. A number of other Mexican officers also escaped at the same time.

abstract: Invasion, the
snippet: Invasion, the
lead_paragraph: The excitement that was produced in the City yesterday by the publication in the TIMES of the news that LEE'S rebel army had crossed the Rappahannock and was marching northward, and that HOOKER'S army had also left camp to take up a new line of operation, will be greatly increased to-day by the news of the battles in the Shenandoah Valley on Saturday and Sunday -- the rebel advance into Pennsylvania -- and the call of the Government for 120,000 more troops -- 20,000 of whom are to be from this State. It may be thought passing strange that we were not permitted to hear of these important battles two days ago. They were known in Baltimore and Washington on Sunday, and details of them were published in the Baltimore papers of yesterday morning. It is the withholding of the news of rebel movements, that does more than anything else to precipitate the country into demoralizing excitements. We were assured last week, up to its very last day, that the rebel army was still at Fredericksburgh -- while the fact is, that they must have begun their march with the week, for on Friday they appeared before Winchester, in the Shenandoah Valley, with 18,000 men, and another force as high up as Martinsburgh, on the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. The people of Pennsylvania were in as great darkness as ourselves, and the rebel army, by a forced march might actually have filed into Philadelphia while its shad-bellied citizens were reading in their morning papers that all was quiet on the Rappahannock. Now, as a matter of course, on learning the facts, they are in an unparalleled condition of excitement; and even the Copperheads, who were preparing to hold their great Peace meeting in Independence-square, may first have to fight two or three battles with the rebels for its possession.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Invasion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Invasion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gov. CURTIN, of Penn  sylvania, has been under the necessity of sending personal appeals to the Governors of various Eastern States to hasten forward the militia of their respective States to aid in the defence of Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: -- Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, has been under the necessity of sending personal appeals to the Governors of various Eastern States to hasten forward the militia of their respective States to aid in the defence of Pennsylvania. The Governor of New-York has received such an appeal, and the Governor of New-Jersey, in his proclamation to “Jerseymen,” says that “Pennsylvania, through her Governor, appeals to New-Jersey to aid in driving back the invading army.” A perfect military system in Washington would have enabled the national authorities to inaugurate and carry out measures for the defence of the soil of Pennsylvania; but in times of invasion like these, States have not only to aid themselves, but their officers have also to appeal to sister States for aid. Until the close of this rebellion, the militia of every State in the Union should be kept on a war footing.

abstract: The People ex rel. Anne O’Brien vs. Jas. Lyuch, Sheriff. -- This case came before the Court on a habeas corpus commanding the Sheriff to produce the body of Anne O’Brien. The Sheriff returned that she was in his custody on a warrant issued by a referee. A copy of the commitment was annexed. The commitment showed that the relator head refused to answer a question, which the referee decided it was her duty to answer, (which question was set forth in the warrant,) and that the Sheriff was required to hold her in custody until further orders. It was objected and argued by counsel for the relator, that the provision of the code allowing referees to commit for contempt was unconstitutional; and also that the commitment was defective in form. The point principally argued was upon the right of the witness to refuse to answer, the counsel for the Sheriff contending that the matter could not be renewed on habeas corpus, and that if it could be renewed, then the commitment was proper, because the question was not put to the witness with the intent to impeach her character, but to obtain an answer material to the issue between the parties to the action. The Court adjourned the decision until to-morrow, and meantime remanded the relator to the Sheriff’s custody.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. Anne O’Brien vs. Jas. Lyuch, Sheriff. -- This case came before the Court on a habeas corpus commanding the Sheriff to produce the body of Anne O’Brien. It was objected and argued by counsel for the relator, that the provision of the code allowing referees to commit for contempt was unconstitutional; and also that the commitment was defective in form. The point principally argued was upon the right of the witness to refuse to answer, the counsel for the Sheriff contending that the matter could not be renewed on habeas corpus, and that if it could be renewed, then the commitment was proper, because the question was not put to the witness with the intent to impeach her character, but to obtain an answer material to the issue between the parties to the action. The Court adjourned the decision until to-morrow, and meantime remanded the relator to the Sheriff’s custody.

abstract: We observed around  town last evening a large number of officers and soldiers of the United States. They were evidently not the returned two years' soldiers  for these have nearly all doffed their uniforms. They were not our militia soldiers hastening to the war. They were mostly offi  cers and soldiers on leave of absence, on furlough, and such like.
lead_paragraph: -- We observed around town last evening a large number of officers and soldiers of the United States. They were evidently not the returned two years' soldiers -- for these have nearly all doffed their uniforms. They were not our militia soldiers hastening to the war. They were mostly offi cers and soldiers on leave of absence, on furlough, and such like. Furloughs have been given out quite freely of late -- much exceeding, we believe, either two or three to the hundred men; and leaves of absence to officers of all grades have been extensively granted. We hope some of these gentlemen will now strain a point to get back to their regiments. We should like to have them among us always; but the rebels are now ravaging Pennsylvania, and every soldier we have is needed to drive them back. The nation sustains the prodigious burdens connected with its vast army at present in hope that the rebellion may be speedily crushed. Thus far, in the East, we have not been brilliantly successful; but, if ever circumstances demanded of us a great and united effort, it is at present. Patriotism and honor should lead every absent soldier, who can make it possible, to rush back to the ranks; as it has led thousands of our citizen-militia again to officer their services to the Government. After the war is over, and the rebellion crushed, we will welcome back all our heroes with joy, and crown them with honors as long as they live.

lead_paragraph: The Northward movement of the rebel army is certainly very audacious, though we are not yet able to divine its precise course, nor the special object it may have in view. We do not even yet know whether it has crossed the mountains or is still on the upper waters of the Rappahannock. Some think that LEE will offer HOOKER battle on the present ground now held by our army, near the old Bull Run battle-fields; others hold that he is going to march his whole army into Pennsylvania by the Shenandoah Valley, and attempt a short campaign in the North; while others think his object is an attack on Washington from the rear. A short time must develop the truth in the matter. His plan and course are doubtless clearly enough marked out in his own mind. But their execution will depend very much upon us. We have already an army in the field near Washington far superior in numbers to his; and twice a hundred thousand volunteers are rushing to arms in the five States nearest to the theatre of operations. If we have energy and vigor in our movements; if we have intelligence and unity in our plan; if we have skill and sagacity in our leadership, there is no reason under Heaven why LEE’s new campaign should not prove as disastrous as it is daring.

abstract: At the meeting of the Supervisors, yesterday, notice was received from the Mayor and Comptroller of their selection of the Herald and Tribune in which to publish the City and County advertisements. Mr. PURDY said the provision of law under which the Mayor and Comptroller acted was unconstitutional; but even if it were good law, they were not respecting it in restricting the public advertising to half the number of papers they were directed to select. Mr. STEWART took the same view, and added that the clause, if valid, was only for the City, being inserted in a law relating exclusively to raising money for the City, and in which County advertising is not mentioned. The subject was referred to a Special Committee, consisting of Messrs. Stewart, Purdy, Shook and Roche, to obtain legal advice as to the constitutionality, meaning and application of the clause. A communication from the Comptroller transmitting a statement of the amount required to be raised by tax this year for State, City and County purposes, was referred. The appropriations amount in all to $12,614,330 48, for which the general fund provides $1,350,000; an addition of $524,127 47 to the balance, for deficiencies in extending taxes, leaves $11,788,457 95 as the sum to be raised by taxation. The Committee on Criminal Courts and Police reported adversely on the claim of Messrs. EDWIN JAMES and THOMAS DUNPHY, for defending MARY REAL on the charge of murder at her trial last October, they having been assigned as her counsel by the Court, but proposed an appropriation of $250 to cover their expenses. This was voted, and the Board adjourned to 3 o’clock P.M., on next Tuesday.

abstract: The frank and cordial manner in which our Southern brethren are responding to the offer of the Ohio Democrats, "to cooperate with them in the restoration of peace," fully justifies the anticipations which we ventured to express on this head a few days ago.
lead_paragraph: The frank and cordial manner in which our Southern brethren are responding to the offer of the Ohio Democrats, "to cooperate with them in the restoration of peace," fully justifies the anticipations which we ventured to express on this head a few days ago. We conjectured that as soon as the South heard for the first time that the democracy of the North would “hail with delight” its return to the Union, it would take immediate steps for coming back. It is now evident that the leaders of the rebellion are desirous of meeting as many of their Northern fellow-citizens as can be got together in Convention at either Harrisburgh or Philadelphia; at the date of the last accounts it had not been decided which it was to be. And we may guess how hearty and zealous they are in this great movement, from the enormous size of the delegation which they are sending forward. There is no Peace Democrat who can avoid feeling a glow of satisfaction at the thought that 90,000 or 100,000 of the bone and sinew of the South should have started Northward, to confer and discuss, the minute they heard that the great Peace party would be pleased to see “them return to their allegiance.” We doubt if the South has ever yet been so well represented in any of the conferences which she has held with the Northern democracy. The delegation comprises men of all ranks and parties, from the wealthiest planters down to the negro slave, and there is not one of them who is not desirous of staying at the North as long as it will be convenient for us to keep him.

abstract: The  very urgent appeal of Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, for help to expel the invaders who are expected, this day, to be in sight of Harrisbugh, though addressed to Pennsylvanians only, must excite the earnest sympathy of every one who reads it.
lead_paragraph: -- The very urgent appeal of Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, for help to expel the invaders who are expected, this day, to be in sight of Harrisbugh, though addressed to Pennsylvanians only, must excite the earnest sympathy of every one who reads it. It is certainly an insult and a dishonor of no small degree that the Capital of so ancient and so powerful a Commonwealth as Pennsylvania should be threatened by an enemy always deemed contemptible in their numbers and despicable in the cause for which they fight.

abstract: European news five days later is received by the arrival at this port of the???ship Scotia. She left Liverpool on the 6th and Queenstown on the 7th inst. The news is of very little importance. It is stated that the steamer Lord Clyde, suspected to be intended for the rebels, was searched while at Cardiff, by order of Earl RUSSELL. A very rigid scrutiny, however, failed to reveal any thing suspicions about her, and she proceeded on her voyage o Nas???au. Parliamentary proceedings were without interest. It appears from a St. Petersburgh telegram that France invited the American Government to join the great European Powers in their diplomatic action toward Russia on the P???ish question, and the reply of Mr. SEWARD had been published at St. Petersburgh. The Washington Cabinet refused its cooperation, on the ground that America can never deviate from her traditional policy of non-intervention in European affairs, except in cases of evident necessary. The revolution conduced very active. Three or four defeats of the Russians are chronicled. The London Observer says that the three great Power have sent an urgent note to Russia, asking for a representative Government for Poland, a general amnesty for all the Polish insurgents, and an immediate??? The Liverpool Cotton market was very quiet, and prices had a drooping tendency. Breadstuffs were dull, and Provisions quiet. Consols 92@92 1/8.

abstract: News of the advance of  LEE'e army reached Pittsburgh on Sunday, and on the evening of that day the citizens had intelligence that "an immense force was then marching to Pittsburgh, with the avowed object of laying the city in ruins." A dispatch was also received from Gen. HALLECK to the effect that an attack on Pittsburgh was imminent, and that the city should be put in a state of immediate defence.
lead_paragraph: -- News of the advance of LEE'e army reached Pittsburgh on Sunday, and on the evening of that day the citizens had intelligence that "an immense force was then marching to Pittsburgh, with the avowed object of laying the city in ruins." A dispatch was also received from Gen. HALLECK to the effect that an attack on Pittsburgh was imminent, and that the city should be put in a state of immediate defence. The excitement of course to fever heat, and the manufacturers had a meeting on Sunday night, and resolved that business be temporarily suspended, that the workmen might have an opportunity of fortifying the city. On Monday a crowd of several thousand workmen gathered together, and rumors of the near approach of the rebels also gathered thick and fast. It may be thought that the men rushed headlong to work with pick and shovel, fortifying. Not at all. They marched up to the hotel where the local commander was stopping, and called for a speech! The officer did not gratify them, but the crowd was determined to have a speech from some one, and various gentlemen were called upon. Finally, it is reported, an “old soldier, three sheets in the wind, forced his way to the front of the balcony, and after waving his hand for silence,” began his speech, which was soon cut short; but he only gave way to another orator, who “proceeded to address the assemblage.” It is well that the rumor of the advance of the rebels, was a little ahead of the fact; for, had they been up to time, they would have found the citizens busily engaged -- one class in making speeches, and the other in listening to them. It is but just to say, however, that in the course of the day, and after the able speeches, the audience went actively to work on the fortifications.

abstract: Everything looks very gloomy here.  The indications are that the rebels will be within sight of Harrisburgh to-morrow, and in the absence of troops to stop the advance of the rebels, the destruction of all the bridges along the Susquehanna is inevitable.

abstract: We observe that in the general attack of all persons in high places, the General-in-Chief does not escape. He seems to be particularly singled out by some German papers in the West. His generalship, his Union feelings, his sincerity in carrying out the President's policy concerning negroes in the disloyal States all are criticized, doubted, and even perversely assailed.
lead_paragraph: We observe that in the general attack of all persons in high places, the General-in-Chief does not escape. He seems to be particularly singled out by some German papers in the West. His generalship, his Union feelings, his sincerity in carrying out the President's policy concerning negroes in the disloyal States -- all are criticized, doubted, and even perversely assailed. We do not pretend to know the motives of these assailants, nor do we undertake to discuss with them the military merits of Gen. HALLECK, or measures and orders of which his enemies do not know anything more than ourselves -- whether they emanated from him or not. His Union feelings are proved by his career, from the day when the first news of the insurrection reached him in California to this day; and as to the third point -- his assumed unwillingness frankly to carry out the views of the Government regarding Slavery -- we are able to state a few; facts which will shed some light on the debated point.

abstract: The rebels, in their invasion of Pennsylvania, are reported in our latest dispatches to have advanced no further than Chambersburgh. Nothing certain appears to be known about their movements, however, further than that they were at Chambersburgh on Monday night, having, it is supposed, burnt the town of Greencastle in their progress. The rebel force in the Shenandoah Valley, which attacked Gen. MILROY at Winchester, had not up to last evening made any demonstration against Harper’s Ferry, though they were reported in heavy force at Charlestown, only eight miles distant. We receive assurances from Washington that there was no collision yesterday between Gens. HOOKER and LEE. The invasion of Pennsylvania has, of course, created the greatest excitement throughout Pennsylvania and Maryland, and the excitement has spread to New-York, under the spur of the call upon the militia, which is being responded to with the greatest alacrity. Twelve or fourteen regiments are already under marching orders from New-York City, and most of them will probably leave to-day.

The invasion of Pennsylvania has, of course, created the greatest excitement throughout Pennsylvania and Maryland, and the excitement has spread to New-York, under the spur of the call upon the militia, which is being responded to with the greatest alacrity. Twelve or fourteen regiments are already under marching orders from New-York City, and most of them will probably leave to-day.

abstract: The City Inspector gives no  tice this morning that all the obstacles which have heretofore embarrassed the operations of his Department in the matter of street cleaning have now been removed, and he has entered upon the prosecution of his work, including the removal of ashes and garbage, with the whole force at his disposal.
lead_paragraph: -- The City Inspector gives notice this morning that all the obstacles which have heretofore embarrassed the operations of his Department in the matter of street cleaning have now been removed, and he has entered upon the prosecution of his work, including the removal of ashes and garbage, with the whole force at his disposal. He calls upon the people of the City to aid him in his labors, by refraining from throwing ashes, garbage, rubbish and store-sweepings into the streets and gutters; and announces that ash-carts will pass through the streets of the City daily, to collect and carry away the waste material which may be deposited in the barrels and boxes used as receptacles therefor. He promises that he will make every effort to keep the streets in a cleanly and healthy condition; and asks that every neglect on the part of his employes be reported at his office.

abstract: His Value to the Army
snippet: His Value to the Army
lead_paragraph: -- It is understood that Maj.-Gen. DAN SICKLES will not return, for the present, to the Army of the Potomac. We know nothing of the ground on which the ru mor to this effect rests. But we are ready to assert, what will certainly meet general concurrence, that the services of this distinguished officer, or of any other of like ability, cannot be very well dispensed with at the present exciting stage of affairs. Maj.-Gen SICKLES has developed a very high capacity for military service. Whether it be in organization and discipline of men, or in their cool and skillful handling, from a brigade to an army corps in battle, Gen. SICKLES has proved himself thoroughly competent and complete master of himself and of his position. The Excelsior brigade, organized by him mainly from this State, has made a record for patient endurance of hard work, dashing gallantry and heroic steadfastness in the fires of many battles during the past two years of campaigning in Virginia, that no troops of the day can surpass. The brigade is a living and glorious proof of the spirit and skill of the man who organized and trained them for their work.

abstract: The rebels are reported to be near the town of Carlisle, Penn., which is one day's march from Harrisburgh. abstract: We suppose our splendid cavalry force is watching very closely the line of the Alexandria, Loudon and Hampshire Railroad, or the region from Leesburgh and Aldie toward Fairfax Station and the Occoquan. It must be a very tempting thing for the rebel cavalry, while a body of them are making such a fuss in Pennsylvania, to try and get down in that region between HOOKER's army and the Potomac, and cut off his communications, or the possibility of his cooperating with the troops at Washington. The rear manoeuvre of Stonewall JACKSON last year in this vicinity, and the fatal results that followed it, under Gen. POPE, cannot be forgotten.

abstract: A letter from Richmond of June 2, in the Atlanta (Ga.) Intelligencer, reports the current rumor that LEE was about to march either for Washington or Philadelphia. The writer says that the fortifications of Washington are such as to render it well-nigh impregnable, and if. "Gen. LEE invades Maryland, It is not probable that he will immediately make an attack on the well-defended Capital of the Union, but upon other places, with a view to cut off its supplies, and thus, by stratagem, ultimately compel its surrender." Gov. CURTIN, the writer thinks, has not altogether neglected the defence of Philadelphia; but, generally, he considers that any of the cities of the North, owing to the formerly prevalent opinion there that that section was safe from invasion in any event, would fall an easy prey to a "Confederate" army. But a succession of defeats has at last wakened the North to a consciousness of its danger. Steps are being taken to put into a defensive posture; and, consequently, "this if ever, is the time for our gallant troops, under inexperienced leaders, to pass the Rubicon, tear down the bridges behind them, and move, with all the pomp and circumstance of bloody war, into the heart of the enemy's country."

abstract: News  from Vicksburgh shows that Gen. JOHONSTON, in GRANT'S rear, is being reinforced from the rebel army of BRAGG in Tennessee. News from Murfreesboro shows that none of BRAGG'S troops have left him, but that his...
lead_paragraph: -- News from Vicksburgh shows that Gen. JOHONSTON, in GRANT'S rear, is being reinforced from the rebel army of BRAGG in Tennessee. News from Murfreesboro shows that none of BRAGG'S troops have left him, but that his whole army still fronts ROSECRANS, and has even been reinforced from LEE's army in Virginia. News from Virginia shows that LEE's army has certainly not been depleted, but it is asserted that it has been enormously reinforced from the West, from the vicinity of Richmond, and from North Carolina. News from the latter points shows that the rebels are still there in unabated strength.

abstract: At a meeting held at Sheffield, on Wednesday night, June 3, under the presidency of Mr. Alderman SAUNDERS, the following resolution was adopted: "That this meeting has heard with profound regret of the death of Lieut.-Gen. THOMAS JEFFERSON JACKSON, of the Confederate States of North America -- a man of pure and upright mind, devoted as a citizen to his duty, cool and brave as a soldier, able and energetic as a leader, of whom his opponents say he was 'sincere and true and valiant.' This meeting resolves to transmit to his widow its deep and sincere condolence with her in her grief at the sad bereavement, and with the great and irreparable loss the army of the Confederate States of America have sustained by the death of their gallant comrade and General." It was decided to request Mr. MASON to transmit the resolution to Mrs. JACKSON and the troops lately commanded by the deceased General.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting held at Sheffield, on Wednesday night, June 3, under the presidency of Mr. Alderman SAUNDERS, the following resolution was adopted: "That this meeting has heard with profound regret of the death of Lieut.-Gen. This meeting resolves to transmit to his widow its deep and sincere condolence with her in her grief at the sad bereavement, and with the great and irreparable loss the army of the Confederate States of America have sustained by the death of their gallant comrade and General." abstract: As a Revolutionary Force
snippet: As a Revolutionary Force
lead_paragraph: DANTE describes one of his condemned as forever moving round a dreadful crater, and, on his arriving at a certain point, ripped almost in twain by the stroke of an avenging sword. The wretch pursues his endless journey, piteously moaning, and with difficulty holding together his bleeding, lacerated frame. The huge wound rankles, festers and heals; but no sooner does the victim accomplish his fated round, than another frightful gash bares his palpitating vitals, and sends him howling on his way.

lead_paragraph: Another of the Canadian steamship line has been lost -- the Norwegian, which left Liverpool on the 4th, and Londonderry on the 5th inst. for Quebec. She was wrecked on St. Paul's Island on Sunday morning, the 14th, during a thick fog. All her passengers and crew, together with her mails and baggage, were saved.

abstract: The results of the Paris elections have just reached me, and though the figures are not absolutely official, yet as they are given out by the authorities they may be considered thoroughly reliable. The issue of the contest bears out the most sanguine anticipations of the opposition; the Government has courted defeat and has not courted it in vain.

abstract: Invasion; promptness of the defence
snippet: Invasion; promptness of the defence
lead_paragraph: It is a glorious thing to recognize -- the exhaustless patience and the exhaustless patriotism of the loyal people of the United States; although it is a burning shame that these noble qualities should be taxed so often and so severely as they are. Now, for the third time within two years, after having given their Government soldiers by the million, and treasure by the thousand million, to wage an offensive war against an inferior foe, they are agitated at the approach of that foe to their own homes and firesides, far away as they are from all the former scenes of conflict.

abstract: Negroes are now helping to fight our battles in the South; they are helping the rebels to fight us; they are helping to fight France's battles in Mexico; and even the Imperial Capital of France is now in part garrisoned by negroes; and, says our Paris correspondent, the "proud Court of NAPOLEON III. does not appear to observe that there is anything abnormal in having the guard of the palace mounted by black men." The negro race is in a fair way of having a chance to learn to fight; and as, unfortunately, nations and peoples are, in this world, valued very much in proportion to their powers of fighting, the black man will soon be able to establish his historical value.

abstract: Appointed to Command Dep't of the South
snippet: Appointed to Command Dep't of the South
lead_paragraph: Gen. HUNTER has been relieved from command of the Department of the South, and Gen. GILMORE has entered upon duty as his successor. Gen. HUNTER has been at Port Royal for about a year and a half, and has been steadily on duty, except during the period when he was temporarily relieved by the lamented Gen. O.M. MITCHEL. The most remarkable events of his administration were the battle on James Island, which was fought against his orders -- the recent attack on Charleston, in which he took no part -- and the siege of Fort Pulaski, which was conducted by the officer who is now to be his successor.

abstract: On Tudnesday night, the Capitoline Associaciation gave an entertainment at their rooms in Brooklyn. The audience was exceedingly large, and composed of the most respectable citizens of Brooklyn. The President, Dr. J.L. KEEP, was in the chair. The exercises consisted of readings, essays and singing -- the latter being under the direction of Prof. WIEBE. Miss NINA FOSTER was present, but did not give any readings as was hoped she would. Mr. THOS. T. ATKINS read a Scottish poem in excellent taste and style. Mr. HAWS gave "The Tale of a Tub" -- a humorous poem -- in a superb manner. An original Essay on Life followed, by Dr. S.S. Guy. Mr. J.W. CARRINGTON read "The Burial of Sir John Moore" in an effective manner, and was generously applauded. Mr. S.W. HIGGINDOTHAM gave a humorous parody on it, to the delight of the audience. Two little girls each gave a recitation, and performed very creditably. Mr. E.F. CRONYN was next announced to give an original essay, and was very warmly applauded. He chose for his subject, "The Ancient and Numerous Order of the Philo-Donkians," which he claimed was older than the Masons, dating back to Adam, when he took the apple from Mother Eve. The coat of arms of this order was, one donkey rampant, one fool cross-heads, and a female divinity in the background, handing the seated assignee an apple. The entire essay was brimful of humor, and created great merriment, particularly the gathering of the Philo-Donkians, on a bugle-call from their chief. Mr. PARDESSUS, in a comic description of a bewildered Frenchman, closed the evening's entertainment.

abstract: Lee's Forces in the Shenandoah Valley
snippet: Lee's Forces in the Shenandoah Valley
lead_paragraph: The city was thrown into a state of great excitement yesterday afternoon, by the receipt of intelligence to the effect that LEE's army had occupied the Shenandoah Valley in force, and that an incursion into this department by the enemy was imminent. The news, it appears, first reached here through the medium of a delegation of citizens from Wheeling, who stated further that MILROY was surrounded by the enemy at Winchester without a hope of escape, and that MULLIGAN had been defeated near Grafton with severe loss. It was also stated that the rebels, in overwhelming force, were approaching Wheeling from the Kanawha Valley, and that everywhere in Western Virginia the greatest excitement prevailed. The news, as might be expected, created intense excitement, and people were eagerly engaged in discussing its probability, when a dispatch was received from the War Department for Gen. BROOKS, which, without knowing a word of its contents, the crowds on the streets were not slow to assert confirmed all that had been previously reported, ad ling further that Harper's Ferry had been captured, and that an immense force was then on its way to Pittsburgh with the avowed object of laying the city in ruins.

abstract: -The usual musical entertainments at this popular establishment were varied on Monday night by the introduction, for the first time of FALLON's "Stereopticon," an instrument which magnifies to the diameter of 24 feet the ordinary objects of the stereoscope. There are very few who have not derived pleasure from the charming little instruments which are now found in every parlor. Although of limited power and difficult adjustment to various sights, they are capable, as we all know, of giving wonderfully distinct and truthful representations of places and things. It will be easily understood how FALLON's newly-invented Stereoscope intensifies this pleasure. The cartoons are grand not only in proportions, but in depth of tone and breadth of effect. They are, in fact, a succession of pictures that have never been equaled, enabling the looker-on to catch something of the spirit, beauty and importance of the original scenes. The architectural views are truly remarkable, and afford a fine study of that branch of art; while the sculpture is reproduced with a roundness and truth that equals the original. The exhibition, in a word, is one of the best and most instructive we have ever had in the City, and merits the most unbounded patronage of the public. A couple of hours passed in gazing on these grand sun painted pictures convey to the mind a better impression of the world than all the books of travel in the Astor Library.

abstract: Our latest reports from Harrisburgh indicate that the rebel cavalry, under JENKINS, have retreated from Chamoersburgh. They are supposed to be about 3,500 strong. There was said to be another force, however, under IMBODEN, on another route of advance. STUART himself is not in Pennsylvania, according to the latest advices, but in Shenandoah Valley.
lead_paragraph: Our latest reports from Harrisburgh indicate that the rebel cavalry, under JENKINS, have retreated from Chamoersburgh. They are supposed to be about 3,500 strong. There was said to be another force, however, under IMBODEN, on another route of advance. STUART himself is not in Pennsylvania, according to the latest advices, but in Shenandoah Valley. The fortifications constructed on the hills opposite Harrisburgh are considered sufficient protection to the city, and an offensive movement on the part of our forces is not improbable.

abstract: The news this morning from the Pennsylvania border is extremely meagre; and regarding the movements of LEE'S main body we yet know nothing whatever. We get not a glimpse of their general purpose, or the special end they propose to attempt.
lead_paragraph: The news this morning from the Pennsylvania border is extremely meagre; and regarding the movements of LEE'S main body we yet know nothing whatever. We get not a glimpse of their general purpose, or the special end they propose to attempt. We have no new engagements to report -- no additional towns captured. The rebels hold Winchester, Martinsburgh, and Shepherdtown, in Virginia, and our troops lately at Harper's Ferry are reported to have crossed the Potomac and occupied Maryland Heights, which command the Ferry; the rebels also hold Williamsport, (at which they probably crossed the river,) and Hagerstown, in Maryland; and the farthest point their cavalry have reached in Pennsylvania is the town of Chambersburgh. The startling reports we had on Tuesday and Wednesday of the overwhelming masses of rebels that were filing into the State of Pennsylvania, appear to have been greatly exaggerated, and we should think, after sifting all accounts, that the force of rebel infantry that has crossed the Potomac is very limited. At each of half a dozen widely-apart points, it is thought that LEE is aiming directly at that point, and that all manoeuvres in the other directions are but feints. Pittsburgh in the West, and Harrisburgh in the east, are each anticipating the advent of the rebel army, while HOOKER's army in front of Washington, and Baltimore in its rear, are none the less on the alert for it. In the meantime, the most plausible theory of the whereabouts of LEE's army, is that which places it in the vicinity of the Bull Run Mountain, perhaps at Warrenton, though it may have pushed up as high as Manassas Gap and into the Shenandoah Valley. It is quite possible that LEE, when he struck in a northeasterly direction, had a purpose of making for Manassas Junction, with intent of setting between HOOKER's army and Washington, and attacking one or other of these forces before they got over their surprise, or could get themselves set for battle. But if so, HOOKER's equally rapid march from Falmouth to Bull Run, prevented this; and by this march, the latter officer planted himself in a position where he can cooperate with all the troops in front of Washington, and can receive reinforcements from all points with the greatest advantage. This march of HOOKER may have completely disarranged LEE's original plans, and compelled him to project an enterprise quite different from that which he set forth to accomplish. That enterprise would most likely be one into Maryland analogous to that which he attempted last year.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN.--Mr. EDWARD MOLLENRAUER'S tragic opera, called the "Corsican Bride," was produced here Monday evening, The libretto is derived from a sanguinary piece called "Rosa Gregoria,"and has been twisted into a lyric shape by Dr. A. KOEHLER, who is said to have a great deal to answer for.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. EDWARD MOLLENRAUER'S tragic opera, called the "Corsican Bride," was produced here Monday evening, The libretto is derived from a sanguinary piece called "Rosa Gregoria,"and has been twisted into a lyric shape by Dr. A. KOEHLER, who is said to have a great deal to answer for. It will be remembered that some weeks since Mr. MOLLENHAUER gave a concert performance of some of the music at Irving Hall. The composer is a well-known orchestral conductor, and in this work proves that he possesses a vein of dramatic talent which, properly explored, might lead to valuable results. The opportunities for operatic composers in this country are few and far between. To get a single work produced requires the effort of a lifetime. The chances of improvement and increased facility, which much writing offer to really inventive minds, are consequently denied to Americans. This is the more to be lamented inasmuch as the earlier works in literature and in art, even of the most gifted men, bear distinct traces of the particular line of reading and fancy that has most pleased them. The labor of constant production can alone place a writer on the basis of his own ability, and enable him to be thoroughly original. Mr. [???] MOLLENHAUER's opera is the work of a young man whose memory is keener than his invention. The reminiscences which are noticeable in every act are the fruits of a well-cultivated mind, and prove that the composer has not forgotten his studies or the lighter impressions received in the opera house. We do not for a moment imagine that Mr. MOLLENHAUER would wittingly use a plagiarism, but he has undoubtedly repeated many ideas that have been used before. In other respects the music is fluent and graceful. We look in vain for those strong contrasts and overwhelming bursts of effect which are essential to the writer of serious opera. The combinations are quite ordinary, and the tempt and movements are singularly steady. It seems to us that Mr. MOLLENHAUER will find his talent best adapted to the treatment of lighter themes. We would at all events urge him to select a better libretto for his next work. No skill is displayed in the construction of the "Corsican Bride," and some of the situations are positively ludicrous. The last tableau, in which everybody seems to be anxious to kill everybody, could be transferred bodily to a burlesque or a pantomime.

abstract: On Military Affairs; Speech at New-Hampshire Union Convention
snippet: On Military Affairs; Speech at New-Hampshire Union Convention
lead_paragraph: A complete report of the speech delivered before the Union Convention in Concord, N.H. on June 17, by Postmaster-General BLAIR, has reached us. After returning thanks for the kind greeting which had been extended him, Mr. BLAIR alluded briefly to the political conflicts which had preceded the rebellion. He showed how the Slavery question had been used to mould and, control the policy of the Government, and said that, although very many of the people of the North disapproved the Compromise measures of 1850, they accepted them as a finality. So strong was the feeling in New-Hampshire against disturbing it, that Mr. HALE, who had refused to approve it, considered his career closed, and had determined to remove to this City to enter upon the practice of the law when the repeal of the Missou??? Compromise determined him to remain. Mr. BLAIR Proceeded:

abstract: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a communication was received from the Mayor, nominating GEORGE W. BLUNT for City Inspector, vice DANIEL E. DELAVAN, the present incumbent, whose term of office expired last Monday. The nomination was rejected, by 16 to 1. The Mayor sent in another communication accompanying  and favoring an application from Gen. WARD B.
lead_paragraph: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a communication was received from the Mayor, nominating GEORGE W. BLUNT for City Inspector, vice DANIEL E. DELAVAN, the present incumbent, whose term of office expired last Monday. The nomination was rejected, by 16 to 1. The Mayor sent in another communication accompanying and favoring an application from Gen. WARD B. BURNETT, for an appropriation to aid in the formation of the brigade he is organizing. The subject was referred to the Committee on National Affairs. An application from the City Inspector, for the use of a portion of the dock at the foot of East Twenty-third-street, for dumping purposes, was referred. Mr. FARLEY moved to direct the Clerk to furnish the proceedings of the Board to the Corporation papers designated by the Common Council. Mr. FROMENT questioned the propriety of adopting the motion, because the validity of the section of the law under which the Mayor and Comptroller selected Corporation papers, was now a question before the Courts. Mr. BOOLE disputed this, and remarked that the Courts were only considering the matter in respect to the meaning of the law. The action how proposed would bring the whole question to a direct issue. The newspapers concerned could publish the proceedings or not, as they might see fit, and such of them as chose to publish them, probably, would sue for their pay. Thus, without interfering with the action taken by the Mayor and Comptroller, it could be judicially determined whether the right of the Common Council, under the charter, to select their own advertising mediums, was abrogated. Mr. FROMENT thought this could all be done without adopting the motion made by Mr. FARLEY. Mr. BOOLE replied that it was desired that the papers should have the proceedings furnished to them officially. The motion was carried by 11 to 5. A report in favor of granting the request of the American Institute for a full term lease of Reservoir-square, at a nominal rent, was laid over. Adjourned to Monday, at 1 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Copperheads and the Constitution as it Is
snippet: Copperheads and the Constitution as it Is
lead_paragraph: What means it? The Copperheads have clamored from the beginning about "the Union as it was, and the Constitution as it is." They have done their best to make it their distinctive party motto. And it was not a bad one. While it all had a pleasing sound, the first clause was so indefinite that nobody cared, and the latter so just that nobody dared, to take issue against it. But it seems that the Copperheads are no longer suited with it. They are going to give it up incontinently. At the State Convention which nominated VALLANDIGHAM for Governor they made bold to adopt the following resolution: "That whenever it becomes practicable to obtain a Convention of all or three-fourths of the States, such body should be convened, for the purpose of proposing such amendments to the Federal Constitution as experience has proved to be necessary to maintain that instrument in the spirit and meaning intended by its founders, and to provide against future convulsions and wars."

abstract: This regiment is organizing as the Tenth regiment New-York State National Guard, and is intended to be perpetuated as a militia regiment, with the same numerical designation under which it was honored in the army of the United States. At the meeting, last evening, the free use of the rooms corner of Mercer and Broome streets were given by the proprietor, Mr. JAMES HADDON. The muster-rolls were distributed, and one company, in half an hour, had forty men. It is proposed to offer their services to the Government for three months, and it is expected that at least six hundred, mainly from Col. BENDIX's old command, will enlist.

abstract: The Twelfth regiment, Col. WARD, is preparing to march. The companies to-day assembled at the armory, Nos. 694 and 696 Broadway; the uniforms for the soldiers were provided; recruiting is in progress, and it is estimated that the ranks, when the regiment starts, will include four hundred men. One of the companies takes its members into the field, without an exception. The subject was made one of pride and reputation, and there are to be substitutes nor absentees. The record of the Twelfth is inseparable from the history of the war for the Union, and replete with honor.

abstract: The noble response of the New-York State Militia of this City to the call for troops to meet the pressing emergency in Maryland and Pennsylvania, was exemplified yesterday by the departure of no less than three regiments the Thirty-seventh, Twenth-second, and Eleventh, making six regiments in two days, and the only reason why there were not eight, was...
lead_paragraph: The noble response of the New-York State Militia of this City to the call for troops to meet the pressing emergency in Maryland and Pennsylvania, was exemplified yesterday by the departure of no less than three regiments -- the Thirty-seventh, Twenth-second, and Eleventh, making six regiments in two days, and the only reason why there were not eight, was because the requisite clothing and equipments were not to be had. The men were ready and eager to respond. And, it should be remembered these regiments marched with even fuller ranks than they have presented on the many parades in the City, of which the metropolis has been justly proud. No doubt, when they are all duly located, they will be joined by many members whose business would not admit of so sudden a departure, but whose hearts are still in the good cause The Seventh regiment, especially, will be largely augmented in a few days by members of this class, who are never known to shirk the duties of active service, and who feel proud of the reputation which the corps d???elite has achieved for promptness and efficiency in times of need. All of the regiments have experienced equal difficulty in procuring the supplies, owing partly to the uncertainty as to the number who would go, and partly to the necessary red tape with which all such proceedings are necessarily bound. Indeed the red tape has become quite a by-word with the soldiers, and it is shrewdly suspected that if the City of New-York were to be menaced to-morrow, by a fleet of rebel privateers, threatening to enter the harbor, it would be impossible to get the requisite ammunition or missiles for the guns in the harbor forts without an official order, duly signed, countersigned, inspected, revised, scrutinized, examined, tested by oath and affirmation, and duly delivered to the proper officer, at a convenient hour of the day. It can hardly be expected that the authorities can have the equipments and supplies for half a dozen regiments ready, to be available at the tap of the drum. But it would seem that since such emergencies as the present have arisen previously, and are likely to arise again, it would be a fortunate circumstance if some official could be found to take the responsibility and have things done in a common sense sort of way. By this it is not intended to censure the state officials, fort despite the malicious predictions of the peace ??? that Gov, S??? would never permit another soldier to leave the State, the State Government has do??? its part of the work with energy and will. As i??? is, our regiments have not been as fully supplied as might be desired, but it is understood that Whatever is lacking will be for??? coming at Harrisbu???gn or such other point as the Government may designate as headquarters.

abstract: We hope there are not many honest, patriotic men at the North, who have not, during the last week, asked themselves in sober sadness: How is it that, after two years of war, with every advantage on out side; with overwhelming superiority in men, money and material; with our ports open, our trade ...
lead_paragraph: We hope there are not many honest, patriotic men at the North, who have not, during the last week, asked themselves in sober sadness: How is it that, after two years of war, with every advantage on out side; with overwhelming superiority in men, money and material; with our ports open, our trade flourishing, our credit good, our people pertinacious and determined beyond example -- we find the enemy threatening our own territory with an army equal, if not superior, to our own? How is it that, within a day's march of Washington, we have no better protection against invasion than a levy en masse, and a tumultuous rush to the field of half-armed civilians -- undrilled, unofficered and unorganized? How is it that the United States Government, while actually engaged in the task of conquering the whole South, finds itself reduced to the humiliating necessity of abandoning the defence of Northern soil to the frantic energy of State Governors? How is it that, when the second campaign opens, the national authority seems to disappear from our view, and the Union seems to resolve itself into a mere Confederation, each member of it acting for itself, and shouting to the others for help? What is it, in short, that constitutes the military superiority of the South at this moment? What gives it a veteran and disciplined army, equal in number to HOOKER's, and enables it to spread panic through the whole North, and send the authorities of Pennsylvania flying off with the State archives from the State Capital, by merely sending two or three thousand troopers over the border? Why are our young men called off from their business at a day's notice to repulse "raids" three hundred miles away? Why is a great, powerful society like ours thrown into convulsions by the opposition of a brigade of bushwhackers, its business men driven to their wits' ends, and its chiefs forced to make appeals to the patriotism and devotion of private citizens -- such as are usually the last resource of despairing energy?

lead_paragraph: The Twenty-second, under command of Lieut.Col. ASPINWALL, was busy at the armory at Palace Garden all day, preparing to leave. It was expected that their supplies would be forthcoming, so that they could get off at 12 o'clock, but, as usual, there was delay -- "some one had blundered" -- and the men were kept changing around until late in the afternoon. Fourteenth-street was the scene of much excitement, and when the regiment left, about P.M., the popular ovation it received was cordial indeed.

lead_paragraph: The time has not yet come for an impartial judgment on the military operations immediately preceding the late irruption of rebel forces into Maryland. No certain understanding is had of the direction of approach, or of the real strength of the enemy, in the attacks upon Winchester and Martinsburgh; and until we do know all the facts of the case, it would be unfair to condemn Gen. MILROY for a retreat that, on his own showing up to the present time, does not fully admit of justification.

abstract: The Eleventh regiment, Col. MAIDHOFF, secured their arms, uniforms and equipments on Wednesday evening, and orders were at once issued for their distribution yestersay, and the departure of the command at 4 o'clock. Their armory was densely crowded all morning, the bustling scenes of preparation filling every room.
lead_paragraph: The Eleventh regiment, Col. MAIDHOFF, secured their arms, uniforms and equipments on Wednesday evening, and orders were at once issued for their distribution yestersay, and the departure of the command at 4 o'clock. Their armory was densely crowded all morning, the bustling scenes of preparation filling every room. Issues were made of clothing, &c., by the regimental Quartermaster in the great hall, and in adjoining rooms company officers dealt out to the men the needed articles. Scores of friends were there bidding good-bye to the departing soldiers. Womanly kisses, gentle reproaches and lamentations mingled in the cloud of smoke and dust, with manly invitations to beer, giving, as in most Teutonic affairs, a half domestic and social character to the stern aspect of war.

abstract: Those of our readers who have WHEELER & WILSON Machines in their families -- and who has not? -- will be pleased to learn that still another improvement has been added to their invaluable home companions -- a "trimmer," so called from its being designed to "trim" ladies' dresses. This little attachment stitches braid of any width on one edge only: and really, when one observes the hundreds of elegant robes decorated around the skirt with half a dozen rows of braid, more or less, now worn, it is surprising that this improvement was not sooner "thought of." There is no computing the weary hours of labor its steel and crystal circlet will economize. -- N.Y. Express.

abstract: The invasion of Pennsylvania has ended. So, at least, the news of the morning indicates. The invasion, as it appeared to the eyes of the startled country on Tuesday and Wednesday, was a movement of gigantic magnitude; but it suddenly dwindled, yesterday and to-day, until now we must believe that it was
lead_paragraph: The invasion of Pennsylvania has ended. So, at least, the news of the morning indicates. The invasion, as it appeared to the eyes of the startled country on Tuesday and Wednesday, was a movement of gigantic magnitude; but it suddenly dwindled, yesterday and to-day, until now we must believe that it was only a cavalry raid, under the inevitable JENKINS. On Wednesday we beheld, through the telegraph, three stupendous rebel columns, each accompanied by five thousand cavalry and trains of artillery, filing into Chambersburgh; and to-day we espy the tails of the horses of two or three thousand rebel riders as they gallop out of Chambersburgh, leaving behind them not a soul of the vast host who had entered it by magnetism two days before. One day the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania is rocked to its foundations, and the next it is laughing at its fears.

lead_paragraph: A telegram from Harrisburgh expresses the opinion that there are now no rebel troops in the State. JENKINS' cavalry left Chambersburgh on Wednesday afternoon, after robbing all the drugstores in the place and setting fire to a warehouse and were at Hagerstown on Wednesday night. They took with them a number of the most promminent farmers in the valley. There is a report that another body of rebel cavalry -- probably under IMBODEN -- have come from Cumberland, Md., to Romney, Va. There is also a report that eight thousand rebels have crossed the Potomac at Williamsport, and marched toward Hancock, Md., stampeding a portion of Gen. MILROY's force which had taken refuge there. These reports are unauthenticated, however. The authorities at Harrisburgh are busy organizing the troops as fast as they arrive, and the work on the fortifications and rifle pits still goes on

The number of men is seven hundred and fifty to eight hundred, of a total of nine hundred on the rolls. No recruits were taken, and the de-
lead_paragraph: The Fifth regiment (also German,) is under marching orders, and will form at one o'clock this afternoon, in order to take its departure for Pennsylvania. The number of men is seven hundred and fifty to eight hundred, of a total of nine hundred on the rolls. No recruits were taken, and the deficiency represents approximately the number of men who could not go with the regiment. The proportion is, however, very small. The equipments were furnished yesterday afternoon, and will be distributed this morning.

lead_paragraph: The Twenty-third regiment departed for Pennsylvania yesterday morning. They formed in line on Orange-street, near Fulton-street, about 7 o'clock A. M., and marched down Fulton-street to the ferry at 8 o'clock. A large number of the friends and relatives of the members assembled at the armory to see them leave. On reaching New-York they marched up Fulton-street, and down Broadway to Pier No. 1 East River, where they took the boat for South Amboy, whence they will proceed to Philadelphia by railroad. abstract: Councilmen's and G rman Partnership of McClellan and Fremont
snippet: Councilmen's and G rman Partnership of McClellan and Fremont
lead_paragraph: Our Board of Councilmen have adopted a resolution urging upon the Administration the restoration of Gen. McCLELLAN to the chief command of the Army of the Potomac. Some of our most influential German citizens, on the other hand, have solicited the President to allow Gen. FREMONT to raise an inde pendent force to aid in beating back LEE's revel columns. These are but the latest manifestations of the persistent endeavor, in different directions, to push the fortunes of these two Generals. It seems to be the chief study of two distinct fractions of our people how to rehabilitate their respective favorites. They seize upon every occasion, and resort to every device, for the furtherance of their own particular end. They estimate every new development of the war primarily by its bearings, not upon the fortunes of the cause, but upon the fortunes of Gen. MCCLKLLAN and Gen. FREMONT. TO judge by the habitual language of some of them, it would seem that their highest idea of the war was that it was a scene expressly for the benefit of their own hero; and that the whole performance was weary and flat so lone as he was in the background.
