abstract: The match, two miles and repeat, to wagons, between these horses, tools place Thursday, on the Fashion Course, in presence of about 1,500 spectators. The betting was 100 to 40 on Patchen, who lost the first heat, by only half a length, and was nearly a distance behind at the end of the second heat. The race was, however, awarded to Patchen.
lead_paragraph: The match, two miles and repeat, to wagons, between these horses, tools place Thursday, on the Fashion Course, in presence of about 1,500 spectators. The betting was 100 to 40 on Patchen, who lost the first heat, by only half a length, and was nearly a distance behind at the end of the second heat. The race was, however, awarded to Patchen, on account of the driver of Butler crossing Patchen and breaking him up, when but a length a head of bun, as they passed the judges' stand on entering the second mile of the last heat. The judges were nearly three-quarters of an hour before they came to a decision, when two of them agreed to distance Butler for foul driving, the third loudly dissenting, and advising those who had bet on Butler not to pay, and declined all bets off. This advice was not attended to, as bets were generally paid over under the decision of the majority of the judges.

abstract: A typographical error gave the Twenty-sixth New-  York, instead of the Twenty-sixth New-Jersey, the credit of crossing the Rappahannock in company with the Fifth Vermont, when the last passage of the river was effected by the Sixth Corps. The Twenty-  sixth New-Jersey led the charge, and was closely followed by the Fifth Vermont. Lieut.-Col. MARTINDALE commanded the former regiment at the time, as Col. MORRISON was still under arrest.

abstract: On Monday the  people of this City were startled by the news of the northward advance of the rebels, of which no one had dreamed up to that time. On the evening of that day the Governor of the State received a telegram from Washington calling for twenty thousand militia, to resist invasion, which order was promulgated ...
lead_paragraph: -- On Monday the people of this City were startled by the news of the northward advance of the rebels, of which no one had dreamed up to that time. On the evening of that day the Governor of the State received a telegram from Washington calling for twenty thousand militia, to resist invasion, which order was promulgated next morning. The militia regiments, composed of citizens engaged in all pursuits, merchants, workmen, mechanics and professional men, instantly prepared themselves to march. Wednesday they began to leave, the Seventh leading the van, and up to last night eight regiments had left this City and Brooklyn. We learn from Albany that ten regiments altogether have left the State, and that four more will have left by this morning. New-York's twenty thousand will very soon be in the field; and if ten times twenty thousand were needed to put down the rebellion and save the Union, the Empire State would furnish them with alacrity. Who will say that the North is exhausted?

abstract: According to our dispatches from Harrisburgh this morning, the rebel cavalry under JENKINS has been succeeded by that under MOSEBY in the vicinity of Chambersburgh. MOSEBY was reported eight miles below that town yesterday morning. A body of rebel cavalry, probably part of JENKINS force, which left Greencastle, in the direction of Mercersburgh, on Thursday, were at ...
lead_paragraph: According to our dispatches from Harrisburgh this morning, the rebel cavalry under JENKINS has been succeeded by that under MOSEBY in the vicinity of Chambersburgh. MOSEBY was reported eight miles below that town yesterday morning. A body of rebel cavalry, probably part of JENKINS force, which left Greencastle, in the direction of Mercersburgh, on Thursday, were at McConnellsburgh yesterday morning, and took the road toward Hancock, Md. They were on a horse and cattle stealing expedition. On the line of the Potomac there is much activity. A force ??? three hundred rebels were driven away from Hancock on Thursday, after burning some cana??? ???oats there. Seven hundred rebels on the same day attempted to destroy a large culvert opposite Hancock, but they were driven back by a body of our cavalry, under Col. GALLAGHER, after an hour's fight. It was reported that a force of ten thousand rebels was at Cumberland, Md., on Thursday. On the Virginia side, at Williamsport, yesterday, was a considerable body of rebel infantry, and another rebel force was said to be near An???ietam or Shepherdstown, and about to cross the river.

abstract: This exhibition, organized at the Agricultural Rooms, No. 41 Park-row, opened on the 18th inst. with a large display of choice fruits. Those who ...
lead_paragraph: This exhibition, organized at the Agricultural Rooms, No. 41 Park-row, opened on the 18th inst. with a large display of choice fruits. Those who attended the exhibition a year ago cannot fail to observe the immense progress that twelve months have made in the development of this fine berry. Four large tables are spread, and each table contains specimens exceeding in number and quality the entire exhibition of berries made by the Royal Horticultural: Society at London, last year. This we are assured by a competent amateur who witnessed both exhibitions.

abstract: Thursday the Athletics played with the famous Atlantics, whose battles and triumphs have gained for them fame in every place where base ball is played. The Atlantics were deprived of the championship last season by their old ally, the Eckford. They are determined, however, to regain their lost laurels. To accomplish this they have revived the spirit which instigated them in years gone by, and which was perceptible in the match yesterday, which was by far the most interesting of any played thus far. In batting and fielding both sides made fine displays. LOUGHERY played in the place of GASKELL, on the Athletic side, which is the first change made in the series. The contest was witnessed by some 6,000 persons, a large number of whom were of the fair sex. We annex the score:

abstract: The Fifth regiment N.Y.S.M. effected its departure for the seat of war about 8 o'clock last evening, numbering about six hundred men, fully armed and equipped. They were escorted on their route down Broadway by a very large number of our German fellow-citizens, of which nationality the regiment is composed. They are a credit both to the Teutonic race and the Metropolis, and will compare favorably with almost any of our City corps.
lead_paragraph: The Fifth regiment N.Y.S.M. effected its departure for the seat of war about 8 o'clock last evening, numbering about six hundred men, fully armed and equipped. They were escorted on their route down Broadway by a very large number of our German fellow-citizens, of which nationality the regiment is composed. They are a credit both to the Teutonic race and the Metropolis, and will compare favorably with almost any of our City corps. Their enthusiasm for the cause was immense, and the fair German damsels, many of whom accompanied them, bedecked many a musket with fragrant flowers. The ranks were filled with stalwart soldiers, as staunch and true as any the Republic can boast, and they received the god-speed of as fine a class of our population as has turned out on a similar occasion. Their march down Broadway, though at an unexpected hour was a continued ovation, and will long be remembered by all who witnessed it. They will do, as they have already done, credit to the City. The following are their officers:

lead_paragraph: We have advices from Europe four days later, by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Bohemian. She left Liverpool on the 11th, and Londonderry on the 12th inst. The American ship Kate Dyer, from Callao, had arrived at Antwerp. She reported having been overhauled by a rebel privateer, and compelled to give bonds for $50,000. The privateer is supposed to have been the bark Lapwing, recently captured by the Florida. The new steamer Southerner, recently launched at Stockton-on-Tees, had made her trial trip, and was subsequently searched by the Government authorities, under the supposition that she was intended for a privateer. Nothing suspicious was found on board, however. Parliamentary proceedings were without importance. There is nothing new regarding the Polish question. There had been a decline in the Liverpool Cotton market, consequent upon the news of Gen. GRANT's victories. Breadstuffs had a downward tendency, and Provisions were flat. Consols were quoted at 91 ???/8.

abstract: The annual meeting of the Institute of Reward was held on Thursday last at the Free Academy, the President, VALENTINE MOTT, N.D., in the Chair, supported by HORACE WEBSTER, L???.D., and SAMUEL BELL, D.D., Vice-Presidents. The annual report was read by DAVID P. HOLTON, M.D., Corresponding Secretary. During the year past the exertions of the Institute have been mainly directed to urging upon the State Legislatures their acceptance of the Congressional grant of land for agricultural and educational purposes, and toward securing provisions, by which, in the selection of students for the colleges and experimental farms endowed by the grant, preference shall be given to the orphans of those dying in the defence of their country; and also, toward procuring a supplemental fund for the support of a preparatory department for a younger class of orphans on the said farms. Governors, Congressmen, Assemblymen, and others, have been seen and consulted, and the objects of the Institute have been made known to large numbers of the people, in meetings held for this purpose, in various parts of the country, and have everywhere been received with cordiality. Especially has this been the case in the camps, where our troops have found in this movement new encouragement for their devotion to the country's service.

abstract: the Richmond British Consul, >amp;c.
snippet: the Richmond British Consul, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: It was published a short time since that the rebel Government at Richmond had dismissed Mr. MOORE, British Consul at that city. It was not then known that an act, originating in the alleged personal misconduct of the Consul, was made the occasion of a general change of policy on the part of the Confederate Government, toward the representatives of foreign Powers. Such is the case. And the letter which we published yesterday, from J.P. BENJAMIN, rebel Secretary of State, to J.M. MASON, rebel Commissioner at London, furnishes an interesting history of the offence of Mr. MOORE, and of the orders that have been the consequence of his conduct.

abstract: Strategy at the Fireside and Street Corner
snippet: Strategy at the Fireside and Street Corner
lead_paragraph: The street-corner and fireside strategists have a splendid field for their wits at present. The situation in Virginia is sufficiently complicated and indefinite to make strategical speculation delightfully easy and dismally profound. Nothing is known about the location of LEE's army, and little about HOOKER's. Nobody knows what LEE's plans are; and nobody can tell how HOOKER proposes to circumvent them. No one has any idea how large a force the rebels have at Richmond, or what means have been adopted for the defence of that place; and nobody knows whether or no KEYES, DIX, PECK & Co. have any designs against it. Furnished with this stock of ignorance, and armed with one of the awful "maps" with which our cotemporaries so frequently adorn their columns, it is easy for the strategist to show how HOOKER should operate against and defeat LEE -- how KEYES should capture Richmond -- and how HOOKER, by a grand coup, might smash the rebellion and end the war -- marching into Washington with LEE in chains, antique fashion, and a hundred thousand rebel captives following in his rear.

abstract: ANDREW GEOGHEGAN, a policeman of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, was returning from his post to the Station-house on Thursday evening, about 8 o'clock, when he was suddenly attacked by a band of four or five rowdies in Second avenue. Without any provocation, one of the assailants struck the victim on the head with a slung-shot, and knocked him down. Another of the gang stabbed him in the forehead with a dirk-knife while he lay prostrate. GEOGHEGAN was so much injured that he was insensible for some time, and before any assistance could be procured, the persons who made the attack had effected their escape. The wounded officer was conveyed to his residence on the corner of Thirty-ninth-street and Second-avenue. Dr. HODGEMAN was called, and, after an examination, he pronounced the injuries to be of a very serious nature. He advised that the Coroner be notified immediately to hold an ante-mortem examination. The skull is badly fractured, and he has also sustained other wounds, which his physician fears will prove fatal. GEOGHEGAN is about 24 years of age, and has been connected with the Police Department for the last four years. He has always borne a good reputation as an officer and a citizen, and has the confidence and esteem of all who know him. Capt. SPEIGHT, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, has interested himself in the case, and, with the men of his force, is doing everything he can to bring the guilty parties to punishment.

abstract: The curiously  "mixed" condition of our military system, and the inefficiency resulting therefrom, has just had a striking illustration in Pennsylvania. When the first news of the projected invasion ...
lead_paragraph: -- The curiously "mixed" condition of our military system, and the inefficiency resulting therefrom, has just had a striking illustration in Pennsylvania. When the first news of the projected invasion reached that State, Gen. COUCH, who had just been appointed to the command of the Department of the Susquehanna, summoned to arms, for the defence of the State, all citizens between the ages of 18 and 60, "to serve during the pleasure of the President or the continuance of the war." When the danger was more imminent, came the order of the Governor calling out the militia. When the rebels were actually on Pennsylvania soil, came the proclamation of the President, calling for one hundred thousand men, fifty thousand of whom were assigned as the quota of the Keystone State, "to be mustered into service, and to serve for the period of six months." The Pennsylvanians, however, did not like the terms or conditions of any of these calls, and did not fly to their rifles as promptly as was proper. Then Gov. CURTIN, spurred by the news that the rebels were advancing toward his capital, to adopt any expedient to save it, issued an address and also delivered an earnest personal appeal to the people to volunteer -- in the former of which he said he would "accept men without reference to the six months' term," and that it "never was intended to keep them beyond the continuance of the emergency;" and imploring the people to trust in his and the Government's words.

abstract: Numerous mail-bags have fallen into the hands of the National troops in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Numerous mail-bags have fallen into the hands of the National troops in Louisiana. The universal usage of war declares captured mails of the enemy property of the captor, and a National officer was appointed to examine the captured letters and to make a report to headquarters accordingly. Several of these letters have reached us, but, instructive as they are, we can find room for publishing one only. We on???it the name of the writer and of the intended recipient, as well as of the place whence it was sent, for obvious reasons. If its remarkable contents should induce any readers to doubt its genuineness, we would state that the original was given to us for publication by a gentleman whose honor and veracity no one has ever doubted. We have omitted those portions only, together with those paragraphs relating to family affairs:

abstract: Capt. HUNT, of the United States Engineers, yesterday took the sub-marine battery What Is It from the Brooklyn Nary-yard, to try further experiments in the harbor. Some officers of the army and navy went with him. Shots were fired from under water to an astonishing height, and evolutions performed which demonstrated the entire success of the battery. The Government is about to construct a very large vessel, on Capt. HUNT's plan, which will effectually remove all obstructions in harbors.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning, Capt. WARLOW, of the First Precinct, received instructions from Police Headquarters, directing him to take a sufficient number of his reserve force, and repair to the neighborhood of Pier No. 8 East River, foot of Coentiesslip, where, from indications, it was believed that a serious riot would occur, unless the strong arm of the law was interposed. As our readers are aware, there has existed for some time past much trouble and dissatisfaction among the laborers employed by the New-York and Erie Railroad Company, who have been, engaged in loading and unloading the Company's barges lying along the piers in that portion of the City. Mr. ALLEN, the agent of the Company, informs us that for several years past they have steadily employed the men, who have now tried to create the trouble. These laborers have, to a great extent, owing to their long experience in the business, for months past controlled that kind of work, and the Company saw they must either accede to the demands of these laborers or suffer a stoppage of their freighting. The Directors of the Company at last resolved to rid themselves of that class of men, and when, a few weeks ago they raised the wages of the workmen to $2 per day, they concluded to employ none of the old hands. The latter were greatly exasperated at this turn of affairs, and by threats and other hostile demonstrations they tried to deter the new employes from going on with their labor. At about 7 o'clock yesterday morning, one of the new men was seized by a gang of the discharged laborers, and severely beaten about the head and face. But for the timely interference of Capt. WARLOW's men, it is thought he would have been killed. Roundsman CONNER, with the aid of other officers, succeeded in quelling the disturbance and in taking into custody PATRICK MALOY and PATRICK KEIRNS, two of the ringleaders of the attacking party. The prisoners were taken before Justice CONNOLLY at the Tombs and committed in default of ball.

abstract: The public  have grown somewhat chary of confidence in the frequent reports of the " reinforcement" of our Generals in the critical times when reinforcements were most needed.
lead_paragraph: -- The public have grown somewhat chary of confidence in the frequent reports of the " reinforcement" of our Generals in the critical times when reinforcements were most needed. A degree of distrust existed for some time as to the alleged reinforcement of Gen. GRANT, to enable him to maintain the siege of Vicksburgh and at the same time keep off Jo. JOHNSTON from his rear. The more [???]o, because the first statement in this connection was that GRANT was being heavily [???]forced by Gen. BANKS, which we soon found to be untrue. But the fact is unquestionable that GRANT has been reinforced, and to so large an extent that it would seem impossible for any rebel army in the Southwest to disturb his operations. A correspondent from Memphis writes that he counted fifty steamboats, each with from five to fifteen hundred troops aboard, proceeding to GRANT's aid, and that Gen. HERRON, who is leading the reinforcement, has a command of 30,000 men.
headline: {'main': 'REINFORCEMENTS FOR GRANT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'REINFORCEMENTS FOR GRANT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: MURDER TRIAL. MARY ANN McLAUGHLIN was placed on trial in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer on Friday, on the charge of killing her mother, CECELIA McLAUGHLIN, the wife of THOMAS McLAUGHLIN.
lead_paragraph: MURDER TRIAL. -- MARY ANN McLAUGHLIN was placed on trial in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer on Friday, on the charge of killing her mother, CECELIA McLAUGHLIN, the wife of THOMAS McLAUGHLIN. The family occupied the upper floor of a house in Park-avenue, near Canton-street. On the 19th of February last Mrs. MCLAUGHLIN was ound dead in her room, her face and body covered with many bruises and deep gashes. The husband was lying in an adjoining apartment, drunk. The daughter was the only person in the room with her mother, and in consequence of her subsequent actions and contradictory statements, suspicion fell upon her, and she was arrested. The father was also arrested as accessory, but discharged by the Grand Jury.

abstract: A large train of cars reached this City last evening from the West, bringing seven hundred and sixty-six rebel prisoners, being a part of those captured by the army of Gen. GRANT, at the battle of Black River. The prisoners were in charge of a guard, composed of members of Ohio regiments, under command of Lieuts, LESTER and JUDKINS. Most of the prisoners belonged to Tennessee and Mississippi regiments, and all of them looked as if they had seen hard service. Their clothes were much worn and faded, and some of them were without shoes. Many of them looked sick, out this was probably the result of their long journey and confinement in the cars. As the train of cars moved down Washington-avenue, crowds followed it, and before the prisoners were embarked on the steamboat intended to convey them to Fort Delaware, thousands had gathered about the cars. The prisoners entered freely into conversation, and replied pretty sharply to reflections upon the rebel leaders. One of them was asked what he thought of JEFF. DAVIS, to which he replied that he thought him a gentleman and a scholar. Many of them spoke of Gen. PEMBERTON in a manner showing a want of confidence in him. The boat containing the prisoners left the wharf about dusk. Another train of rebel prisoners was said to be on the way, and was expected to react the city during the night. -- Phila. Ledger, June 13.

abstract: Benedict vs. Vanderbilt; Harbor Masters' Act
snippet: Benedict vs. Vanderbilt; Harbor Masters' Act
lead_paragraph: Spencer S. Benedict et als., Respondents, vs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Appellant. -- ROBERTSON, J. -- A statute of this State provides that every vessel entering the port of New-York, which "loads or unloads, or makes fast to any wharf therein," shall, within a certain time thereafter, pay certain fees to certain officers, denominated Harbor-Masters, which fees are graduated by the tonnage of such vessel. (Sess. L., 1850, ch. 72, p. 81. [???] 4, 2 R.S., [5th Ed.,] 422.) In default of such payment, a penalty of double the amount is imposed upon the owner, master or consignee of the vessel who refuse to make it. (Sec. 5.)

abstract: THE STRAWBERRY EXHIBITION closed yesterday, and notwithstanding the unfavorable weather, which impaired somewhat the flavor and good appearance of the fruit, it was an eminent success. We gave yesterday the names of cultivators to whom first prizes were awarded.
lead_paragraph: THE STRAWBERRY EXHIBITION closed yesterday, and notwithstanding the unfavorable weather, which impaired somewhat the flavor and good appearance of the fruit, it was an eminent success. We gave yesterday the names of cultivators to whom first prizes were awarded. But it must not be concluded that the list of fruits thus complimented embraced all that were excellent. So far from it, it is probable other judges would have given other awards, so close was the balancing between competing berries. We noted the name of J.W. FAULKNER, of Stamford, Conn., for especial compliment in our survey of the exhibition tables. He presented no less than forty-one varieties of strawberries, gathered at random from his fields, and such as he can supply any day from his stand, No. 97 Fulton-street, New-York. There was not an inferior variety in the lot. A number were remarkable for their size and flavor, among which we may mention the Sterling Castle Pine, Alice Maud, Compte de Flanders, Wilson's Seedling. Fillmore, Scott's Seedling, Peabody's Seedling, and especially a Seedling from the Austin of Mr. FAULENER's own producing, which took a premium in the exhibition. This last is a berry of exceedingly fine promise, extra sized, long necked, conical shaped, spicy flavored, and a liberal bearer. It will certainly become a standard fruit. Upon the whole, this annual exhibition of strawberries was a very encouraging affair, deeply gratifying to horticulturists and creditable to Mr. JUDD, proprietor of the Agricultural Rooms, under whose auspices and enterprise these fruit exhibitions are becoming a feature in our City shows.

abstract: Dr. KREBS has abandoned his dear old Church in Rutgers-street, and it has passed into Catholic hands, under the pastoral charge of Rev. J. BOYCE. The interior has been refitted somewhat, to suit Catholic ceremonial. A beautiful altar has been erected, and the organ thoroughly restored. The Archbishop will officiate to-day, (Sunday,) at the dedication, and preach the sermon. The attendance of many of the old congregation will add new interest to the impressive scene. The first musical talent of the City has been engaged, and Mr. SCHMIDT, who holds high rank as an organist, has deferred to the Pastor's wishes, and will lead the choir. The Church will henceforth be known as St. Teresa's.

abstract: Life with the Contrabands. Cor. TIMES
snippet: Life with the Contrabands. Cor. TIMES
lead_paragraph: We have received the following private letter from an educated friend who went out some four months since to take charge of contrabands on two or three of the island plantations on the South Carolina coast. He went with the sole object of doing what he could to elevate the condition of the black man, and fit him for freedom. The writer is a close and philosophic observer, and this narrative of his experience will be found exceedingly interesting and valuable.

abstract: The Northern Gordian Knot
snippet: The Northern Gordian Knot
lead_paragraph: Austria has again become deeply interested about the Teutonic Schleswigers, and her representative at Frankfort has even proposed to the Diet that Holstein should be occupied with Federal troops, and held as a guarantee for the fulfillment of the stipulations entered into by Denmark in 1851, for the benefit of her German subjects. The Austrian proposition has been rejected through the influence of Bavaria and the jealousy of Prussia, and, as the Bund is impotent when its leading members disagree, the Government at Copenhagen need not fear any aggression for the present. The mere mooting of such a proposition, however, demonstrates to what length the Confederation would be disposed to go, if the several States belonging to it could be induced to act together. But, even though they could be brought to act in concert, they would have no right to attempt to coerce Denmark in this way. It is undoubtedly very impolitic of the Danish King to delay redressing the grievnces of the German Schleswigers. As they have become occupants of Cimbrian soil, they should enjoy the same privileges and the same liberties as its other inhabitants. Yet, between them and their sovereign, the German Powers have no business to interfere. Schleswig is not a part of Germany; and as for the pledges, the fulfillment of which is to be exacted, they are of no more validity than the oath that a burglar, pistol in hand, constrains a terrified householder to swear. Under what circumstances were those pledges obtained from the Danish monarch? An Austro-Prussian force, brought into aid in suppressing insurrection in Holstein, treacherously held possession of that province, and refused to evacuate it, till the pledges in question had been made. Yet we are told that these engagements are to be considered as binding, as if FREDERIC the Seventh was a free agent when he contracted them.
headline: {'main': 'The Northern Gordian Knot.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Northern Gordian Knot.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Of all the fierce rebels (on paper) that we have heard of lately, commend us to the Chattanooga Rebel. We instinctively picture him as resembling that terrible rebel whom the correspondent of the London Morning Herald met in Charleston: "The Federal name excited his eye into a glare of hate, set his lips quivering with anger and the muscles of his face into full play of passion." This Chattanooga Rebel has heard that we were arming and equipping one hundred thousand cavalry, (we wish the news were true,) and that "regiments and brigades of negroes are being impressed" into our ranks; and the "cause of these new movements is clear" to him -- it is that we are resolved to burn up "bridges, cities, depots and dwelling-houses by raids in the interior, and to add the horrors of a San Domingo massacre to plundering and brutal warfare." And the Rebel is not unmoved. On the contrary, he feels "profoundly touched at the sad and solemn picture of the future that is thus weaving in the womb of fate." The very confusion of his metaphor bears witness to the profundity of his sensations.

abstract: Ireland. The Debate on the Volunteers' Bill
snippet: Ireland. The Debate on the Volunteers' Bill
lead_paragraph: It is usually instructive to read a genuine Irish debate in the British House of Commons; and the perplexing question of allowing the formation of Irish volunteer companies supplies about as lively a theme for parliamentary discussion as anything within the range of debate. Seventy years have elapsed since EDMUND BURKE said: "There is no hope for the body of the people of Ireland, as long as those who are in power shall make it the great object of their policy to propagate an opinion that the mass of their countrymen are not to be trusted by their Government." And nearly twenty years have gone by since Sir ROBERT PEEL said: "There should be a real and substantial equality of political and civil rights, so that no person viewing Ireland with an unbiased eye, and comparing the civil franchises of Ireland with those of England and Scotland, shall be able to say with truth that a different rule has been adopted toward Ireland; and that, on account of hostility, or suspicion or distrust, civil freedom is there curtailed and mutilated." How these words of warning from the lips of the foremost Commoners the Kingdom has produced, have been heeded, there are innumerable illustrations to show.

abstract: The Philadelphians, accompanied by representatives from the leading Clubs of this City and Brooklyn, left Jersey City yesterday in the 1 P.M. train for Newark, where they arrived after a pleasant ride of half an hour.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphians, accompanied by representatives from the leading Clubs of this City and Brooklyn, left Jersey City yesterday in the 1 P.M. train for Newark, where they arrived after a pleasant ride of half an hour. They were then conveyed to the grounds, which are beautifully located on the corner of Mercer and High streets, in two large stages. The Playing began at 2 1/2 o'clock and ended at 5 o'clock, being the shortest game of the series.

Freights were inactive, with 612 vessels of all classes in port.

abstract: The Fifty-sixth regiment took their departure for Harrisburgh at noon on Friday. They formed on Raymond-street, in front of the Armory, about 9 o'clock A.M., but it took nearly two hours' time before the men were supplied with all that was required for the campaign.
lead_paragraph: The Fifty-sixth regiment took their departure for Harrisburgh at noon on Friday. They formed on Raymond-street, in front of the Armory, about 9 o'clock A.M., but it took nearly two hours' time before the men were supplied with all that was required for the campaign. The Armory and vicinity was crowded with friends and acquaintance, and the officers and men were presented with bouquets and flowers. The former carried them in their hands and the privates stuck them in their button-holes or in the muzzles of their muskets, as mementoes from their fair friends. The line was formed about 11 o'clock, and the order to march was given, when they proceeded down Fulton-avenue and Fulton-street to the ferry, accompanied [???] by a throng of enthusiastic fellow-citizens. They marched to Pier No. 2 East River, where they embarked for the New-Jersey Central Railroad Depot. They go by the way of Easton. A full list of the officers was published on Friday.

abstract: Two more regiments the Fourth and Twelfth  left this City yesterday, making nine in all that have responded to the call to meet the emergency in Maryland and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Two more regiments -- the Fourth and Twelfth -- left this City yesterday, making nine in all that have responded to the call to meet the emergency in Maryland and Pennsylvania. The alacrity of this response from citizen soldiers will ever remain a striking testimonial of the ardor of our military spirit, as well as of the efficiency of our unequaled militia organization.

abstract: Elections in
snippet: Elections in
lead_paragraph: The recklessness of M. DE PERSIGNY, has given a triumph to the opponents of Imperialism, and placed his master in a false and awkward position. The Minister of the Interior entered the arena against the independent candidates, and in the nine arrondisements of Paris and several of the Provincial towns, he and the Government have been signally defeated. Thiers, Ollivier, Jules Favre, Odillon Barrot, Berryer, D'Avimon, and some twenty others little inferior to those named, in ability and eloquence, have been elected, and will occupy seats in the popular Chamber, during the ensuing six years. From this brilliant band, whose power is not to be estimated by numbers, neither ministerial extravagance nor ministerial delinquency need expect mercy. They will wage skillful war against the minions of arbitrary power; they will denounce foreign conquests and onerous taxes; they will claim greater freedom for the Press and for individuals; and, though they may suffer defeat after defeat, still their arguments and their oratory will go forth to the country, and every defeat which they sustain will but add to their influence and multiply their adherents.

abstract: A good commercial  transaction should never be considered amiss, either in peace or war, and therefore we read wild lively interest, that Mr. CLARK MILLS has offered to sell to our City an equestrian statue of Gen. JACKSON for the trifling sum of $30,000.
lead_paragraph: -- A good commercial transaction should never be considered amiss, either in peace or war, and therefore we read wild lively interest, that Mr. CLARK MILLS has offered to sell to our City an equestrian statue of Gen. JACKSON for the trifling sum of $30,000. The statue is a duplicate of the work that stands out in the weather in Lafayette-square, City of Washington. The duplicate was made for one of the rebellious States, the order having been given before the war. But as it has not been paid for, and Mr. MILLS has nothing reliable as to the wishes of the "rebellious State" in the premises, he feels at liberty to cast about for another customer. The Corporation of New-York City is supposed to have the needed amount of patriotism, taste, and surplus funds to invest in so costly a specimen of the Fine Arts. In one way, we suppose, the equestrian statue could not be considered extravagant at the price. Mr. MILLS tells the City Fathers that $30,000 is less by "two-thirds than the sum he received for the original." One of two conclusions must be accepted. Either Mr. MILLS charged the Nation a great deal too much for the statue erected in Washington, or he volunteers a "sacrifice" in selling the duplicate to our City that exceeds in liberality the most "prodigious bargains" of any Chatham-street clothing-store.

abstract: Freedom of the Press and Copperhead Spouters
snippet: Freedom of the Press and Copperhead Spouters
lead_paragraph: The untraveled spouters of the Copperhead faction, institute solemnly amusing comparisons between the " military despotism" at Washington and the tyrannical practices of European Governments. The illustrations are vague enough, and it is quite impossible that a single soul should view them otherwise than as the wild facetiae of rant. The "freedom of the Press" is an especially convenient phrase, and the suppression of a disloyal sheet is characterized as a thing unparalleled in the history of the ancient or modern world.

abstract: Passengers who arrived, last evening, from Cumberland, report that about one thousand of Gen. MILROY'S men had arrived at New-Greek. A gentleman who was in Winchester at the time of the attack......
lead_paragraph: Passengers who arrived, last evening, from Cumberland, report that about one thousand of Gen. MILROY'S men had arrived at New-Greek. A gentleman who was in Winchester at the time of the attack on Gen. MILROY, Sunday afternoon, is among the passengers. He says that when our forces were attacked four miles out of Winchester, on the Manchester road, that a terrible scene of confusion.[???] ensued, and the men were dispersed in all directions. Our informant, with others, started for Sir John's Run on the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and was joined during the next day by various straggling parties, and when the straggling force reached New-Creek, it was about one thousand strong, and consisted of cavalry, infantry and artillery, and very few or the men had arms. These men came to Cumber land, and from Cumberland they came on to New-Creek, where they still remain, in command of Gen. KELLEY, who is now at that point.

abstract: The President has appointed the following sons of officers of the Army and Navy to the Naval Academy, for the year 1863, in accordance with the provisions of the eighth section of the act approved July 14, 1862: Allen Smith, son of Maj.-Gen. C.F. Smith, United States army, who made the decisive attack on Fort Donelson, in February, 1862, and died April 25, 1862, from disease contracted by exposure in the service; Ashbarton Webster, son of Col Fletcher Webster, and grandson of Daniel Webster. Col. Webster died of wounds received in battle, near Washington, D.C., Aug. 27. 1862. Frank Case Birney, of Philadelphia, son of Maj.-Gen. Birney, United States army; John A. Rodgers, son of Major R.O. Rodgers, Maryland Volunteers; James De Camp, son of Capt. James De Camp, United States Navy; Morris De Haven, son of Lieut. Edwin De Haven, United States Navy, who was sent by the United States Government, in 1853, in search of Sir John. Franklin, and now on the retired list of the Navy, in consequence of physical infirmities; Lambert G. Palmer, son of Surgeon J.C. Palmer, United States Navy; Jonathan M. Wainwright, United States Navy, son of Commander Wainwright, killed in battle on board the Harriet Lane, in Galves on harbor, Texas, Jan. 1. 1863; Arthur Walke, son of Capt. H. Walke. United States Navy, now serving in the Mississippi Squadron; Charles W. Ward, son of Commander James H. Ward, killed in action, June 27, 1861, off Mathias Hoint, Potomac River.

abstract: Almost every peo  ple of Europe has a newspaper organ in this country, and indeed in this city. The deep interest taken in the affairs of Poland has led to the establishment of an organ in the language of that country. It is called Echo z Polski, or Polish Echo, and contains full details concerning the present Polish war for independence. It is published under the auspices of the Central Polish Committee.

abstract: Capt. FREDERICK NELSON, of the pilot boat Charles H. Marshall No. 3, reports that on 17th inst. spoke fishing schooner Rose, of Boston. The Captain came on board, and reported having been boarded ...
lead_paragraph: Capt. FREDERICK NELSON, of the pilot boat Charles H. Marshall No. 3, reports that on 17th inst. spoke fishing schooner Rose, of Boston. The Captain came on board, and reported having been boarded the day previous, by the privateer Nantucket, bearing north by east, thirty miles. He (the privateer) took two barrels of mackerel, and all the pork they had on board; he said he would not hurt any poor man, but was looking out for the rich ones.

abstract: The London shipping Gazette, of the 8th inst., says that a question is likely to be raised in the House of Lords whether it is competent for the Government of a neutral State to afford protection, by convoy, without infringing upon recognized belligerent rights; and, in reference to the proceedings of Her Majesty's ship Ariadne, in the West Indies, a copy of the instructions to the British Admiral will be moved for, with a view of ascertaining how far they are in conformity with international law.
lead_paragraph: The London shipping Gazette, of the 8th inst., says that a question is likely to be raised in the House of Lords whether it is competent for the Government of a neutral State to afford protection, by convoy, without infringing upon recognized belligerent rights; and, in reference to the proceedings of Her Majesty's ship Ariadne, in the West Indies, a copy of the instructions to the British Admiral will be moved for, with a view of ascertaining how far they are in conformity with international law.

abstract: -- MARY ANN MCLAUGHLIN was placed on trial in the Kings' County Court of Oyer and Terminer, on Thursday, on the charge of murder in the first degree. The accused resided with her parents in Park-avenue, near Canton-street, in October last. The father, THOMAS MCLAUGHLIN, the mother, CECELIA MCLAUGHLIN, a son named FRANK, 12 years of age, and MARY, aged 19, comprised the family. They occupied the third floor of the house. Mrs. MCLAUGHLIN, the victim, had been blind for some years. With the exception of the son, all were addicted to drinking, and had frequent quarrels. On the afternoon of the 19th of October last, the mother was found dead in her room by the son. She was lying on the floor in a pool of blood, flowing from a dozen wounds. The stove had been upset and all the furniture was disarranged, indicating that there had been a struggle. The father was lying helplessly drunk in a connecting apartment. The son had bought brandy for the father during the forenoon. He went out to play, and on his return met his sister, who was crying. She stated that she had killed her mother, and then told him that the stove had fallen on her. Seeing her lying dead, he awoke his father, who lifted up her head, and, asking how it happened, commenced crying. The accused sent the boy for the Coroner, and requested that he should hold an inquest immediately, so that she could be buried. The Coroner, on visiting the house, at once saw the state of affairs, and caused the arrest of MCLAUGHLIN and his daughter. The latter denied that she was in the house at the time her mother received the injuries from which she died; but it was shown by the boy and other witnesses that she was in the room at the time the murder had evidently been committed. There was no direct proof before the Court as to the commission of the deed, but circumstances were so strongly against the accused at to leave no doubt on the minds of the jury that the injuries sustained by the mother were inflicted by the daughter. The most serious wounds appeared to have been caused by blows from a hatchet. A few witnesses were examined for the defence, but the evidence was unimportant. Nothing whatever was elicited to contradict the testimony of the prosecution showing her guilt. The jury retired about noon on Saturday, and after deliberating for about two hours, brought in a verdict of "Guilty of manslaughter in the second degree." On the announcement of the verdict the prisoner evinced considerable feeling, crying and sobbing most piteously. Sentence was reserved until Tuesday. The father had been discharged by the Grand Jury, and appeared as a witness against his daughter. It was shown conclusively that he was so drunk that he could have known nothing of the matter.
lead_paragraph: -- MARY ANN MCLAUGHLIN was placed on trial in the Kings' County Court of Oyer and Terminer, on Thursday, on the charge of murder in the first degree. There was no direct proof before the Court as to the commission of the deed, but circumstances were so strongly against the accused at to leave no doubt on the minds of the jury that the injuries sustained by the mother were inflicted by the daughter. abstract: Misfortunes of the
snippet: Misfortunes of the
lead_paragraph: -- We have intelligence of the capture of two rebel iron-clad vessels -- one of them the blockaderunner Calypso, an English-built iron screw propeller, which was captured near Wilmington, N.C., on the 11th inst., and the other the famous ram Fingal, which was attacked on the 18th or 19th inst., near Savannah, by two of our Monitors, and captured after an engagement of thirty minutes. We think it must be something like fifteen months since the Fingal crossed the ocean from England, and ran the blockade into the port of Savannah. There she was covered with railroad iron and plates, converted into a ram, and was kept for a long time watching the chance to run out. It was intended that she should attack our blockaders at Savannah and Charleston, in the style in which our blockaders at New-Orleans were attacked by rebel rams shortly after the opening of the war. It was also feared she would attack our land forces stationed at Port Royal, and a great panic was produced there last September by the announcement that the Fingal was coming. The rebels for a long time threw out mysterious and menacing hints about her, and some months ago disting??? ???nnounced that the hour had almost co??? they were going to cry havoc and let ??? the rams of war -- of whom the Fingal was the most terrible. But when we sent the Monitors down to cruise around the harbors of Charleston and Savannah, the Fingal thought proper to lay very low; and the fearful example that the Monitors made of the iron-clad steamer Nashville was not of a kind to entice the Fingal to try her luck while they were around.

abstract: SEVEN  LIVES LOST. One of the most terrible steamboat disasters that has occurred on the river for many years, took place last Monday afternoon. The new tugboat Greenwood, owned by GEORGE H. POWER, of this city, in making her first trip up the river, with a heavy tow, exploded her boiler when opposite Barrytown, killing at least seven persons, and seriously injuring others, and making the boat a complete wreck.
lead_paragraph: SEVEN LIVES LOST. -- One of the most terrible steamboat disasters that has occurred on the river for many years, took place last Monday afternoon. The new tugboat Greenwood, owned by GEORGE H. POWER, of this city, in making her first trip up the river, with a heavy tow, exploded her boiler when opposite Barrytown, killing at least seven persons, and seriously injuring others, and making the boat a complete wreck.

abstract: We publish this morning a special dispatch from headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, dated yesterday, which will set at rest all the Copperhead stories of disaster which for the past few days have been industriously circulated. There had been no engagement whatever up to the date of the dispatch, involving any portion of Gen. HOOKER's army except the cavalry, and of the doings of this arm of the service our readers have been very fully informed. There have been cavalry skirmishes, fights and reconnoissances only, uniformly resulting to our advantage. Some 250 prisoners have been captured within the last three days. No enemy, we are assured, is on or near the old Bull Run battle-ground, and a report of the appearance of a rebel force by way of Dumfries is totally false. Our correspondence, giving further details of the situation, is to the 20th. The brilliant cavalry fight at Aldie on the 18th was followed, it appears, on the 19th, by another equally brilliant, near Middleburgh. Gen. GREGG's division was again engaged, and after a severe fight drove the enemy from the field, capturing one hundred prisoners, and the rebels leaving their dead and wounded behind. The location of the main body of LEE's army is probably by this time fully ascertained. The greater portion of EWRLL's corps is believed to be still around Winchester. LONGSTREET's corps was in the Loudon Valley on Thursday, but it subsequently moved back, apparently into the Shenandoah Valley. HILL's corps, which was the last to leave Fredericksburgh, has not been positively heard from, but it is expected by way of Warrenton. It is now not considered probable that LEE will attempt to cross the Potomac at Nolan's Ford, where he crossed last year, as Gen. HOOKER's present position is such as to make such an attempt extremely foolhardy.

abstract: And his Detractors
snippet: And his Detractors
lead_paragraph: There seems to be is certain quarters a determination that Gen. HOOKER shall not succeed. Nothing has been left unsaid or undone to weaken the confidence of his soldiers in his leadership, and to prepare the people for his being overmatched and overwhelmed. Flippant criticism, jaunty raillery, bitter sneers, high dudgeon, rueful repinings and hysterical despair -- all the resorts that could excite contempt for the commander and alarm for the country -- have been exhausted. Gen. HOOKER still retains command, and will to the end of the campaign. The Government trusts him, the soldiers follow him, the people believe in him. But if the spirit that has been shown against him be any index, it may well be doubted whether his triumph over LEE would excite more disappointment and grief among the rebels than among the Copperheads.

abstract: on the Peace Question
snippet: on the Peace Question
lead_paragraph: In the course of his sermon at the dedication of St. Teresa's Church yesterday, Archbishop HUGHES said that one party can make war, but it requires two to make peace, and that, at present, there seems to be but one side disposed to make peace. He, therefore, pertinently asked, What prospect is there of peace? It might be well for the Peace Democracy to consider this point, and answer the Archbishop -- if they can.

abstract: It is reported from reliable sources that forty thousand rebels are at Hagerstown and Williamsport. Three hundred cavalry are at Mercersburgh, stealing all the horses they can find and pillaging property. The rebels have with them eighteen pieces of artillery, and a force is reported within eight miles of Gettysbursh. Ample preparations on our part have been made to receive them.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBUGRH, Sunday, June 21.

abstract: Among the distinguished visitors to this City we notice at the St. Nicholas Hotel a delegation from the Cincinnati Common Council. They arrived here on Saturday morning from Philadelphia, where they had been entertained by that city's authorities for three days. They departed last evening for Boston, in compliance with an invitation received from the Mayor and Common Council of that city. Their purpose in visiting our Eastern cities is to examine the police and fire alarm telegraphic systems in operation in the different cities, in order to establish a similar system in their own city on their return home. The delegation is composed of two Committees, one on the Fire Department and one on Contracts, accompanied by Assistant-Engineer of the Fire Department T. Chambers, J.F. Stevens, of the Union Telegraph Company. Mr. Walcott. Cincinnati Gazette correspondent, and City Auditor Chas. Betts, Esq. There are four members on each of the Committees. The delegation will stop again in this City on their return from Boston to Cincinnati.

abstract: Your readers have often heard that the citizens of this State (Mississippi) were notoriously illiberal to soldiers. The mountaineer from East Tennessee, who has lived among the living streams that come leaping down every hillside, never imagined that life-giving, abundant water could have a pecuniary value. It is true, however, that in the broad, fertile plains of Mississippi, nothing possesses a greater intrinsic value than the beverage which elsewhere costs nothing. In the desert of Sahara water has its commercial value, and in such a locality it would have its price, like bread; and thus it has been in many portions of this State through which our armies have passed.

abstract: SUICIDE BY SHOOTING. -- Coroner FARREL, of Jersey-City, commenced an inquest on Saturday afternoon, on the body of a respectable appearing man, named THOMAS WALLIS SARGENT, who committed suicide at TAYLOR's Hotel by shooting himself through the head. From facts since ascertained it appears that deceased was a civil engineer, and for about six years past has made his home at the Stevens House in the lower part of Broadway. On Friday afternoon, he came over o TAYLOR's hotel with his baggage and engaged a suite of rooms, stating that he expected his wife, two children and servant from the old country in a few days. On the following morning he was found lying dead on a settee in his room, having shot himself through the head. Amongst his effects was found a letter from his wife, stating that herself and family would arrive in this country about the 26th inst. After the jury had viewed the body the inquest was adjourned to this (Monday) evening.

abstract: What is happening in Pennsylvania deserves the close attention of everybody who wants to get an accurate idea of the nature of the dangers and inconveniences to which we shall be exposed, whenever the Southern Confederacy achieves its independence, if it ever achieve it. Whenever that day comes there is nothing more certain than that the very first institution, after Slavery, which the Confederates will place ...
lead_paragraph: What is happening in Pennsylvania deserves the close attention of everybody who wants to get an accurate idea of the nature of the dangers and inconveniences to which we shall be exposed, whenever the Southern Confederacy achieves its independence, if it ever achieve it. Whenever that day comes there is nothing more certain than that the very first institution, after Slavery, which the Confederates will place "on a sure and lasting foundation," will be a standing army. They will be impelled to do this by divers weighty reasons. Their relations with the North and with foreign nations, will, owing to the peculiar nature of their "property," remain for many years after the war in a very unsettled state.

abstract: Dedication of St. Theresas Church, New-York, by Archbishop Hughes
snippet: Dedication of St. Theresas Church, New-York, by Archbishop Hughes
lead_paragraph: The solemn services incident to the dedication of St. Teresa's (Catholic) Church, corner of Rutgers and Henry streets, yesterday morning, attracted an immense concourse of our Catholic fellow-citizens, Although an admission fee of half a dollar was charged, the vast edifice was crowded to excess, and hundreds, unable to gain admittance, thronged the streets in the vicinity. The services were characterized with all the pomp and ceremony of the Catholic ritual, and derived additional interest from the presence and address of the Most Reverend Archbishop HUGHES. Among the clergy who officiated were Father MCNIERNEY, Master of Ceremonies, the celebrant, Father STARRS, who conducted the dedicatory services and the subsequent High Mass, assisted by Rev. Mr. MCGLYNN as Deacon, and Rev. Mr. MCSWEENEY as Sub-Deacon. Among the reverend gentlemen who participated in the services were Rev. Fathers Morrow, Nelligaa, Mooney, Farrall, MCCarthy, Kregan, Hecker, Curran, Boyce, (Pastor of the Church,) Daly, Duranquet, Quinn, and others. The music, which comprised a mass composed especially for the occasion, by Prof. GUSTAV SCHMITZ, was unusually fine, though somewhat extended, owing to the number of prominent artists who volunteered to assist. Among the voices most noted in the service were those of Mrs. CLARK, of Brooklyn, soprano; Mrs. P.H. CAREY. of New-York, soprano; Mrs. HOLBROOK, alto; Mr. HUBNER, tenor; Mr. HARTMANN, baritone. There was also a splendid chorus of sixteen voices. Prof. SCHMITZ presided at the organ. The solo by Mrs. P.H. CAREY, in the "Benedictus" -- selection from the "Stabat Mater" -- was particularly pleasing, and the performance of the entire choir unusually fine.

abstract: We called attention the other day to the necessity of keeping a sharp lookout toward the mountain gaps that lead from the Shenandoah Valley to the rear of our army, in the direction of Leesburgh, Aldie and the Bull Run Mountains, as there was a great temptation for STUART's cavalry to come through these gaps and cut our line of communication with Washington. The necessity of this warning has been shown in the fact that on the very day our words were written, STUART's cavalry were in force at Aldie, and on that very day the heavy cavalry battle at Aldie took place, in which our forces were victorious and held that position. We have now reason to believe that early last week Gen. HOOKER directed his attention to all these points along the Katoctin and Bull Run Mountains; and now there is no danger whatever of a surprise such as Gen. POPE suffered.

abstract: The steamship City of New-York arrived at this port yesterday. She left Liverpool on the 10th, and Queenstown on the 11th inst. Her news is not so late as was received by the Norwegian, off Cape Race, but her mails are several days later than have before reached us. A vessel which had arrived at Scilly reported having been boarded on the 5th of May, in lat. 4 north, long. 30 west, by a boat from the rebel pirate Georgia. The question of the legality of con???ing vessels by the war-ships of neutral Powers was to come up in the House of Lords, on the 20th, copies of instructions to the British Admiral in the West India waters having been moved for. The case of the Alexandra was set down for the 22d, at Liverpool. The Europe of Frankfort publishes the official text of the American dispatch announced by the Journal of St. Petersburgh, and an analysis of Prince GORTSCHAKOFF's reply to the Cabinet of Washington. The Russian Minister, in order to be able to give his reply as early as possible, has addressed it to Mr. CLAY, Minister of the United States at St. Petersburgh. Prince GORTCHAKOFF expresses the Czar's sentiments of affection and gratitude at the attitude of the United States Government under the grave circumstances in which Russia is placed.

abstract: ASPEY DAY, C.B., Wednesday, June 17, 1863. yesterday, blowing a heavy gale from the eastward  and heavy sea. Ship settled down alt. The sea is at high water up to the spar deck, as far as the mainmast. Part of the cargo above hold is dry. To-day the weather is moderate.

abstract: Work on the city defences is still progressing vigorously, and some of the more important works are now ready to receive the guns. The number of men employed on the fortifications yesterday was 4,605, apportioned as follows: On Herron's Hill, 1.161; on Harrison's Hill, 145; on Mount Washington. 1,363; on Squirrel Hill, 200; and on Negley's Hill. 1,555. There are upward of 5,000 men is the trenches to-day, and with such large working force it cannot take many days to finish the works now in hand. Gen. BERNARD, with a competent staff of engineers, was engaged in laying out new works, yesterday, on the other side of the Allegheny, so as to render the city secure against an advance from that direction. Works have also been laid out near Turtle Creek and other important points, but whether it is the intention to construct them now or at some other time we are not advised. It would be the wisest plan to pi???ceed to their construction right away, and no doubt this is the course which will be adopted.

abstract: Fresh reinforcements to the number of ten thousand men were to be sent out forthwith to Mexico, together with large supplies of material of war. An official announcement had been published upon the steps taken to secure the supply of provisions and munitions to the troops in Mexico. On the 19th of April the army was furnished with supplies for fifty days, the renewal of which was easily effected. Independently of the monthly transports from St. Nazaire, the Minister of Marine had organized a ship service leaving Cherbourg or Toulon on the 23d of every month, carrying out supplies and bringing bark the sick.

abstract: Knoxville Register Proposes to Hang Dutch Soldier
snippet: Knoxville Register Proposes to Hang Dutch Soldier
lead_paragraph: Of late, in all battles and in all recent incursions made by Federal cavalry, we have found the great mass of Northern soldiers to consist of Dutchmen. The plundering thieves captured by FORREST, who stole half the jewelry and watches in a dozen counties of Alabama, were immaculate Dutchmen. The national odor of Dutchmen, as distinctive of the race as that which, constantly ascending to heaven, has distended the nostrils of the negro, is as unmistakable as that peculiar to a pole-cat, an old pipe, or a lager-pier saloon. Crimes, thefts, and insults to the women of the South, invariably mark the course of these stinking bodies of animated sour-krout. ROSECRANS himself is an unmixed Dutchman, an accursed race which has overrun the vast districts of the country of the Northwest. * * * It happens that we entertain a greater degree of respect for an Ethiopian in the ranks of the Northern armies than for an odoriferous Dutchman, who can have no possible interest in this revolution. * * * Why not hang every Dutchman captured? We will hereafter hang, or shoot, or imprison for life all white more taken in command of negroes, and enslave the negroes themselves. This is not too harsh. No human being will assert the contrary. Way, then, should we not hang a Dutchman, who deserves infinitely less of our sympathy than Sam???vo. The live masses of beer, krout, tobacco and rotten cheese, which, on two legs and four, on foot and mounted, go prowling through the South, should be used to manure the sandy plains and barren hillsides of Alabama, Tennessee and Georgia. * * * Whenever a Dutch regiment adorns the limbs of a Southern forest, daring cavalry raids into the South shall cease * * * President Davis need not be specially consulted, and if an accident of this sort should occur to a plundering band like that captured by Forrest, we are not inclined to believe that our President would be greatly disgruntled.

abstract: -- We had the pleasing news yesterday that the "blockade off Charleston is perfect." The mode in which this object has been attained is very simple, and is as consonant with law as it is simple. Instead of attempting to capture as prize the vessels trying to run the blockade, our blockaders, on espying them, pour broadside after broadside into them until they sink or surrender. This is the policy which has been adopted, and will be hereafter carried out at Charleston. It will diminish the chances of our gallant tars for getting prize money, but it will make blockade running a much more perilous business than it has heretofore been.
lead_paragraph: -- We had the pleasing news yesterday that the "blockade off Charleston is perfect." abstract: The Sixty-ninth regiment, Col. BAGLEY, was to have left the City for Pennsylvania at 1 P.M. yesterday, and the regiment was assembled at their armory, over the Essex Market, at the time appointed, but it was found impossible to procure suitable transportation, and they were obliged to postpone their departure until to-day. They will leave at 7 o'clock this morning. The regiment numbers between 700 and 800. The Sixth regiment is also under orders to march to-day. and there is some prospect that the Fifty-fifth will also get off during the day. The remaining companies of the Seventy-first are ordered to assemble at their armory, at 3 P.M., with two days' rations, to take their departure for Pennsylvania, to join their comrades.

abstract: SIR: I have the honor to report to the Department that on the night of the 5th inst., a steamer attempted to run out of Charleston. she was turned back by the Wissahickon, which vessel pursued her over the bar, firing at her repeatedly. The steamer was sunk. From subsequent information from two deserters from Charleston, (whom I send North by the Massachusetts,) there is reason to believe the vessel was the Isaac Smith.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 21.

abstract: All the rumors of battles, victories and disasters in front of Washington last week, were canards. All the statements that HOOKER'S army had retreated behind the defences of Washington, were false. All the detailed accounts that LEE's army was planted at Bull Run, and stretched from Dumfries to Leesburgh, and across the Potomac, were bogus.

abstract: In the United States District Court, the prize steamer Cherokee has been condemned, no claimant having appeared. Testimony was read by which it was clearly shown that this vessel was the British steamer Thistle, built on the Clyde, which sailed from Glasgow bound to Nassau, last Winter, under British flag and papers, and thence to Charleston, running the blockade with a cargo of firearms and other munitions of war. At Charleston she was sold, and she ran out on the 8th May, and was captured, after a chase, by the United States steamer Canandaigua. A decree of condemnation was rendered. The steamer has been taken by the Government for the use of the navy, and the cargo, which was cotton, has been sold. -- Boston Journal, June 18.
lead_paragraph: In the United States District Court, the prize steamer Cherokee has been condemned, no claimant having appeared. abstract: Brace, Chas. L.; The Races of the Old World
snippet: Brace, Chas. L.; The Races of the Old World
lead_paragraph: The prominent place occupied in the public mind by inquiries relating to the subjects constituting the science of Ethnology is one of the most noticeable features of the time. It is only of late years that philosophers have agreed to group together under that head the researches now making into the families or races of man -- their affinities, dividing lines, and distinguishing characteristics. Yet in this brief space the science has taken titular rank with its elder sisters, and can show its societies, journals, &c., in three quarters of the globe -- nay more, it has been rudely invoked to the political arena, where its aid is demanded by contending parties as a new and potent ally. It is impossible to take up a newspaper without observing a tone of argument and reflection on the destinies of nations that would have been scarcely intelligible to our fathers. Struggling and oppressed races, long dormant but reviving nationalities, are the themes orators now delight to dwell on, when they would move most deeply the sympathies of their hearers. So recently as the Congress of Vienna in 1814, it is probable that no considerations of this nature were present to the minds of a single member of it, when engaged in the settlement of the map of Europe, they were volcanic fires smouldering below unconscious feet. Now, however, they are ablaze, and it would seem that events are tending to produce a comparative disregard of the old conventional geographical boundaries of States, and a remodeling of that very map on principles purely ethnological, as national sympathies, popular affinities, identities of language and religious beliefs. Old statesmen and ministers are vexed with thoughts beyond the reaches of their official souls, based on realities sterner than dynastic usurpation, subtler than political expediency. "Celt" and "Saxon," "Slave," "Teuton," "Scandinavian" and "Magyar," are no longer mere abstractions, but have become the watchwords of angry factions, the battle-cries of peoples struggling in the throes of political birth. The future of a continent even may hang on a despot's version of the theory of dominant races, and an appeal to that be considered sufficient to outweigh the ordinary considerations of right and justice. These facts, which it is impossible to ignore, meet us daily in some shape or other. They have a double operation; they stimulate men both of thought and action to the study of the races of man, and all such studies deepen the conviction that seeks expression by grappling with the facts to which they alone afford a satisfactory key or explanation. Some knowledge of the subject is indispensable to all intelligent persons, but the mass of information collected is so large that inquirers have been repelled by it, until the results are arranged and presented in some practicable shape. Neither French nor English literature offers us any portable work setting forth the existing landmarks of this progressive science. This task Mr. BRACE undertakes in the book now before us. A fair examination enables us to say that he has accomplished it in a manner eminently satisfactory. A traveler himself, and one who, like ULYSSES, has seen "many men and many cities," he combines with these personal advantages a thorough acquaintance with the literature of the science in the various European languages. Though perfect uniformity of opinion on points so open to dispute cannot be looked for, Mr. BRACE may be recommended as always a safe and intelligent guide in whose judgment his readers may place reliance. It may be mentioned that the work has undergone the ordeal of English scholarship, and is now publishing in London by Mr. MURRAY, from whose establishment issue the writings of LYELL, MURCHISON, DARWIN, OWEN, and most of the scientific lights of the age.

abstract: We cannot help calling attention again and again to the exploits of our cavalry force in the Army of the Potomac. Those who read carefully the letters of our correspondents, and note the different points mentioned as visited by our cavalry, will see the prodigious work they are doing. They are galloping round the Virginia mountain ranges and defeating the enemy's cavalry wherever found. Not only did they achieve victory in the brilliant battle at Aldie on Wednesday last, but attacked and defeated the enemy again on Thursday -- not only do we find them up at Leesburgh, but down at Warrenton -- not only in the Bull Run, Katoctin and Rattlesnake mountains, but we find them at Snicker's Gap, over on the Blue Ridge. The work they perform, and the information they furnish, is invaluable. Without them, we cannot see how it would be possible for Gen. HOOKER to carry on the campaign in that region.

abstract: It would seem to be a pro  per inference from the facts developed by the reconnoissances of our cavalry, that LEE'S main body is not on this side of the Blue Ridge Mountains. We have penetrated almost every part of the Loudon Valley, and we have forces at all the strategic points from Warrenton up to the Potomac; and no enemy has been seen or found anywhere except STUART'S cavalry, who, according to the ...
lead_paragraph: -- It would seem to be a proper inference from the facts developed by the reconnoissances of our cavalry, that LEE'S main body is not on this side of the Blue Ridge Mountains. We have penetrated almost every part of the Loudon Valley, and we have forces at all the strategic points from Warrenton up to the Potomac; and no enemy has been seen or found anywhere except STUART'S cavalry, who, according to the news this morning, have been whipped in their third engagement within five days. All the indications are, that if at first LEE intended to operate in front of Washington, while he made a feint northward by the Shenandoah Valley, he has now moved nearly all his forces up into the Valley, from whence he is preparing to move them into Maryland, near the scene of his discomfiture last year.

abstract: - The Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle chronicles some of the peregrinations of VALLANDIGHAM in the Confederacy. On Monday, the 7th, he had got as far North as Petersburgh, Va., and after spending a day there he proceeded to Wilmington, in charge of Judge OULD, who would see him safely on board a steamer for Nassau. From thence it was conjectured he would go to Canada, to engineer the political campaign in Ohio, or, perhaps, to New-York City. The Chronicle says: "We are glad VALLANDIGHAM has gone:" and adds: "We ask for him the prayers of the congregation." We do not see the applicability of the last remark, nor comprehend the purport of the proposed prayers. Is the rebel congregation to pray for his success or defeat in the canvass for Governor of Ohio? If they desire his success, we fear rebel prayers will not prevail against Ohio votes; and if it is his defeat they desire, we doubt if they need to cry to Heaven to help in it.

abstract: Rear-Admiral FOOTE still lingers at the Astor House, but his physicians have no hopes of his recovery. There have been several consultations of his physicians -- Drs. METCALF. THOMAS, REYNOLDS, and Surgeon WILLIAMS -- all of whom have pronounced his case hopeless. The Admiral's family, consisting of Mrs. FOOTE, Mrs. REESE, his eldest daughter, and his two sons, are with him. His disease is said to be a complicated disorder of the liver and kidneys.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: A writ of habeas corpus was issued by Hon. Judge BARNARD, of the Supreme Court, on the 10th instant, requiring Col. LOOMIS to produce HENRY A. SMITH before the City Judge at his chambers, on the 11th inst. The petition sets forth that HENRY is a minor, 20 years of age, and enlisted, six months since, in the Fourth Metropolitan regiment, without the knowledge or consent of his mother his father being dead.
lead_paragraph: A writ of habeas corpus was issued by Hon. Judge BARNARD, of the Supreme Court, on the 10th instant, requiring Col. LOOMIS to produce HENRY A. SMITH before the City Judge at his chambers, on the 11th inst. The petition sets forth that HENRY is a minor, 20 years of age, and enlisted, six months since, in the Fourth Metropolitan regiment, without the knowledge or consent of his mother -- his father being dead. That he was physically disabled from performing any military duty; that Dr. MOTT, the military surgeon, so reported, and gave HENRY a certificate, reciting his ailments, and he was thereupon, about five months since, discharged. That, on the 8th inst., he was -- or???ibly arrested by the Provost- Marshal, and tah n to the Park barracks, from whence, on the following day, he was taken to Governor's Island. On the return of the writ, the prisoner was produced, and the hearing adjourned for one week, at which time the parties appeared, and evidence was given of the facts contained in the petition. Mr. ALEXANDER W. REEVEY, the prisoner's Counsel, contended that the certificate given by the authorized military surgeon operated as a discharge, from which it was clearly the intention of the authorities that SMITH should be discharged -- that the enlistment was void ab initio, because the prisoner was a minor, and entered the service without the knowledge or consent of his mother. In support of these propositions, Counsel referred to the 2d Statutes at Large, pp. 135, 792, 3d Statutes at Large, pp. 146, 224. 9th Statutes at Large, p. 507, and the Act of Congress of Feb. 13, 1862. The Court, after consideration, granted an order discharging the prisoner, which discharge was made absolute.

abstract: THE THUMBS AND THE COMING FOURTH. -- Gen. and Mrs. THUMB are patriotic in an inverse ratio to their size, and can by no means be persuaded to leave the country before the anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. On the 4th of July they propose, in connection with the $30,000 N???TT and Miss MINNIE, to startle Gotham by a terrific stroke of enterprise. What it is we are not yet informed. In the meantime, they may, as usual, be seen at the Museum.

abstract: - The telegraph from Washington informed us, yesterday, with much gravity and an air of superlative and patronizing wisdom, that the rumors that had for several days pervaded the North, of heavy battles in front of Washington and of national reverses, were wholly without foundation, and all the painful anxiety they occasioned uncalled for. This late explanation may bring relief, but it can excite no approbation of the policy whose dismal reticence alone gave occasion and life to the rumors that the people suffered under.

abstract: In Newburgh, on Sunday evening, a colored man, who had been arrested on a charge of outraging an Irish servant girl, was taken from jail by a mob of her countrymen and hanged in the jail-yard. Previous to the hanging the victim was beaten and kicked with savage fury by the lynchers. Such an event as this, in the usually very quiet town where it occurred, is most surprising. Till then law and order were obeyed and respected to a highly creditable degree, and the earnest-minded and sober citizens of the place should take the most prompt and effective measures to indicate their condemnation of this first manifestation of lawlessness. The crime of which the negro stood charged with was of a revolting character, but he was amenable to the law, and still had the right of a fair trial. Those who were instrumental in destroying his life, however, in their misguided frenzy, committed the higher crime of murder.
lead_paragraph: In Newburgh, on Sunday evening, a colored man, who had been arrested on a charge of outraging an Irish servant girl, was taken from jail by a mob of her countrymen and hanged in the jail-yard.
