abstract: The rebel newspapers  always become peculiarly ferocious and bloodthirsty when their army is on the offensive. We have, among other Southern papers, the Richmond Whig of last Saturday, which contains column after column of matter that might make one think that the editor was a ghoul, writing exclusively for confederated ghouls.
lead_paragraph: -- The rebel newspapers always become peculiarly ferocious and bloodthirsty when their army is on the offensive. We have, among other Southern papers, the Richmond Whig of last Saturday, which contains column after column of matter that might make one think that the editor was a ghoul, writing exclusively for confederated ghouls. Merciless carnage, sanguinary ideas and black flags dance through and wave over his columns. Even pestilence and the powers of darkness are invoked. He says that yellow fever is now raging in New-Orleans, and adds the hope that the "fever may spread and rage among the Yankees in that hapless city, until all of them are carried off to their abode in the infernal regions." Elsewhere he cries: "Let the black flag wave in every battle in which the negroes are made the tools of the cowardly Abolitionists, and let there be no officer in command of a black regiment taken prisoner unless it be for the purpose of giving him a more merited death by hanging." And so the rebel rages on, until every ghoul in the Confederacy must be excited to madness.

abstract: The rebels are now advancing in force toward Greencastle, and hold that place with a heavy column. abstract: Willing to Own Defeat
snippet: Willing to Own Defeat
lead_paragraph: -- We had occasion a day or two since to call attention to the declaration of the Tribune, that if GRANT should be beaten and the rebels should water their horses in the Delaware, "we should be under foot, and might as well own it." And we said that in our belief "our people would bear burdens in the cause of freedom and the Union as cheerfully as the rebels had borne them in the cause of Slavery, and as heavy ones," &c. All this the Tribune declares to be the "reverse of courageous and patriotic" -- which, we suppose, means cowardly and traitorous. And, having thus summarily disposed of our objections to its remarks, it proceeds to argue, what no one disputes, that we should all do what we can to prevent the rebels from attaining such a measure of success.

abstract: The first call for militia was for three months, 'but this was before the full magnitude of the struggle in which the country was embarking had become apparent.
lead_paragraph: The first call for militia was for three months, 'but this was before the full magnitude of the struggle in which the country was embarking had become apparent. After Bull Run, when it was evident that "a long and bloody war" was in store for us, a call was made for men for three years. A year afterward, after our failure before Richmond, another call was made for men for two years and for nine months. The latest call is for six months, and the number that can be got to volunteer even for this period does not seem to be overwhelmingly large. Most of the levies who have taken the field in Pennsylvania have taken every possible precaution to insure their discharge in thirty days, or when "the emergency" is over; so that six months now seems to be rather more than the maximum period for which men will enlist in any great force, and this only under pressure of invasion. It remains to be seen whether they would enlist in much greater numbers for three months, as a call for that period has still to be made. But aside from their actual effectiveness in raising men, these calls for short periods are open to the very strong and very palpable objection that each of them is a sort of intimation to the South to hold out, and it will succeed. When we called an army into the field for three years, and made no arrangements for renewing it as it diminished, it was tantamount to telling the rebels that if they could protract the contest to the close of that period, we should leave them masters of the field. Since then, nothing we have done toward reinforcing it has had any tendency whatever to prolong its existence. In a year from this time, unless some steps are taken in the interval to avert it, the United States will not have a single soldier in the field, and yet he must be a very sanguine man who feels confident that there is not more than even this year's work left at the South for soldiers to do.
headline: {'main': 'An Army for the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Army for the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We learned ten  days ago that the name of the "acting telegraphic supervisor," or censor, at Washington, to whom we are indebted for so many sensations and misbeliefs, was "Mr. LYNCH." We now learn an additional fact concerning him, which we hasten to publish. It is from the Washington correspondent of the Commercial Advertiser.
lead_paragraph: We learned ten days ago that the name of the "acting telegraphic supervisor," or censor, at Washington, to whom we are indebted for so many sensations and misbeliefs, was "Mr. LYNCH." We now learn an additional fact concerning him, which we hasten to publish. It is from the Washington correspondent of the Commercial Advertiser. The correspondent ably remarks that the censor (LYNCH) is a "very young man." This is excellent and striking, as far as it goes, but we should like to know precisely his age, and also whether he parts his hair in the middle. The same correspondent makes some nice remarks as to the indefinitely, young man's occupation prior to being installed as censor; but as he was employed in rather an humble sphere of duty, we do not think it proper to tell what it was. It may be considered quite??? a neat thing to in- trust the sensations of the nation and its knowledge of the war to a very young man, who possibly parts his hair in the middle, whose sphere of labor has heretofore been humble and confined to country districts; but we should think it was rather a grave business.

It was supposed the Government would flood tha valley on the approach of the French, and in every other ...
lead_paragraph: We have advices from the City of Mexico to the 24th ult., by way of San Francisco. All the French residents have been compelled to leave the city. JUAREZ had taken command of the Mexican troops in person, and the fortifications around the city were being strengthened. It was supposed the Government would flood tha valley on the approach of the French, and in every other possible manner make a desperate resistance. COMONFORT had been much censured for not relieving the garrison of Puebla, and in consequence had resigned. The French advance had arrived at San Martin los Mulican.

abstract: For the War, need of an
snippet: For the War, need of an
lead_paragraph: STUART's cavalry has suffered another defeat at the hands of Gen. PLEASANTON -- a worse one, apparently, than either of the preceding ones. Gen. PLEASANTON, in an official report of the affair, states that he moved with his command, on Sunday morning, to Middleburgh, and attacked STUART. The rebels were driven steadily all day, losing heavily at every step. We captured two pieces of artillery -- one a Blakeley gun, with three caissons, and another blown up, together with a large number of prisoners, including a number of prominent officers. All the rebel dead and wounded were left on the field, with carbines, pistols and sabres in large numbers. The rebels were driven beyond Upperville into Ashby's Gap, a distance of eight miles. Our loss was very small, both in men and horses, notwithstanding very heavy charges were made and the sabre was used freely.

abstract: The Hudson River steamer Mary Powell, Capt. A.L. ANDERSON, made the run between New-York and Poughkeepsie, on Friday, in three hours and forty-  two minutes. Leaving New-York at 3 1/2 o'clock, P.M., she reached the latter city at 7??? 12 o'clock. Deducting thirty-five minutes consumed at landings, and five minutes lost in getting into the stream on starting, and the actual running time for the seventy-five miles is three hours and two minutes -- a feat unprecedented in annals of Hudson River steamboating.

abstract: The brig Umpire, of Boston, Capt. PERRY, was captured, burned and sunk in lat. 37째 37, lon. 69째 57 1/2', about noon on the 14th inst., by the privateer Tacony, or Florida No. 2. She was from Sagua for Boston, with a cargo of sugar and molasses. The Captain and crew agree in stating that they were kindly treated and comfortably provided for, as far as the circumstances would allow. They were transferred to the packet ship Isaac Webb on the 19th, ???in lat. 40째 25', lon. 69째. Capt. PERRY does not know whether his vessel was insured or not. The Tacony showed no colors until within a mite of the brig, when she hoisted the American Ensign and afterward the Confederate flag.

abstract: The rebels are reported to have reoccupied Chambersburgh, Penn., yesterday. After its evacuation, two or three regiments were sent forward from Harrisburgh to hold it, but these troops seem to have retired when they heard the rebels were returning, and to have made no opposition whatever. Whether it was because they had no artillery, or no competent officers, or knew positively that they were too weak in numbers to resist the rebel forces, does not yet appear. It was stated yesterday that a Gen. Somebody had "commenced fortifying Chambersburgh," and that Gen. COUCH had "ordered it to be held;" but the programme was suddenly changed on the news of another rebel advance. There was a very large amount of Government hay left untouched at Chambersburgh when the rebels left it, the other day. It will probably be disposed of now. We hope the abandonment of the place, in the present case, will not turn out as discreditable as much of the running away on the occasion of the rebels' first approach.
lead_paragraph: The rebels are reported to have reoccupied Chambersburgh, Penn., yesterday. abstract: The position of the army of the rebel Gen. LEE seems gradually to be developing. All accounts, for two days past, concur in placing it in the Shenandoah Valley. The corps of Gen. EWELL was sent ahead to clear the way...
lead_paragraph: The position of the army of the rebel Gen. LEE seems gradually to be developing. All accounts, for two days past, concur in placing it in the Shenandoah Valley. The corps of Gen. EWELL was sent ahead to clear the way, which it did very completely -- in two days driving MILROY from Winchester, seizing that place and all its outposts, and sending the remnant of MILROY's forces to the north side of the Potomac. From the capture of Winchester, ten days ago, to the present time, the rebels have nowhere been seen in force. JENKINS' cavalry brigade invaded Maryland and Pennsylvania, and have been busy for near a fortnight in gathering and taking away all the horses they could find. Gen. PLEASANTON has had several severe and brilliant engagements with STUART's cavalry east of the Blue Ridge, the victory each time resting with the Union standards. Gen. KELLEY has met a portion of the rebels marauding in and near Cumberland, Md., and has driven them back eastwardly. But, excepting in these three directions -- near the Gaps in the Blue Ridge, at Hagerstown and Chambersburgh, and at Cumberland -- there has been no contact with the enemy to show his numbers or the direction of his movement.

abstract: Letters have been received from Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, dated at Liverpool, stating that his trip was an exceedingly pleasant one, and that it passed unmarred by any undue manifestations of the mal du mer. We hear from other sources that Mr. BEECHER slept steadily eighteen hours of the first twenty-four, and that he was in a jolly good humor from the word "go" to the dropping of the anchor.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, Gov. MORTON, of Indiana, at the invitation of D.R. MARTIN, Esq., President of the Ocean Bank, and Col. FRANK E. HOWE, took a pleasure trip down the Bay, in order...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, Gov. MORTON, of Indiana, at the invitation of D.R. MARTIN, Esq., President of the Ocean Bank, and Col. FRANK E. HOWE, took a pleasure trip down the Bay, in order to obtain a view of the harbor and fortifications of New-York. Among the guests invited were, Maj.- Gen. WOOL and Staff, Gen. HIRAM WALBRIDGE, who has just returned from the West, L.L. L'HOMMEDIEU, formerly of the Cincinnati Gazette, Mayor HUSSEY, of Cleveland, Col. BAKER, of Ohio, CHARLES GOULD, Mrs. Gen. N.P. abstract: Recorder HOFFMAN, yesterday, rendered his decision in the case of Dr. BROWN, the abortionist, whose counsel, it will be recollected, put in a special plea to the last indictment against him, that their...
lead_paragraph: Recorder HOFFMAN, yesterday, rendered his decision in the case of Dr. BROWN, the abortionist, whose counsel, it will be recollected, put in a special plea to the last indictment against him, that their >client had been once placed in "jeopardy," and could not therefore be tried again. The "jeopardy," it will also be recollected, consisted in his having been arraigned for trial, and after six jurors had been sworn, the Judge (BANARD) abandoned the trial and discharged the jurors. The District Attorney demurred to this special plea, and the argument on the demurrer was heard before the Recorder on the 13th inst, The point of law raised is entirely new, and the able opinion of the Recorder will be read with interest. The case will probably be taken to the Court of Appeals.

abstract: TURKS ISLAND, June 3. -- The brig Crawford, of East Machias, Munson, from Bangor for Aspinwall, with a cargo of lumber, ran ashore on the Northeast Reef of this island, on the 1st inst., and became a total wreck. Her cargo consisted of 98,500 feet white pine, and 77 spruce spars. The wreckers are now at work saving cargo, the greater portion of which will be saved, and sold here. -- (From Ellwood Walter, Esq, Secretary Board of Underwriters.)

abstract: Alderman BOOLE was sworn in as City Inspector soon after his appointment to the office, on Monday afternoon, and immediately proceeded to the performance of his new duties.
lead_paragraph: Alderman BOOLE was sworn in as City Inspector soon after his appointment to the office, on Monday afternoon, and immediately proceeded to the performance of his new duties. Yesterday morning he was out early visiting the various dumping-grounds, with the view of learning the management of the details of street-cleaning, and reached his office in good season. There he found the crowd that inevitably besiege each new incumbent of an official position commanding any patronage. Their main desire was to fill the new post of Deputy Superintendent of Sanitary Inspection, recently created by an ordinance of the Common Council. All uncertainty, if not all anxiety in the matter, was soon set at rest by the appointment of Ex-Alderman JOHN H. BRADY, for whom the place was specially created. A few months ago Mr. BRADY was appointed Inspector of Railroads by the Croton Board, by the influence of his former colleagues in the Common Council, and a short time ago he was turned out of this berth in order that a party who had been instrumental in passing, at Albany, the bill extending the term of office of the members of the Croton Board, might be rewarded with it. The Common Council were thus baulked of all their kindness to their old colleague, but as a salve, it was arranged that Mr. BRADY should have the new office which Col. DELAVAN had asked should be created in his department. Mr. BOOLE had about one hundred applications made to him for the place during yesterday, and the pressure brought to bear upon him by the applicants and their friends, to secure the prize, was tremendous. They probably will feel considerably disappointed on learning that the result had long been a foregone conclusion.

abstract: At no time since the war began has work been put in more vigorously by both sides, than during the past two weeks. Everywhere the utmost activity prevails, the greatest enterprises are planned, and the most determined efforts to achieve grand results are making. GRANT is pounding Vicksburgh into submission. BANKS is doing a like work for Port Hudson. BRAGG is feeling his way to the flanks of ROSECRANS. And LEE is bursting his way into Maryland and Pennsylvania. Gen. CARTER is spreading terror among rebels by another highly successful raid in East Tennessee. The rebels return the compliment by sending MORGAN toward Kentucky, and pushing 1,000 rebels into Indiana. Gens. MARMADUKE and PRICE are drawing their forces closely around Helena. And our iron-clads are shutting up, effectually at last, the harbors of Charleston and Savannah. Wherever we look on all the field of war there is visible sign that each side is straining every nerve for decisive action. We can hardly resist the conclusion that the next two weeks will prove the most thrillingly eventful of the whole war, and go far toward furnishing the solution of a strife, the most gigantic that ever shook the world.

abstract: To-day Gen. PLEASANTON, having completed the work for which he was sent into this vicinity, commenced to move his force to another field of operations, when a portion of Gen. STUART'S command...
lead_paragraph: To-day Gen. PLEASANTON, having completed the work for which he was sent into this vicinity, commenced to move his force to another field of operations, when a portion of Gen. STUART'S command smarting under the disgraceful defeat of yesterday, got within range of his guns, and they (the guns and rebels both) went off. The enemy, seeing they were closely watched, very prudently kept at a respectful distance.

abstract: The unanimity and enthusiasm with which the nomination of JOHN BROUGH is hailed by all the true war men of Ohio Republicans as well as Democrats is a grand token of the...
lead_paragraph: The unanimity and enthusiasm with which the nomination of JOHN BROUGH is hailed by all the true war men of Ohio -- Republicans as well as Democrats -- is a grand token of the completeness with which all the old party questions are becoming merged in the one vital issue between war and peace. No man was more thoroughly identified with the Democratic party than this former Editor of the Cincinnati Enquirer, the leading Democratic organ of the Northwest; and to this day he has renounced none of his old party principles. In a speech delivered before a popular convention in Marietta, a week previous to his nomination, he defined his position as follows:

abstract: Jane F. Cawley vs. Thomas C. Lyman. This was an action brought to recover $2,000 damages for an alleged breach of contract. The plaintiff claimed that in October, 1861, the defendant was in the shipchandiery...
lead_paragraph: Jane F. Cawley vs. Thomas C. Lyman. -- This was an action brought to recover $2,000 damages for an alleged breach of contract. The plaintiff claimed that in October, 1861, the defendant was in the shipchandiery business in South-street, and sold out to her his stock and fixtures and business for an agreed upon amount; that he also agreed to remain in the store and introduce the customers; that he did remain in the store till the following February, but during that time took some of the business that came into the store and did it himself, to the amount of several thousand dollars, and that some of the fixtures were not his to sell, but belonged to the landlord.

abstract: It is published in Illinois that Secretary STANTON has telegraphed to Gov. YATKS to know how many men can be called out in that State for temporary service, in case Illinois shall be invaded. It has been published that...
lead_paragraph: It is published in Illinois that Secretary STANTON has telegraphed to Gov. YATKS to know how many men can be called out in that State for temporary service, in case Illinois shall be invaded. It has been published that the Governor of Indiana had issued a call for 20,000 volunteers for six months' service -- but this has been specifically denied in a dispatch from Indianapolis. It is much to be hoped that the statement in each case is unfounded, and that the military strength of these two great fighting States will not be impaired by the organization of six months' troops. Under the excitement and pressure of the actual invasion of Maryland and Pennsylvania, the War Department has called for 120,000 six months' men from the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Maryland and West Virginia. Secretary STANTON has since informed Gov. CURTIN that the troops under this call will probably not be wanted for over thirty days, and at all events shall be discharged "as soon as the emergency is past." This is very indefinite language, and well calculated to breed discontent in certain contingencies. For instance, when will "the emergency be over?" When the rebels are driven out of Pennsylvania, or when they are South of the Potomac again? A Pennsylvania volunteer, enlisting to protect his State, will not wish to march beyond his State line, and will feel that the emergency is past when the rebels are back in Maryland and retreating.

abstract: At about 10  o'clock yesterday A.M., an explosion occurred in the building known as No. 25 John-street, near Nassau, which resulted in the destruction of a large amount of property, and in injuries by burning, to sevaral persons, some of whom...
lead_paragraph: At about 10 1/2 o'clock yesterday A.M., an explosion occurred in the building known as No. 25 John-street, near Nassau, which resulted in the destruction of a large amount of property, and in injuries by burning, to sevaral persons, some of whom are regarded as in a dangerous condition. From persons who were in the immediate vicinity at the time, we learn there were three distinct shocks, evidently the result of three explosions, occurring at intervals of from five to fifteen seconds. The sound was like that of heavy artillery, and for a few moments after there were hundreds of persons who suddenly paused and asked themselves: Are not the rebel privateers bombarding the City? The force of the explosion very sensibly shook buildings situated three blocks away from the scene.

abstract: These horses trot to-day on the Fashion Course under saddle, mile heats, best three in five. Although great dissatisfaction arose from the decision of the majority of the judges, on the part of many who were affected by it at the last race, when Butler was declared distanced; yet the majority of bets were paid, and Butler's ba???kers have great faith in his ability to beat Patchen in the race to-day. AS many of Patchen's backers gave up their money before the decision of the judges was given, some had considerable difficulty in getting it refunded, whilst others failed altogether, and have learned a lesson never to consider a race ended until it is decided by the judges

abstract: Although our troops withdrew from Chambersburgh last night the rebels did not enter the place till 11 o'clock this morning. It was believed at daylight that the enemy would not advance, and the troops that fell back to Carlisle were ordered to return to Chambersburgh. The unfounded reports of last night, however, were superseded by facts at noon today.

abstract: Moses Lowenberg, plaintiff in error, against the People, defendants in error. Dr. Lowenberg was convicted in the General Sessions of murder in the first degree, in having killed one Hoffman.
lead_paragraph: Moses Lowenberg, plaintiff in error, against the People, defendants in error. -- Dr. Lowenberg was convicted in the General Sessions of murder in the first degree, in having killed one Hoffman. The Court of Sessions sentenced the prisoner to suffer the punishment of death for said murder and felony on Friday, the 20th day of February. 1863, between the hours of ten in the forenoon and two in the afternoon of that day; and it is further ordered and adjudged by this Court that said Moses Lowenberg be confined at hard labor in the State Prison until such punishment of death shall be inflicted.

abstract: Recruiting for this favorite and well-known City regiment is now rapidly progressing. Nine companies have been organized, and their ranks are being filled with first-class material. None but active, healthy and strong men are received, as it is the intention of Col. WINSLOW to produce a regiment in every particular equal to the one he has so long commanded. The merchants and bankers of this city have become interested in the reorgnization of this regiment, and subscriptions are now being made for the purpose of paying an extra bounty to first-class men and those who have returned from the field. This fond is placed on deposit for disbursement with Mr. J.M. BENEDICT, Vice-President of the Ocean Bank. Semi-monthly returns are made to each subscriber of the expenditures.

abstract: HEAVY ROBBERY. -- The clothing store of Messrs. MCCOY & MOUNT, corner of Montgomery and Greene streets, Jersey City, was entered by burglars, daring Sunday night, and robbed of cloths and vestings valued at over $500. The entrance was effected by boring a hole through the top of a shed, and afterwards by prying open a window with a jimmy.
lead_paragraph: HEAVY ROBBERY. -- The clothing store of Messrs. abstract: Commodore STEPHEN C. ROWAN, Commander of the iron-clad frigate Roanoke, has been ordered to proceed to Port Royal, and to relieve Commodore CRAVEN in command of the iron-clad frigate NewIronsides. Commander CREIGHTON it is said will assume command of the Roanoke, and proceed South with her. It is believed that the Government will charter a vessel to convey to Port Royal Commodore ROWAN and all the other officers recently ordered to the South Atlantic fleet.
lead_paragraph: Commodore STEPHEN C. abstract: We have advices from Europe two days later, by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamships Canada and City of Cork. The news is to the 14th inst. President LINCOLN, through Minister ADAMS, had returned his warm thanks to the Liverpool Emancipation Society for their friendly address. News of the capture of Puebla by the French had reached England, and was received with satisfaction on Change in London. Mexican bonds advanced 2 1/2 @ 3 1/2 ??? cent. Parliamentary proceedings were without importance. The Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia had congratulated the French Emperor on the capture of Puebla. Reports were current in Paris on the 12th that the orders for sending reinforcements to Mexico had been countermanded, but the reports were subsequently denied. The Polish revolutionists had destroyed all the telegraph lines leading out of Warsaw. It was reported that the notes of the three Powers to Russia regarding Poland would be dispatched to St. Petersburgh on the 13th. In the Liverpool market Cotton was firm, but unchanged. Breadstuff's were dull, but steady, and Provisions flat. Console were quoted at 92 @ 92 ???

abstract: We have had no news whatever of operations by our forces on the James Peninsula for the last ten days -- or since LEE and his army struck out for the North. It was supposed that the movement of the main rebel army furnished an opportunity for our pretty heavy bodies of troops south of Richmond to advance against that city. The public have no information of the number of rebel troops retained at and near the rebel Capital for its defence. It may be considered sure that JEFF. DAVIS would retain what he considered a sufficient force for his own protection. The defensive works around Richmond, by every line of approach, are known to be very strong -- as strong as they can be made of the kind. We need expect no weak spots in the defences of Richmond. It is the most important position in the Confederacy. It was believed that the rear defences of Vicksburgh were of no account, and that GRANT would soon level them or surmount them. A test of the matter has proved that this was a mistaken belief. We may be sure that Richmond is no weaker than Vicksburgh. It has been the rebel capital for two years, and, as we have made efforts to approach it in every direction, there is no doubt it has been fortified in every direction. If so, it might be thought, with the case of Vicksburgh before the rebels and before us, that it would not require a very powerful garrison to hold the works against a vastly superior force. The defenders of Vicksburgh do not probably number over 15,000, while GRANT's army numbers four times as many, yet they have kept GRANT at bay for over five weeks. Fifteen or twenty thousand, perhaps, could do as much for Richmond. And we need not doubt that Jeff. DAVIS has that number, or twice that number, of conscript defenders within call.

abstract: THE HUDSON RIVER BAPTIST ASSOCIATION.  The thirteenth anniversary exercises of the Hudson River Baptist Association were commenced at the Hanson-place Church yesterday morning, before a large congregation. The body is composed of about 40 churches.
lead_paragraph: THE HUDSON RIVER BAPTIST ASSOCIATION. -- The thirteenth anniversary exercises of the Hudson River Baptist Association were commenced at the Hanson-place Church yesterday morning, before a large congregation. The body is composed of about 40 churches. They meet annually for fraternal conference, to hear each other's statements and to encourage brotherly sympathy and union. It disclaims all power of making laws for the churches, but deems it a duty to observe and guard with a jealous care the condition of all churches of that denomination, and determining the propriety of continuing connection with other churches. Rev. WM. J. MICKEL, of the Sixteenth-street Baptist Church, was chosen Moderator, and the opening discourse was delivered by Rev. W.H. PENDLETON, of the Cannon-street Baptist Church. After the sermon Committees were appointed, and the Conference adjourned until this morning.

abstract: About 10  o'clock yesterday forenoon an explosion of saltpetre occured at No. 25 John-street, near Nassau, whereby several persons were seriously injured, and a large amount of property was destroyed. Mr. PECKHAM, proprietor of the premises where the accident occurred, is not expected to recover from the effect of the burns he received. An investigation as to the cause of the explosion will be made to-day.
lead_paragraph: About 10 1/2 o'clock yesterday forenoon an explosion of saltpetre occured at No. 25 John-street, near Nassau, whereby several persons were seriously injured, and a large amount of property was destroyed. Mr. PECKHAM, proprietor of the premises where the accident occurred, is not expected to recover from the effect of the burns he received. An investigation as to the cause of the explosion will be made to-day.

abstract: Iron-clads, the Construction and Merits of
snippet: Iron-clads, the Construction and Merits of
lead_paragraph: In the accounts which we published yesterday of the iron-clad battle between the Monitor Weehawken and the rebel iron-clad Atlanta, we have the first true test of the wisdom of ERICSSON'S system of building vessels of war. When the Monitor fought the Merrimac in Hampton Roads, and permitted her to return to Norfolk without being either totally destroyed or captured, ERICSSON claimed that the full powers of his vessel had not been tested, because the guns which had been furnished him by the Navy Department were not so powerful as he had asked for, or as the vessel was capable of carrying. That original iron-clad battle, therefore, only proved the impregnability of the Monitor when opposed to the most powerful ordnance then afloat.

abstract: Col. Montgomery Expeditions
snippet: Col. Montgomery Expeditions
lead_paragraph: When Gen. GRANT lately ordered the ravaging of a large section of country between Vicksburgh and Canton, he took a step not only necessary in itself, but justified by the laws of war. It was done purely for military purposes. JOHNSTON's army was on the verge of the ravaged region, was drawing supplies from it, and in case of an advance toward GRANT's rear, the provisions, the mills, manufactories and bridges between the Yazoo and Big Black Rivers would be of the greatest service to him. To destroy them was to retard the advance of the enemy, if not to make it altogether impracticable. This, therefore, we say, was an instance of justifiable devastation.

snippet: Jersey City Yacht Club; Annual Regatta
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL REGATTA OF THE JERSEY CITY YACHT CLUB. -- The Annual Regatta of the Jersey City Yacht Club came off Tuesday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, from McGiehan's Basin, foot of Van Vorst-street, a large number of spectators being present. Messrs. QUAIFE, REA and SMITH were the judges. The hour announced for starting was 12 o'clock, but through some delay the boats did not start till 1 o'clock. The third class started first, the second following, and then the third. The smallest boats in each class started first. An interval of thirty seconds was allowed between the boats, and one minute between the classes. The following were the boats which were entered:

abstract: Portions of Gen. GREGG'S cavalry command have been engaged skirmishing with the enemy nearly all day. The enemy's line of skirmishers were met early this morning in a piece of woods a little to the west of Middleburgh, and they were gradually forced back about five miles on the road leading to Ashby's Gap, where, it is said, the enemy have two brigades of infantry.
lead_paragraph: NEAR RECTOR's FOUR CORNERS, Va., Friday Evening, June 19, 1863.

abstract: Our dispatches from the headquarters of Gen. HOOKER'S army, this morning, renders it positive that the bulk of the rebel army is west of the Blue Ridge. STUART'S cavalry range up and down under its eastern shadows, but Gen. PLEASANTON keeps sharp watch of him, and skirmishes occur daily.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from the headquarters of Gen. HOOKER'S army, this morning, renders it positive that the bulk of the rebel army is west of the Blue Ridge. STUART'S cavalry range up and down under its eastern shadows, but Gen. PLEASANTON keeps sharp watch of him, and skirmishes occur daily. Gen. STAHL has pushed a reconnoissance to Warrenton, Sulphur Springs, Rappahannock Ford, and other points, and ascertained that there are no rebels in that direction. Gen. BUFORD, on Tuesday, went to the top of the Blue Ridge, and discovered LONGSTREET's camp in plain sight.

abstract: Two regiments still remain--the Forty-seventh infantry and Seventieth cavalry--both of which are under marching orders, and will leave some time during the week. Both the brigades at the seat of war--the Fifth and Eleventh--will then be full. The Generals in command received their orders on Tuesday, and last night proceeded with their commands to Harrisburgh.
lead_paragraph: Two regiments still remain -- the Forty-seventh infantry and Seventieth cavalry -- both of which are under marching orders, and will leave some time during the week. Both the brigades at the seat of war -- the Fifth and Eleventh -- will then be full. The Generals in command received their orders on Tuesday, and last night proceeded with their commands to Harrisburgh. The Staff-officers of the Fifth brigade are as follows: Brigadier-General, PHILIP H. CROOKE: Brigade Inspector. Capt. Wm.H. Daycraft: Surgeon, Dr. Thomas McAllister; Aid. Capt. John H. Bergen; Quartermaster, Capt. James Mooney.

abstract: Later news from Mexico, by way of Havana, is received, but it is not important. The escape of ORTEGA and other Mexican officers from Orizaba is confirmed. ORTEGA and his companions were  at Jalapa on the 29th ult., and intended to leave immediately for the Capital. The resignation of COMONFORT had been received by the Government.
lead_paragraph: Later news from Mexico, by way of Havana, is received, but it is not important. The escape of ORTEGA and other Mexican officers from Orizaba is confirmed. ORTEGA and his companions were at Jalapa on the 29th ult., and intended to leave immediately for the Capital. The resignation of COMONFORT had been received by the Government. Preparations for the defence of the Capital, even to mandating the valley, were proceeding with vigor. Gen. GARZA was in command of the defences. The French headquarters had been removed from Puebla, a garrison of 4,000 men only remaining. MARQUEZ, in the French interest, is said to have moved toward the Capital with 7,000 men, and the French General, BAZAINE, with 9,000.

abstract: And emancipation
snippet: And emancipation
lead_paragraph: The politics of Missouri were never in a condition of more violent excitement than at the present time. The ordinary "high-pressure" action of everything personal, political and military, in that State, has just received a heavy fillip in the reassembling of the State Convention, charged now with the duty of relieving that Commonwealth from the curse of Slavery. We say duty, for the debate on the expediency and policy of Emancipation has long since closed, and all parties acknowledge that the hour of action has come. It is the duty of the Convention to carry out fairly and firmly the unmistakable will of the people, now fortunately in harmony with the decrees of Providence.
headline: {'main': 'Missouri and Emancipation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Missouri and Emancipation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: What does his Proclamation Withdrawing Troops Mean?
snippet: What does his Proclamation Withdrawing Troops Mean?
lead_paragraph: -- The proclamation of the Governor of New-Jersey in reference to the regiments lately sent from??? that State, is quite incomprehensible. It would seem to mean the withdrawal from Pennsylvania of the regiments of New Jersey militia just dispatched there. The militia troops raised are ordered to "return to their respective places of enrollment to be mustered out, and paid for the service they have performed," as the "necessity for their services no longer exists." The news this morning is that the rebel army is advancing upon the capital town of Pennsylvania, and no force is there sufficient to prevent it. What does Gov. PARKER mean?

abstract: The schooner Lawrena arrived at Gloucester this morning and reports that on Monday afternoon, forty miles east-southeast from Chatham, saw the schooner Marengo on fire. abstract: The State of Pennsylvania has a population of three millions. She has something like a hundred thousand soldiers in the armies of the Union. She is believed to be threatened by a rebel force estimated at ninety thousand strong. It is, undoubtedly, very desirable that the army of Gen. HOOKER should save her from the danger of rebel invasion. But it is impossible at present, it seems, to prevent invasion altogether -- though it does not seem unlikely that Pennsylvania may, for a time, be made the battle-field for contending armies.

abstract: And the Crisis; Gov. Parker's Withdrawal of Troops
snippet: And the Crisis; Gov. Parker's Withdrawal of Troops
lead_paragraph: The promptness with which Gov. PARKER, of New-Jersey, responded to Gov. CURTIN'S recent call for aid to repel the invasion of Pennsylvania, drew forth, as it deserved, very general commendation, in which the TIMES was happy to join. On the 22d inst. Gov. PARKER issued a proclamation, calling back all the troops he had dispatched to Pennsylvania, to receive their discharge.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by tolegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and, Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Brooklyn Yacht Club; Sixth Annual Regatta
snippet: Brooklyn Yacht Club; Sixth Annual Regatta
lead_paragraph: The Sixth Annual Regatta of the Brooklyn Yacht Club, which came off yesterday, was a complete success both numerically and pecuniarily. The weather, which, next to the water, is the most important thing in a regatta, was decidedly favorable; a cool breeze blowing throughout the day from the southeast, rendered the atmosphere pleasant and lessened the effect of the sun.

abstract: City Inspector, Mr. Boole's Appointment
snippet: City Inspector, Mr. Boole's Appointment
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermon, at their meeting yesterday, adopted a resolution, offered by Mr. FARLEY, inviting City Inspector BOOLE to continue to participate in the proceedings of the Board, and allowing him all the privileges of membership, except that of voting, was adopted, Mr. MCCOOL only voting in the negative. Alderman HALL waited on Mr. BOOLE and escorted him to the Chamber, when he thanked the Board for the honor they had paid him and resumed his former seat. This action will permit Mr. BOOLE to continue to be an Alderman so for as to take part in the discussions in the Board. A communication from him as City Inspector, stating his intention to perform his duties faithfully and energetically, and to give unremitted attention to the paramount duty of cleaning the streets and removing the garbage, was received and ordered to be printed in the minutes. Resolutions to donate $5,000 to the House of the Good Shepherd and a piece of land to the German Hospital, were passed over the Mayor's vetoes. The Comptroller's report of City finances for 1862 was presented and ordered to be printed. The Board adjourned to 1 P.M. on Monday, but afterward met specially at 4 o'clock, when a resolution appended to a report from the Committee on National Affairs was adopted, requesting the Comptroller to issue the $1,000,000 worth of bonds authorized by the Common Council for the Municipal Harbor Defence Commission, that the Commission may forthwith take steps to improve the City defences. A resolution by Mr. FARLEY, directing the Committee on National Affairs to confer with Gov. SEYMOUR and Senator MORGAN, of the State Harbor and Frontier Defence Commission, to ascertain what they have done or are going to do for New-York harbor, was also adopted. The resolution to annul the Broadway Railroad grant to the Harlem Railroad Company came in from the Councilmen, and was concurred in by 11 to 3, under the operation of the previous question, after slight discussion. Adjourned.
headline: {'main': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. GRANT has removed Gen. JOHN A. MCCLERNAND from the command of a corps in the Army of the Mississippi. Gen. MCCLERNAND ranked next to Gen. GRANT in that army, his Major-General's commission dating from the battle of Fort Donelson. He has not been a favorite with the regular officers of the army, and was blamed, we do not know with what measure of justice or injustice, for the failure before Vicksburgh on the 22d of May. We should not he surprised if the immediate cause of the removal of Gen. MCCLERNAND was the publication of an order of congratulation to his corps relating to their exploits, in which there were observations on the affair of the 22d of May susceptible of an unmilitary construction. -- Cin??? Commercial.

He has not been a favorite with the regular officers of the army, and was blamed, we do not know with what measure of justice or injustice, for the failure before Vicksburgh on the 22d of May. We should not he surprised if the immediate cause of the removal of Gen. MCCLERNAND was the publication of an order of congratulation to his corps relating to their exploits, in which there were observations on the affair of the 22d of May susceptible of an unmilitary construction. -- Cin??? Commercial.

abstract: If to no one else, it will be a  matter of delight to Secretary WELLES to learn that a large United States steamer was seen cruising off Chatham on Wednesday last. Only a couple of days previous the rebel brig Tacony had committed a series of daring depradations in that vicinity.
lead_paragraph: -- If to no one else, it will be a matter of delight to Secretary WELLES to learn that a large United States steamer was seen cruising off Chatham on Wednesday last. Only a couple of days previous the rebel brig Tacony had committed a series of daring depradations in that vicinity. With a celerity that could hardly have been expected, the Secretary of the Navy succeeded in getting a cruiser to the spot just two days after the pestiferous little craft had taken her departure. The large United States steamer will doubtless enjoy the soft Summer breezes of her new cruising ground, but we doubt if the pirate will be much disturbed by her presence. The most remarkable results may be anticipated from locking the safe after the spoons have been stolen. There is, of course, a strong probability that the robbers will continue to hover round the place.

abstract: Our dispatches from Harrisburgh state, that at last accounts the rebel were within four miles of Carlisle, Gen. KNIPE, in command of the small National force there, had drawn his men up in line of battle, prepared for an attack. The enemy was expected to reach Carlisle before night, but for some reason did not make his appearance. McConnellsville was entered by the rebels in force on Wednesday night, at 8 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Harrisburgh state, that at last accounts the rebel were within four miles of Carlisle, Gen. KNIPE, in command of the small National force there, had drawn his men up in line of battle, prepared for an attack. The enemy was expected to reach Carlisle before night, but for some reason did not make his appearance. McConnellsville was entered by the rebels in force on Wednesday night, at 8 o'clock. Their advance was met by the 12th Pennsylvania cavalry, who fell back after a brisk skirmish. A militia regiment also fell back somewhat precipitately; but an independent company, commanded by a Capt. WALLACE, took position in the mountains, and bush whacked the rebels with great success, killing a number of them. He is supposed to have finally retreated over the mountains. It was believed in Harrisburgh, last night, that un???ss the rebels appeared at Carlisle in very heavy force, Gen. KNIFE would give them battle. Fugitives -- fanners and contrabands -- were arriving in Harrisburgh in large numbers.

abstract: So far as all the rest of the world goes we are here at this point as yet in a fog, and I will therefore only speak of things hereabouts. This order was subsequently changed to New-Creek, twenty miles distant.

abstract: Invasion--numbers of the enemy
snippet: Invasion--numbers of the enemy
lead_paragraph: Was Pennsylvania, invaded two weeks ago by 1,500 or 50,000 rebels? Who knows? The Government at Washington evidently thought the latter number, or they would nor have called for 120,000 volunteers to repel the invasion. But as yet there has been no evidence whatever that the danger menacing the North which called forth such herculean preparatians for repulsion, came from over a couple of thousand of JENKINS' guerrilla cavalry.

abstract: Spence, Mr., of Liverpool, Rebel Agent His Tribulations
snippet: Spence, Mr., of Liverpool, Rebel Agent His Tribulations
lead_paragraph: An alliance between a young reprobate and the broker against his "governor" is not an uncommon thing; but it is a ticklish arrangement, and requires discretion. These young blades have high notions, and it don't do for their business agents to be too free with them. It is not enough that Overreach should be very prompt in his supply of funds -- not enough, even, that he should keep very shady about filial obligations and all that sort of thing -- he must make it a point to humor all the young fellow's foibles, and particularly to keep a civil tongue in his head at all times.

abstract: The navy has once more been stirred up by the depredations of the privateers. Hardly had the steamers returned which were sent away a few days since, and reported their failure to discover the whereabouts of the pirates, than orders were received here to prepare once more all available vessels, and to charter every fast one to be had.
lead_paragraph: The navy has once more been stirred up by the depredations of the privateers. Hardly had the steamers returned which were sent away a few days since, and reported their failure to discover the whereabouts of the pirates, than orders were received here to prepare once more all available vessels, and to charter every fast one to be had. The steamers Gertrude and Granite State, both captured prizes, are finishing rapidly at the Navy-yard, and will be sent to sea immediately. A tugboat was dispatched, on Wednesday evening, after the steam frigate San Jacinto, with orders to bring her back, and dispatch her after the Tacony, but she was too far out to sea. Yesterday Rear-Admiral PAULDING succeeded in chartering the splendid ocean steamships Atlantic, Baltic, Star of the South, and others. The fleet arrived at the Navy-yard last evening, and will be outside the lights to-day. The new steam corvette Shenandoah has received her sailing orders at Philadelphia, and will join the chase; the bark Ethan Allen has gone from the Boston Navy-yard, and the new steamer Hawquch, built at East Boston, by BROWN & LOVELL, been chartered for instant service. The splendid steam frigate Susquehanna, which accompanied the Niagara on the cable expedition, has been hauled alongside the wharf at the Brooklyn Yard to be fitted out: and, indeed, every vessel that possesses any sea-going qualifications will be in the hands of the constructors and fitters-out for the next few days. The following is a recapitulation of the squadron now about to participle in the chase:

abstract: It is no discredit to any community to be "alarmed" by the announced approach of the public enemy. The discredit and the disgrace consist in remaining "alarmed" after time has elapsed and been unimproved for ascertaining the extent of the danger, and preparing to meet it.
lead_paragraph: It is no discredit to any community to be "alarmed" by the announced approach of the public enemy. The discredit and the disgrace consist in remaining "alarmed" after time has elapsed and been unimproved for ascertaining the extent of the danger, and preparing to meet it. The two Cities of Harrisburgh and Pittsburgh, Penn., at the present moment present a striking contrast of the extremes of good and bad cond???ct of communities in the presence of danger. When Harrisburgh was first wakened from its dream of peace, and assured that the rebels were approaching, scenes of the wildest panic and confusion ensued. The utmost exertions of Gov. CURTIN and Gen. COUCH were put forth almost without avail to rally the people of the place to the duty of self-defence. Their prevailing emotion was that of terror, manifested in offers to dispose of goods and property at any price, and in efforts to flee the town in cars, carriages and on foot, to some unknown and unthought-of place of safety.

abstract: The elevation of Mr.  BOOLE to the office of City Inspector, has been received with singular favor by all parties, people and papers. Few men have reached the purple of office amid more general acclamations.
lead_paragraph: -- The elevation of Mr. BOOLE to the office of City Inspector, has been received with singular favor by all parties, people and papers. Few men have reached the purple of office amid more general acclamations. Something of this is due to the belief that Mr. BOOLE is acquainted with the duties and dangers of the office, and will discharge the one and avoid the other to the best of his ability. But perhaps more is to be ascribed to the popular respect for the old saying, that a new broom sweeps clean. The virtues of a besom may not be apparent in every walk of life, but in our public promenades they are very conspicuous, and it is not a sweeping assertion to say that, in him who inspects the thoroughfares, the virtues aforesaid are all important. Mr. BOOLE is our new broom, and it is confidently hoped that he will cleanse the foulness of the Metropolis, and once more make it fresh and wholesome to sight and sense. In what way Hercules BOOLE proposes to set about "his wonders to perform," does not yet appear. Perhaps those dirty and dusty dragons, the sweeping-machines, will once more make their appearance in the streets, scattering confusion and pulverized trap-block among the store-keepers, and bringing comfort to the hearts of the curious in clumsiness. Or, about midnight, we may again behold in Broadway, as of yore, a creature of vaguely bucolic instincts, bearing in his hand a watering-pot, and in an idiotic horticultural effort, vainly endeavoring to cultivate Belgian pavement. In whatever way the broom may make its mark, we shall be content, provided it sweeps clean.
headline: {'main': 'THE NEW BROOM.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE NEW BROOM.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The rebels talk  wildly about marching through Pennsylvania. Probably they will not try it. They profess great contempt for the militia troops that may be sent against them. We hope their contempt will not be justified by events. Even if the State cannot at once organize a great  army to meet them, the people ought to make the march of a rebel force for any distance impossible.
lead_paragraph: -- The rebels talk wildly about marching through Pennsylvania. Probably they will not try it. They profess great contempt for the militia troops that may be sent against them. We hope their contempt will not be justified by events. Even if the State cannot at once organize a great army to meet them, the people ought to make the march of a rebel force for any distance impossible. If regiments and companies of cavalry and infantry will everywhere hover around and fall upon the front and flank of the force attempting to advance, it will not advance very far. It would be a comparatively easy matter for an army to march through the South after the main rebel army is defeated, for the South is nearly exhausted of fighting men. But not so with any Northern State. Even now, without a single great battle, we believe that twenty thousand Pennsylvania militia, horse and foot, aided by an equal number of New-Yorkers, could drive into Virginia all the rebels on this side of the Potomac by simply operating in the way we have suggested.

abstract: The enemy finding that Gen. PLEASANTON was moving back, ventured to come out of the Gap (Ashby's) and make an attack upon our rear, to-day. A portion of the column was halted and the advance of the enemy was checked. Their attack did not create any alarm, nor were many lives lost. A.P. HILL'S corps is known to be in the Gaps, and EWELL'S just beyond in the Shenandoah Valley.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLEBURGH, Va., Tuesday, June 23, 1863.

abstract: Foote, Admiral, the Death of
snippet: Foote, Admiral, the Death of
lead_paragraph: It is remarkable that during the war we have, until the death of Admiral FOOTE, lost none of our great naval commanders, -- and even he died of disease, and not by the hand of the enemy. Of brave and distinguished Generals, our losses have been enormous; and from the death of Gen. LYON, at Springfield, down to the death of Gen. BERRY, at Chancellorsville, nearly every field of any magnitude has been reddened by the blood of some brave officer who had the single or double star upon his shoulder. But, though our heavy naval battles, by river and sea, run up to at least a score, and though our commanders have bared their brave breasts to every danger, Death has strangely spared them from his darts. DUPONT, FARRAGUT, STRINGHAM, the two PORTERS, WORDEN and others, who fought our first naval battles, are still among us, and only one of them, so far as we remember, has even been wounded.

abstract: The Siege of
snippet: The Siege of
lead_paragraph: It is now forty days since the siege of Vieksburgh was commenced. It was on the 18th of May -- the day after that on which was fought the last of the five-victorious battles which illustrated GRANT'S march, that the investment of the city was effected. The three corps of the army moved up to the siege work after their field-struggles with irresistible determination and unflinching valor -- SHERMAN's corps on the right, MCPHERSON's in the centre and MCCLERNAND's on the left. During these forty days, the hard labors of the siege have been prosecuted steadily and unintermittingly. By day and by night, the great siege guns have flung their tremendous projectiles into the doomed city; while several times in the day and night, the bells of the clocks of Vicksburgh gave the signal to our mortar-boats in the river to open their fires and throw their death-laden bombs among the rebels. Latterly we have been informed that Gen. GRANT was about to use red-hot shot in his bombardment, which would probably have the effect of at least destroying the town; but as its people are all said to have taken refuge in caves dug in the hill-sides, they might escape any serious inconvenience from this cause. Since the general assault made upon the rebel works, four days after investment, nothing farther of the kind has been attempted -- though Gen. GRANT's action in dismissing from command Gen. MCCLERNAND, who was mainly blamed for the failure of that attack, indicates that GRANT did not consider the failure to take the works by storm to be owing to their impregnability to direct assault.
headline: {'main': 'The Siege of Vicksburgh.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Siege of Vicksburgh.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A terrible tragedy occurred at a late hour on Thursday night, in the Twentieth Ward, which resulted in a woman named Mrs. JOHN PARE taking her own life by means of a dose of strychnine. lead_paragraph: A terrible tragedy occurred at a late hour on Thursday night, in the Twentieth Ward, which resulted in a woman named Mrs. JOHN PARE taking her own life by means of a dose of strychnine. The particulars of the affair are briefly these: Mr. JOHN PARR, residing at No. 583 Eighth-avenue, by occupation a hardware merchant, has for some time past had in his employ a good looking girl, who goes by the name of NELLIE. She was formerly a servant in the family, but recently she had been promoted to the position of housekeeper for Mr. PARR, and had been treated as one of the family.

abstract: The people turn to the newspapers daily, with anxiety never surpassed in the war, to learn the military situation around Washing- ton.
lead_paragraph: The people turn to the newspapers daily, with anxiety never surpassed in the war, to learn the military situation around Washington. Is LEE's army in the Shenandoah Valley, or is it in Maryland? Is it moving upon Baltimore and Washington, or is it advancing into Pennsylvania? And then as to our own army -- where is it and what is it doing? Is HOOKER moving to head off the invasion and drive the rebels back whence they came, or is he striving to get into the rear of LEE's army and prevent its return to Virginia; expecting then to grind it to powder between Northern militia and his own host of men and power of artillery?

snippet: State Defence, the Duty of
lead_paragraph: One of the newspapers published in Wash- ington, reflecting accurately, we have no doubt, the sentiments of the war Department, observes that the most deplorable fact involved in the present situation is, certainly, "the apparent utter incompetency of the people of Pennsylvania to protect themselves, and aid the cause, even to the poor extent of driving their horses and cattle North, and concealing their coveted other goods, before the different little squads of rebel cavalry pounce on them."

abstract: Preparations at Pittsburgh; Spirited Preparations against Invasion
snippet: Preparations at Pittsburgh; Spirited Preparations against Invasion
lead_paragraph: We commended highly the City of Pittsburgh, yesterday, for its spirited and thorough action in preparing to meet the rebel invasion. We stated that the stores had all been closed for a week, and the citizens had turned out almost en masse, and from 8,000 to 10,000 were working on the fortifications. We now find that we did not, in this honorable statement, do that brave community much over half justice. The Pittsburgh Gazette, of Thursday, says: "The work is progressing on a gigantic scale -- 14,000 men at work to-day; and these 14,000, with 14,000 more to back them, can lay down their picks and shovels, and take up muskets and rifles, or man the batteries." And the Gazette expects the people not to be contented with the defence of their city, but to take up arms and "march" to meet and expel the invader. That is a glorious voice to come up from the hallowed site of old Fort Duquesne. In sight of Pittsburgh the dark struggle took place which brought out the military genius of GEORGE WASHINGTON; and it is a happy omen that in the present day of Pennsylvania's discouragement and humiliation, a spirit so dauntless shines out near the field of WASHINGTON's maiden battle.

abstract: The Indian De  partment has news of the assemblage of 10,000 warlike Indians of different tribes at Fort Larned, Kansas. It is thought that unless they are soon enlisted to fight for the Union, they will give us much trouble.
lead_paragraph: -- The Indian De partment has news of the assemblage of 10,000 warlike Indians of different tribes at Fort Larned, Kansas. It is thought that unless they are soon enlisted to fight for the Union, they will give us much trouble. Five hundred thousand dollars were distributed among them some time since by the Commissioner of Indian Affairs to keep them peaceable, and he now urges upon the Secretary of War the propriety of enlisting them into our military service.

abstract: Gov. CURTIN last evening received information that the rebels occupied Gettysburgh yesterday with ten regiments of infantry, and with cavalry and artillery.
lead_paragraph: Gov. CURTIN last evening received information that the rebels occupied Gettysburgh yesterday with ten regiments of infantry, and with cavalry and artillery. It is supposed that this force intends to strike the Northern Central Railroad, either at Hanover Junction or York, distant about thirty miles. The Governor also received information that the rebels were holding all the passes of South Mountain. Gen. EWELL, it appears, entered Chambersburgh on the 24th. On that day he issued an order to the inhabitants forbidding them to sell liquor to his soldiers, and admonishing persons not in the military service to abstain from all acts of hostility, under penalty of being dealt with in a summary manner. On the approach of the rebels to Carlisle on Thursday evening, Gen. KNIPE, not feeling strong enough to hold the place against so large a force as was supposed to be coming, evacuated it. He reported the rebel force at ten thousand. Up to a late hour last night, the rebels had not occupied the place, though they were expected to do so immediately. It is believed that EWELL's main force has halted back of Chambersburgh, with the intention of awaiting reinforcements -- holding, in the meantime, all the roads and passes in the vicinity.

abstract: Foote, Rear Admiral A. H.
snippet: Foote, Rear Admiral A. H.
lead_paragraph: The public will not be unprepared to learn of the demise of Rear Admiral ANDREW H. FOOTE. The painful disease under which be has suffered (albuminuria) left no hope of his recovery, and for days his friends have waited, with what resignation they could, for the hour of his departure. He died last night, at half-past 10 o'clock, at the Astor House, and is now beyond all mortal anguish.

abstract: The steamship Champion arrived at this port yesterday from Aspinwall, which port she left on the 17th inst. She brought $187,000 in treasure. Everything was quiet on the Isthmus. The news from Central and South America is of no importance.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Champion arrived at this port yesterday from Aspinwall, which port she left on the 17th inst. She brought $187,000 in treasure. Everything was quiet on the Isthmus. The news from Central and South America is of no importance. Capt. LEACH, of the ship George Green, had made a statement before the American Consul at Callao, relative to the piratical steamship alleged by him to have been seen off-Cape Horn. His story is very circumstantial. It is conjectured, however, that the steamer seen might have been the British steamer Fusi Yama, bound to San Francisco, which was off Cape Horn about the same time.

abstract: Friday was the last of the three days' race meeting on the Centreville Course, the programme of which has been so honorably carried out to the letter by Capt. T.G. MOORE, of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: Friday was the last of the three days' race meeting on the Centreville Course, the programme of which has been so honorably carried out to the letter by Capt. T.G. MOORE, of Kentucky. The attendance was no doubt affected to a considerable extent by the action of some trotting men interested in a trot to take place yesterday afternoon -- one of whom almost engrossed the entire attention of the crowd at the Centreville, on Thursday, by the most noisy demonstrations and offers to bet fabulous amounts of paper that his horse would beat all the rest of the trotters in the coming match. At all events, the running races yesterday were comparatively deserted for a trot which might have been put off to another day, and the threatened rain prevented many more from attending, notwithstanding which, Capt. MOORE called upon the judges and timekeepers to enter upon their duties, and ordere the bell to be rung for the horses to come up to the stand for the

abstract: Resignation of Gen. Comonfort and Gov't Reply
snippet: Resignation of Gen. Comonfort and Gov't Reply
lead_paragraph: The Mexican papers have published the two following documents, comprising the correspondence between COMONFORT and the Mexican Government respecting the affair of the 8th of May with the French, in which COMONFORT was defeated. Gen. COMONFORT, in his official account of that affair, insinuated that the Government was responsible for his defeat, because it prescribed to him the mode of operation. The Government, in reply, deny the responsibility, telling COMONFORT that, although the necessity of introducing provisions into P???ebla was declared imperative, they did not interfere with the movements, which, as Commander-in-Chief, be ought to put in practice to bring about the above result.

abstract: We have a few additional particulars of the cavalry fight in Loudon, last week, and from these we learn that the affair was one of much more importance than was at first supposed. Our information represents that the enemy were driven out of Middleburgh, on Wednesday evening, by the brigade of Gen. ROBERTSON. On Thursday morning the fight was renewed, and at first the enemy was driven back with the loss of some 400 prisoners, belonging to a Rhode Island cavalry regiment.

abstract: -JOHN MILLET, an Englishman, about 40 years of age, residing at No. 81 Elizabeth-street, died a frightful death on Thursday afternoon, at No. 84 Division-street, under the following circumstances: The c???ss-pools of Nos. 82, 84 and 86 Division-street, were being connected by means of a sewer with the street. The connection had been made from the rear yards of Nos. 82 and 86 with the street sewer, and the deceased entered the privy of No. 84 for the purpose of perforating a hole through to that of No. 82. As soon as the opening was made, the gaseous matter from the adjoining premises came suddenly upon him, with such strength that he was suffocated almost instantly, and fell back into the c???ss-pool. MICHAEL COEY, a workman in the vicinity, ran to his assistance, and promptly descended into the vault, where he, too, was suffocated and sank helplessly to the bottom. PATRICK WARD, of No. 29 East Broadway, seeing the danger in which the parties were placed descended and caught CO??? by the hair of his head and thereby saved him. The body or MILLET was afterward taken out, and on Friday Coroner WILDEY held an inquest.

abstract: The rebels have always been very much dissatisfied with our mode of carrying on the war. The entire store of epithets which, by long practice in vituperation, they had heaped up, was long ago exhausted, and of late they have only used over again the old stock.
lead_paragraph: The rebels have always been very much dissatisfied with our mode of carrying on the war. The entire store of epithets which, by long practice in vituperation, they had heaped up, was long ago exhausted, and of late they have only used over again the old stock. It has made little difference what measures we adopted. We have been as entirely unable to satisfy them by whatever course we pursued as the boatswain's mate was to satisfy the sailor who was being flogged, by striking high or low. It was the being flogged at all which was at the bottom of the sailor's dissatisfaction with the spot where the blows were laid on. And we despair of ever pleasing the rebels in our way of carrying on the war, unless, to use a Hibernicism, we cease to carry it on at all.

abstract: Interesting exercises, incident to the graduating of the senior class of Grammar School No.47, Fifteenth Ward, were held on Friday afternoon, at the school building, in Twelfth-street, near Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Interesting exercises, incident to the graduating of the senior class of Grammar School No.47, Fifteenth Ward, were held on Friday afternoon, at the school building, in Twelfth-street, near Broadway. For the occasion the main hall of the Senior Department was tastefully decorated with flowers, flags and festooned evergreens, and a select number of favored guests occupied the space not required for the scholars. Upon the platform with Miss WADLEIGH, the excellent principal of the school, were Mr. RANDALL, the Superintendent of Public Schools, Mr. BENEDICT and other members of the Board of Education, the school officers of the Fifteenth Ward, and other gentlemen interested in the cause of public education. The graduating class, numbering 27 members, all prettily dressed in white, occupied the front seats, and behind them, filling the baby of the room sat the remainder of the pupils, ??? an as???lage of young, sweet, happy faces that was very pleasant to see.
headline: {'main': 'Grammar School Commencement.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Grammar School Commencement.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Dispatch says: "We have a report that a considerable battle took place at Big Creek Gap, in East Tennessee, on Friday last, between the forces of Gen. BUCKNER and the Federal Gen. BURNSIDE, in which the enemy are said to have been repulsed, with heavy loss. BURNSIDE then commenced a flank movement, and Gen. BUCKNER fell back to cover Knoxville. The point at which the latter took up position was Clinton, within fifteen miles of the East Tennessee and Georgia Railroad. Other report's state that the enemy had possession of the railroad at Lenoir, and that they were advancing in another body and, after having been defeated at Knoxville, were retreating eastward. The telegraph wires between Bristol and Knoxville had been cut -- supposed by the Union men of East Tennessee."
lead_paragraph: The Dispatch says: "We have a report that a considerable battle took place at Big Creek Gap, in East Tennessee, on Friday last, between the forces of Gen. BUCKNER and the Federal Gen. BURNSIDE, in which the enemy are said to have been repulsed, with heavy loss. BURNSIDE then commenced a flank movement, and Gen. BUCKNER fell back to cover Knoxville. The point at which the latter took up position was Clinton, within fifteen miles of the East Tennessee and Georgia Railroad. Other report's state that the enemy had possession of the railroad at Lenoir, and that they were advancing in another body and, after having been defeated at Knoxville, were retreating eastward. The telegraph wires between Bristol and Knoxville had been cut -- supposed by the Union men of East Tennessee."

abstract: The remains of the late Rear-Admiral FOOTE were yesterday conveyed to Hartford, Conn., where a public funeral will take place, and the body will be inferred with suitable honors.
lead_paragraph: The remains of the late Rear-Admiral FOOTE were yesterday conveyed to Hartford, Conn., where a public funeral will take place, and the body will be inferred with suitable honors. A large number of persons visited the Astor House, yesterday, previous to the removal of the body, to take a last look at the gallant hero. Shortly before 3 o'clock the relatives took a parting look at the deceased, when the coffin was closed, and preparations were made for its removal. Two companies of marines from the Navy- yard, accompanied by the band of the North Carolina, escorted the remains to the New-Haven boat. The procession moved in the following order:

abstract: An authorized dispatch from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, announces that the Army is in motion, and will soon be to the front and north of Baltimore. We are enabled further to say that the entire army of Gen. HOOKER is on the north side of the Potomac, and will soon be head from by the public.
lead_paragraph: An authorized dispatch from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, announces that the Army is in motion, and will soon be to the front and north of Baltimore. We are enabled further to say that the entire army of Gen. HOOKER is on the north side of the Potomac, and will soon be head from by the public. The locations of the various corps, so far as they are known to us, it would be improper to disclose. The whole rebel army is also on the north side of the Potomac, but it is very much scattered. The last corps, under A.P. HILL, crossed at Williamsport on Friday, and was yesterday at Hagerstown. The rebels recently on South Mountain and at Boonsboro, Md., appear to have left those localities, and to be concentrating at Sharpsburgh. Rebel wagon trains loaded with grain, plundered from the farmers of Pennsylvania, have begun to return by way of Smithsburgh and Hagerstown. Large droves of Cattle, sheep, hogs and horses are also being driven in the same direction.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning a very revolting crime was committed by a man named CHRISTOPHER MCCUNE, residing in One Hundred and Twenty-second-street, between First-avenue and Avenue A. MCCUNE, with his wife, ALICE, and two children, lived in a small frame shanty on the abovenamed street. Both the parents were of dissipated habits. The husband came home at a late hour in a state of intoxication, and at once commenced to beat his wife. Weak and exhausted from the effects of the beating and the liquor which she had drank, the wife lay down on a bed beside her two children, and went to sleep. Very soon after this the brutal husband set the bed on fire, and the first intimation the wife had of his intention was the blaze which burned her hair and face. The children fortunately escaped with slight injuries, but the unfortunate woman was burned so badly that she died in two hours after being taken to the Station-house. The husband immediately fled, and at last accounts he had not been arrested.

abstract: Two weeks ago, minus a day, President LINCOLN issued his Proclamation calling upon four States for contributions of militia to aid in repelling the advance of the rebel army into Maryland and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, minus a day, President LINCOLN issued his Proclamation calling upon four States for contributions of militia to aid in repelling the advance of the rebel army into Maryland and Pennsylvania. The quota called from Pennsylvania was fifty thousand; and subsequently from New-York twenty thousand. On the same day Gov. CURTIN issued a Proclamation invoking his people to respond forthwith to the call of the President. He set forth vividly and truly the fearful danger of the State. With all the weight of his official responsibility, he held this language:

abstract: A BOY, ELEVEN YEARS OF AGE, JUST FROM THE RICHMOND PRISON -- BUILDING IRON-CLADS. --- An intelligent boy, named ROBT. HAVEN, aged 11 years, arrived in this city yesterday from Richmond, he having been confined in the Libby Prison in that city for five weeks, and was then exchanged with other Union prisoners. From the statement of the boy, it appears that he resides at Lake Providence, Louisiana, and that his father is now in the Union army under Gen. ROSEGRANS. The boy left his home in April, to go to Nashville, on business for his mother, and after getting through with it, started for home on board the steamer Minnesota, and when near Greencastle, on the Mississippi, she was fired into by guerrilas. A ball struck the bo???ler, thus disabling the steamer, and her officers surrendered. The boy during the ???ring was slightly wounded on the head by a ???ce of shell. The party on board, numbering 19, were marched by the rebels to Vicksburgh, and from thence to Richmond, and confined in the Libby prison. While in prison they were fed on pea soup and corn bread, occasionally getting a little corned beef. One day the boy managed to escape the vigilance of the sentinels and left his prison, and took a stroll through the streets or Richmond. He visited the markets, and found everything enormously high, and at the Navy-yard he discovered that the rebels had two iron-clad gunboats nearly completed. He was informed that they would be launched about the 17th of June. The boats, he said, would carry eight guns each. They have sloping sides, and, from his description, we should suppose they are something upon the plan of the old Merrimac. He also visited the Government foundry, and saw a large number of men employed in making guns of all kinds, shells, &c. About this time he was missed from prison, and soon placed back in his old quarters. He saw but few soldiers in the city; but during their stay and some two weeks since a great many troops passed through the city, on their way to reinforce Gen. LEE. The boy left Richmond on last Saturday week, and was brought to this city by Mr. E.G. WOOD, with whom he is staying until an opportunity offers for his reaching home. -- Philadelphia Ledger, June 22.
