abstract: Prize Master CROFTS, of the United States steamer Florida, who came here in charge of the prize steamer Calypso, delivered the documents found on board the prize to Judge CA???WALLADER yesterday, and the steamer was handed over to the custody of the Prize Commissioners. District Attorney COFFEE has filed a libel against the steamer, and after-the necessary publications the matter will come before the Prize Court. There is not likely to be any delay in the condemnation of the vessel from any claim made on behalf of her owners. There is abundance evidence to show the destination of the vessel. It is reported that a number of letters and other papers were found in the steamer which have been forwarded to Washington. The value of the cargo will not be known until the Court orders its discharge. -- Phila. ledger, June 23.

abstract: Unity of Force in War
snippet: Unity of Force in War
lead_paragraph: Amusing illustrations of the nature of the military system, in which some folks delight, are being afforded every day by the campaign in Pennsylvania. One journal has just congratulated the country upon the fact that the control of the militia had not passed into the hands of the National Government, or we should not have been treated to the grand spectacle of patriotic energy presented by the recent departure of so many volunteers to the aid of Pennsylvania. If armies were raised for the sole purpose of proving the National courage, we should take as much delight in this exhibition as anybody, but we know by sorrowful experience that an army is raised to fight and win battles, and that an army which is not in a condition to do this, is simply a victim led to the altar. An army which marches to meet an enemy which it has no chance of defeating, may be an admirable spectacle, but it can never be a cheering one. For this reason, our last "great uprising," or rather the necessity for it, is mainly a source of regret and humiliation. We read that on the arrival of the Seventh regiment at Philadelphia, Gen. HALLECK ordered it to report at Baltimore, and not at Harrisburgh, as according to its instructions when it left home. The Colonel proceeded to obey, but telegraphed to Gov. Seymour for his "sanction."

abstract: The Navy Department on Friday caused to be chartered here the steamer Thomas G. Scott and the bark Golden Murray, in addition to those whose names were printed on Friday. The Secretary of the Navy did not see fit, up to 4 o'clock...
lead_paragraph: The Navy Department on Friday caused to be chartered here the steamer Thomas G. Scott and the bark Golden Murray, in addition to those whose names were printed on Friday. The Secretary of the Navy did not see fit, up to 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, to incur the marine risk of the Baltic and Atlantic, and those vessels are not to join the chase for the present. The steamer United States, on her return, was rechartered last evening, and will leave this morning at 5 o'clock. The new steamer Gov. Buckingham, which has never been to sea, will probably be purchased -- $50,000 being the price offered. She is a splendid ship, and can steam, it is said, from twelve to fifteen miles an hour. The Thames is lying at the Navy-yard wharf under an old charter, which will probably be renewed. The Honduras will leave this evening, and the Ericsson was to have gone last night

abstract: King WILLIAM and VON BISMARK seem to  have adopted the political maxim of STRAFFORD "Thorough and thorough." No half measures for them, any more than for the "Great Apostate."
lead_paragraph: King WILLIAM and VON BISMARK seem to have adopted the political maxim of STRAFFORD -- "Thorough and thorough." No half measures for them, any more than for the "Great Apostate." No half measures for them, any more than for the "Great Apostate." They will keep no terms with the Constitution or the nation. Not content with closing the Chambers and dispersing the Deputies, they have now undertaken to muzzle the Press -- the sole remaining organ of the people. If they can prevent it, Prussians shall neither hear of their wrongs, nor read of them -- there will be henceforth in Prussia no political discussions, oral or scriptoral -- no censure of Monarch or Ministers, but universal silence and submission. The people must furnish the Government with men and money, whenever and to what extent soever, and for what purpose soever it pleases, and yet are not to have even the poor privilege of remonstrance when men and money are squandered, or when damaging or ruinous policies are adopted. Such is to be Prussia's liberty in the future, according to the new programme of VON BISMARK and his royal master!
headline: {'main': 'The Progress of Despotism in Prussia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Progress of Despotism in Prussia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This gentleman, whose presence among us has caused some sensation, on account of the peculiar circumstances attending, has departed as quietly as he came. After spending a day in Petersburgh. Va., he proceeded on Tuesday last to Wilmington, in charge of Judge OULD, who will see him safely on board a steamer for the port of Nassau. Thence we suppose he will go to Canada, where he can engineer the election campaign in Ohio, or, if he is disposed to try conclusions with the Administration at once, he may take steamer direct for New-York City, and claim the protection of the 30,000 peace men, who declared in assembly that free speech and personal liberty must and should be secured to citizens of the Empire State.

abstract: -We learn that Messrs. L.W. & P. ALMSTRONG, of this city, owners of the bark Morning Star, have received a letter from Capt. MANSFIELD, stating that on his passage from this port to Arroyo, P.R., he was chased for seven hours by a piratical vessel, but that he succeeded in escaping, and arrived safe at his port of destination. Advices from the West Indies state that piratical vessels are numerous in those waters, and many vessels have narrowly escaped capture. -- New-  Haven Journal, June 23.

abstract: Turkey, the Condition of

abstract: The rebels have repeatedly of late hung, and otherwise put to death in the most barbarous manner, such negro soldiers of the Union army as they have taken prisoner in battle. The details of their massacre, in cold blood, of 200 negroes at Franklin, La., and of others at Milliken's Bend, and again, at Port Hudson, have been published in our columns.
lead_paragraph: The rebels have repeatedly of late hung, and otherwise put to death in the most barbarous manner, such negro soldiers of the Union army as they have taken prisoner in battle. The details of their massacre, in cold blood, of 200 negroes at Franklin, La., and of others at Milliken's Bend, and again, at Port Hudson, have been published in our columns. To this crime, they have, with in the past fortnight, added the atrocity of seizing and carrying into Slavery a large number of free-born black men, women and children from Pennsylvania. To these matters, in their military aspect, and legally viewed, we have already called attention. We now add, for the information of our military officers, and to refresh the memory of the Government, the special law applicable to the case, adopted by our own authorities.

abstract: Reed, Lieut., Pirate, Record of and Capture; Portland Harbor; the Bark Tacony; the end of Pirate Lieut. Reed's Record
snippet: Reed, Lieut., Pirate, Record of and Capture; Portland Harbor; the Bark Tacony; the end of Pirate Lieut. Reed's Record
lead_paragraph: We yesterday published a series of dispatches from Portland, Maine, giving the particulars of a daring raid made into Portland harbor, on Friday night, by a party of rebels under command of Lieut, REED, from the pirate bark Tacony, who succeeded in running out the revenue cutter Caleb Cushing, and putting to sea with her. The Cushing was provisioned for a two months' cruise. The packet steamers Chesapeake and Forest City were immediately armed and manned and started in pursuit. The rest of the story is told in the following telegrams:

abstract: THE PREVALING FASHION OF EMBROIDERY WORK on articles of ladies' dress is greatly facilitated by having the labor performed by machinery. Manufacturers respectively announce that their machines will sew, hem, braid, bind, fell, tuck, cord, gather, etc., etc., but we know of none that possesses the faculty of embroidering but the "GROVER AND BAKER." Some articles of ladies' wearing apparel have been shown us embroidered by this machine. The only difference we could perceive between work thus performed and that done by hand labor is, that the former is more regular, and consequently more beautiful. It is more rapidly, and, of course, less expensively executed in this way. -- Home Journal.

abstract: The old familiar disputes as to which General is getting the better of the other in strategy are beginning to rage again, and they are just as vain now as ever they were.
lead_paragraph: The old familiar disputes as to which General is getting the better of the other in strategy are beginning to rage again, and they are just as vain now as ever they were. It would save the public a great deal of useless vexing of the brain, if they would remember that it is not possible and will not be possible to decide whether LEE has outwitted HOOKER or HOOKER LEE, until the campaign is over. The operations in war can only be judged of by their results, which accounts for the fact that for the one strategical writer who is able to foretell how a battle or a series of manoeuvres will end, there are a hundred who knew how they would end after they are over. When the victory is won, we all know why it was won, and are astonished by the imbecility of the vanquished; but the number of us who can warn the vanquished of his impending fate is exceedingly small, and it were much to be wished that the number of those who occasionally undertake that task were still smaller. Whether HOOKER committed a grave error in letting LEE reach the Potomac without attacking him, we shall be better able to judge when we see in what position the rebel force will be a month hence. We have had in the course of the war abundant demonstration of the truth that the object of war is not to fight battles, but to destroy armies, or render them incapable of continuing their resistance. So that if LEE's arrival in Maryland should prove instrumental, let it be ever so slightly, in bringing about his final and complete overthrow, it will matter little whether he got there through HOOKER's neglect or through his design.
headline: {'main': 'Strategy of the Campaign.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Strategy of the Campaign.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: I have barely more than time to announce to you by this morning's mail, that the whole Army of the Cumberland is in motion. The silence of five months is broken by the tramp of solid columns marching on to meet the enemy once more the same enemy which on the first day of the present year was driven from his position at this place.

abstract: The record of the week is unusually scanty. Not a single novelty has been produced at any of the Broadway theatres, of which three only remain open. The regular season is ended, and we are now in the dead calm that precedes the fitful Summer one. Mr. WALLACK brought his campaign to an end on Monday last. Every one will be glad to hear that it was in the highest degree successful. Half a dozen theatres, conducted with similar purpose and pains, would also succeed in New-York. The company will reassemble in September next for the regular performances. It is rumored also that a few of the number will essay a Summer season, playing light pieces in the approved style. Mr. MARK SMITH commences his experiment at the Winter Garden on Monday next, and will be supported by an excellent company. Miss EMILY THORNE and Mr. DAN SETCHELL are both members of it, and the personeile generally is of a kind to warrant the most pleasant anticipations. Mr. MARK SMITH has a widespread and well-earned reputation, which will, we hope, avail him now.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF SICK AND WOUNDED SOLDIERS.  Between three and four hundred sick and wounded soldiers arrived in the steamer Cosmopolitan, from Newbern, yesterday. abstract: -- Clinton Cassidy, brother of one of the editors of the Albany Argus, died on June 26, of consumption. He was educated at Mt. St. Mary's College, Maryland, and at Worcester, Mass. As President of the Young Men's Association, as Assistant Adjutant-General, and afterward as City Attorney, he discharged, his duties faithfully and conscientiously, and always with ability and success. To the last mentioned office he was reelected, several weeks ago, without a dissenting vote.
lead_paragraph: -- Clinton Cassidy, brother of one of the editors of the Albany Argus, died on June 26, of consumption. He was educated at Mt. St. Mary's College, Maryland, and at Worcester, Mass. As President of the Young Men's Association, as Assistant Adjutant-General, and afterward as City Attorney, he discharged, his duties faithfully and conscientiously, and always with ability and success. To the last mentioned office he was reelected, several weeks ago, without a dissenting vote.

abstract: The larger portion of our City military being absent in Pennsylvania, the military parade on the Fourth of July will necessarily be small. What there is left, however, will parade, in obedience to an order from Maj-Gen. SANDFORD. Division line will be formed on Fourteenth-street, right on Fifth-avenue, at 8 o'clock A.M., and the honor of a marching salute will be tendered to the Mayor and Common Council, in front of the City Hail, at 10 o'clock. Company G, (veterans,) Fourth National Guard, will fire the National salute at the Battery at 12 o'clock.

abstract: the new commander of the Potomac army
snippet: the new commander of the Potomac army
lead_paragraph: The country will be astounded by the news from Washington this morning that Gen. HOOKER has been relieved from the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. MEADE appointed as his successor. We have had no hint that a change was anticipated; and probably it has not been anticipated long. No reasons for the change are given; but it is doubtless owing to the fact that the Government has at last come to entertain the feeling so widely prevalent in the country, of a want of that perfect confidence in Gen. HOOKER, which is so essential at a crisis like this. During the recent and present movements of the rebel army against Washington, the manoeuvres of Gen. HOOKER were, to a great extent, incomprehensible to the general public; but we had daily assurances from Washington that our army was being so handled and planted as to insure the circumvention of LEE in his designs. Those of us who knew what HOOKER's movements had been for the past fortnight, found in them some things that were admirable and others that were inexplicable. But we could only wait patiently for results, devoutly hoping that those who had the Government of the country and the ordering of the army in their hands, and who were thoroughly informed concerning much that was dark to mere observers, were working for the public salvation to the best of their knowledge and ability. If so it be that Gen. HOOKER has been removed for good cause, the country will cheerfully acquiesce in the removal.
headline: {'main': 'Removal of Gen. Hooker Appointment of Gen. Meade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Removal of Gen. Hooker Appointment of Gen. Meade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We give this morning, from our own correspondent, news of the advance of Gen. ROSECRANS, last week. It is supposed the rebels will take up a defensive position on the line of the Duck River, which our army would be ready to assault in the early part of this week. Another theory, and a more plausible one, is, that BRAGG will fall back to Chattanooga, where it would be difficult for us to attack him. ROSECRANS has heretofore been a word of victory, and we trust it will prove so now. All our armies are now in motion, if not in action.

abstract: Refugees who have reached the Army of the Potomac from Richmond, represent that there was quite a panic there. Only a very small guard was left there, and many of the citizens were leaving and going to Staunton. This would seem to indicate that the Richmond people are rather uneasy at the almost total abandonment of that city by the rebel forces.

abstract: A member of Gen. ASBOTH'S Staff, from Columbus, reports Gen. PRICE with six thousand rebels in the vicinity of Island No. 37. It is said he is preparing rafts to cross the Mississippi, his object being to cooperate with the rebel force in the vicinity of Memphis. Another report says he will occupy Island No. 35, and intercept navigation. Capt. PENNOCK, of the Navy, is alert and will entrap Price.

abstract: Mr. Ruggles' Speech
snippet: Mr. Ruggles' Speech
lead_paragraph: -- Though the late Canal C onvention at Chicago failed to forward the object for which it was called, in as great a degree as had been expected, it yet did good in bringing before the country some vital facts regarding the growth and prospects of American products and American commerce, and the consequent necessities of greater and better courses and means of transit between the West and the East. By far the clearest, and at the same time most popular exposition of these facts was contained in the admirable speech of Mr. S.B. RUGGLES, of this City, of which we publish a report this morning.

abstract: Mr. LAYARD in answer to Mr. LIDDALL, stated that some time ago a murderous attack was made upon four British subjects riding upon the high road in Japan, in which one gentleman, Mr. RICHARDSON, was killed and two others wounded. Her Majesty's Government had demanded from the Japanese Government an ample apology for the outrage, the payment of ???100,000 as a penalty, and that the perpetrators of the outrage should be taken, tried and executed [a laugh] in the presence of one or more British officers, and that the family of the victim should be compensated.

abstract: The rebel Generals are carrying things with a high hand in Pennsylvania. Gen. EARLY, who is at York, with an army of 15,000 men, has issued an order levying a contribution of $150,000 beside immense quantities of flour, beef and groceries; and he has given the town twenty-fours to comply with his order. This is the first time anything of this kind has been done in the war, on either side.

abstract: It has been our boast, ever since the opening of the war, that the rebels had never gained a foothold, nor the rebel flag ever waved, in any one of the Free States of the North; that no battle had ever been fought there, and no invasion attempted. We can say this no more. Their main army is now encamped on the soil of the second State of the Union, in point of population, wealth and power. The second city of the continent is now fortifying against their approach.

abstract: -The Provost-Marshal for the Southern District, including this City, will have the military enrollment completed to-day. Some people had prophecied forcible resistance in the course of the execution of this work preliminary to the conscription. But there has been none whatever, and the citizens generally have even assisted in performing the work. In a number of the Western States there has been opposition, and we even hear of bodies of men in arms against the enrollment. But New-York has shown its patriotism and regard for law by its course.

abstract: There appears to be no longer a doubt that the whole rebel army under LEE, with the exception of STUART's cavalry, is in Pennsylvania. Thirtyseven thousand troops, with 104 pieces of artillery, had passed through Chambersburgh up to Saturday last. Gen. LEE himself, with his Staff, was in Chambersburgh on Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: There appears to be no longer a doubt that the whole rebel army under LEE, with the exception of STUART's cavalry, is in Pennsylvania. Thirtyseven thousand troops, with 104 pieces of artillery, had passed through Chambersburgh up to Saturday last. Gen. LEE himself, with his Staff, was in Chambersburgh on Saturday morning. At 11 o'clock he, in company with LONGSTREET and A.P. HILL, left that place on the Baltimore pike, in the direction of Gettysburgh and the Northern Central Railroad, and the indications yesterday were that a strong effort would be made to effect a lodgment on this side of the Susquehanna at Home point along that road. The rebels in the immediate front of Harrisburgh, up to a late hour last night, remained apparently inactive. Previous to the burning of the Columbia bridge on Saturday, a light took place, in which several companies of the Custom-house regiment, of Philadelphia, are said to have been captured. The rebels evacuated Wrightsville at 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon, and moved toward York. A number of the Twentieth Pennsylvania militia were captured at Wrightsville.

abstract: -Gen. LEE is now manoeuvring against Washington with an army a hundred thousand strong. Gen. DIX is understood to be manoeuvring against Richmond with a force of twenty or thirty thousand men. The army opposing Gen. LEE undoubtedly bears a larger proportion to his than the rebel army holding Richmond bears to that menacing it. Both capitals are held to be impregnable. The rebels have made a levy on masse of the population for the crisis; the North is calling out an immense body of militia for the emergency. It looks as if the struggle now opened must have a termination which may at last fairly be called decisive.

abstract: The clergy  men of Philadelphia held a meeting yesterday, and offered their services to the authorities to work on the fortifications of the city.
lead_paragraph: -- The clergymen of Philadelphia held a meeting yesterday, and offered their services to the authorities to work on the fortifications of the city. The bulls are bears of the Board of Brokers also resolved to adjourn early in the afternoon, to give members an opportunity to drill. The clergymen will, no doubt, blister their hands considerably in their first day's work, and the brokers will find drilling a rather hard task. But we rejoice to find such evidences of patriotism on all hands. We do not doubt that the preachers will fight well behind their fortifications; and, on a fair field, we would pit a regiment of Philadelphia brokers against Stonewall Jackson's brigade.

abstract: -We don't suppose the rebel army has ever had such fat living since it was organized as it has at this moment. There are no more half or quarter rations for the rebels now. Beef and bread they have in profusion, while they can also enjoy such delicacies as vegetables, cheese and butter. That section of Pennsylvania where they now pasture, along the south bank of the Susquehanna River -- Fulton, Franklin, Adams, Cumberland and York Counties -- is rich and overflowing with everything for man and beast. The stores of the captured towns also furnish them plenty of wearing goods, together with boots and medicines, not to speak of corn whisky, the use of which by the men has been nominally interdicted. The rebels will doubtless make the best of their stay in the healthy, comfortable, rich districts of lower Pennsylvania. But we trust that Gen. MEADE, Gen. COUCH, and the people of the North, will see that their visit be short.
lead_paragraph: -We don't suppose the rebel army has ever had such fat living since it was organized as it has at this moment. There are no more half or quarter rations for the rebels now. abstract: The sixth great trotting-match between George M. Patchen and Gen. Butler, for $5,000, will take place to-morrow (Wednesday) on the Fashion Course. It will be the last contest of the series between these famous horses, and will be two-mile heats, under saddle. It is thought by many of those most able to judge of the merits of the two horses, that Patchen has the best chance of outlasting his antagonist at two-mile heats, although he was beaten in the last saddle race of mile heats.

abstract: The body of a Mr. LOVETT was found at a late hour last evening by Mr. HOLMES, janitor of the building No. 80 Nassau-street, in a water-closet of that building.
lead_paragraph: The body of a Mr. LOVETT was found at a late hour last evening by Mr. HOLMES, janitor of the building No. 80 Nassau-street, in a water-closet of that building. The face, head and body of the deceased were very much bruised and mutilated. Officer CHOWN, of the Second Precinct Police, arrested an Englishman named THOMAS A. HENSHEN on suspicion of having committed the murder. A Coroner's investigation will take place at the Second Precinct Station-house this morning.

abstract: The Quaker City seems to  be aroused at last. Stores and factories are closing, business is pretty generally suspended, and thousands of able-bodied men are addressing themselves with becoming interest and energy to the work of organizing military companies.
lead_paragraph: -- The Quaker City seems to be aroused at last. Stores and factories are closing, business is pretty generally suspended, and thousands of able-bodied men are addressing themselves with becoming interest and energy to the work of organizing military companies. The question is not now whether Philadelphia troops shall go to Harrisburgh, or some other remote point, to meet the enemy; but whether the enemy will not come to their own city and offer them battle on the banks of the Schuylkill. Of a necessity, then, Philadelphians are aroused, and if they will bring out even one-half of their fighting men, there should be no danger of the enemy's near approach.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment to going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The commencement exercises incident to the Twentieth school year of the Mount Washington collegiate Institute took place, Friday afternoon, at the marble church, Fourth-street, near Washingtonsquare, and were attended with the most brilliant success.
lead_paragraph: The commencement exercises incident to the Twentieth school year of the Mount Washington collegiate Institute took place, Friday afternoon, at the marble church, Fourth-street, near Washingtonsquare, and were attended with the most brilliant success. The exercises consisted of thirty addresses, declamations and dialogues, in English, French and German, interspersed with music, and concluded with the distribution of prizes and diplomas by the Principal, G.W. CLARKE, A.M. The whole concluded with an interesting address to the graduating class by Rev. Dr. A.D. GILLETTE.

abstract: -- Among the names of the gallant men who fell on the 14th inst., at the second, assault of the rebel works at Port Hudson, La., is that of BENJAMIN FRANKLIN DENTON, First Lieutenant of Company A, One Hundred and Thirty-third regiment New-York Volunteers. Lieut. DENTON's death will excite a genuine sorrow in the very large number of persons in this City who knew and respected him. Prior to his entering the army he was an efficient officer of the Metropolitan Police force, having joined that organization in the dark days when party spirit ran so high, between the municipal authorities, under Mayor WOOD, and the friends of the law, that it showed true personal courage to take the side of the Commissioners and the right against mob violence. He was soon promoted to a sergeantcy upon his own merits, and continued faithful in that position until it was determined to organize the Metropolitan brigade. Then by the magnetic qualities of his character and his personal popularity, he drew around him large numbers of recruits until not only his own company was filled to the maximum standard, but there were men left to be distributed to other companies. With the modesty that always remarkably characterized him, he was content to accept the subordinate position of Lieutenant, in which capacity he left the City with his regiment, serving for some months in Virginia. The Metropolitan brigade was then ordered to the Banks Expedition, and Lieut. DENTON, although dangerously sick, insisted upon accompanying his regiment. He recovered, however, and was able to take part in every action in which his division has been engaged, always being conspicuous for his bravery. For the last three months he had been in command of his company, the Captain being detached on Provost-Marshal duty at New-Orleans, and it was while heroically leading a storming party to the rebel intrenchments that he fell. He was born at Stillwater, N.Y., and was about 32 years of age. Col. ELLSWORTH, who was murdered at the Marshall House Virginia, was his nephew.
lead_paragraph: -- Among the names of the gallant men who fell on the 14th inst., at the second, assault of the rebel works at Port Hudson, La., is that of BENJAMIN FRANKLIN DENTON, First Lieutenant of Company A, One Hundred and Thirty-third regiment New-York Volunteers. With the modesty that always remarkably characterized him, he was content to accept the subordinate position of Lieutenant, in which capacity he left the City with his regiment, serving for some months in Virginia. The Metropolitan brigade was then ordered to the Banks Expedition, and Lieut. DENTON, although dangerously sick, insisted upon accompanying his regiment. He recovered, however, and was able to take part in every action in which his division has been engaged, always being conspicuous for his bravery. For the last three months he had been in command of his company, the Captain being detached on Provost-Marshal duty at New-Orleans, and it was while heroically leading a storming party to the rebel intrenchments that he fell. He was born at Stillwater, N.Y., and was about 32 years of age. Col. ELLSWORTH, who was murdered at the Marshall House Virginia, was his nephew.

abstract: Democracy in
snippet: Democracy in
lead_paragraph: Some thirty citizens of Kentucky, of fair fame hitherto and of considerable personal influence, have called on Hon. CHARLES A. WICKLIFFE to become a Democratic candidate for Governor of Kentucky. What it means out West to be a "Democratic candidate," we hardly know. We would be glad to feel that it meant this only -- that, though elected on grounds of avowed hostility to the Administration, as were Governors PARKER and SEYMOUR, candidates so denominated will rival these two Executives in the promptitude and vigor of their efforts, whenever called on, to furnish means to suppress the rebellion. But we fear this is not the construction to be put on the candidacy of CHARLES A. WICKLIFFE, of Kentucky. He is reported as accepting the call of his friends to be a candidate, "on the platform of the Ohio State Democracy." What that platform, is may be practically interpreted from the fact that CLEMENT L. VALLANDIGHAM is the nominee of the Convention that framed it. WICKLIFFE and VALLANDIGHAM! Unhappy conjunction. The two sat near each other, all through the late Congress, and the unwonted likeness that run through their votes expresses too forcibly for misconception the political identity of the two men.

abstract: In the House of Lords on the 15th, the Marquis of Clanricarde moved for copies of any reports that may have been received from the Admiral commanding Her Majesty's squadron on the North American and West Indian station, concerning the protection
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 15th, the Marquis of Clanricarde moved for copies of any reports that may have been received from the Admiral commanding Her Majesty's squadron on the North American and West Indian station, concerning the protection from seizure or visitation afforded by the Ariadne and other of Her Majesty's ships or gunboats, by convoy or otherwise; and asked what had been the result of the remonstrances made to the United States Government by Her Majesty's Minister at Washington against the seizure of British vessels engaged in legitimate commerce. The noble Marquis recapitulated the complaints which had been made a few weeks ago in reference to the proceedings of the American cruisers, contending that they were in contravention of international law, and that it was the duty of Her Majesty's Government to reinforce the North American squadron so as to afford adequate protection to our merchantmen. He also urged that the constant seizures which were being made by the Federal fleet were not for the purpose of maintaining the blockade, but of destroying, if possible, a large and legitimate British trade which had sprung up with Nassau and Matamoras. He altogether denied the efficiency of the blockade of the Southern ports, and said it ought not to be recognized by Her Majesty's Government. He read a letter from a Lancashire manufacturer, giving details in reference to four steam merchant vessels which had successively run the blockade of Charleston seventeen times in the course of one month, conveying £120,000 worth of British goods into Charleston, and taking out £200,000 worth of cotton. The noble Lord, in conclusion, complained that the Ariadne and other of Her Majesty's ships had been employed, in contravention of international law, in convoying certain vessels engaged in commerce, while they had altogether omitted to afford protection to others.

abstract: Advices from Europe, four days later, reach us by the arrival of the steamship Hecla, at this port and the City of Baltimore off Cape Race. The news is to the 18th inst.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe, four days later, reach us by the arrival of the steamship Hecla, at this port and the City of Baltimore off Cape Race. The news is to the 18th inst. In the British House of Lords, on the 15th, the Marquis of CLANRICARDK moved for copies of any reports which had been received from the West India Station, regarding the protection afforded to merchant vessels by British vessels-of-war, and asked what had been the result of the remonstrances addressed to the United States Government against the seizure of British vessels engaged in legitimate trade. Earl RUSSELL, in reply, justified the action taken by our Government in regard to seizures, considered the blockade sufficiently efficient to be entitled to be observed, and declined to produce the documents -- whereupon the motion was withdrawn. The impression was prevalent in Liverpool and London, based by advices taken out by the China, that Gen. GRANT would be forced to raise the siege of Vicksburgh, and the rebel loan, in consequence, had rallied to one per cent, discount. The French Emperor, in view of the "capture" of Puebla, had addressed a congratulatory letter to Gen. FOREY. It was asserted in official quarters in Paris that the Emperor's policy on the Polish question was a pacific one. The Polish revolutionists are reported to have gained several important successes over the Russians. The latest reports of the Liverpool markets leave cotton unchanged in price. Breadstuffs were quiet, and Provisions flat. Consols, 92@92 1/8 for money.

abstract: It is anticipated by Col. ROBERT NUGENT, A.A. Provost-Marshal-General, that the enrollment of the names of all persons liable to do military duty will be completed to-day. It was generally supposed that the enrolling officers would meet with many difficulties, and in numerous instances would have trouble in collecting the names, Nothing of this kind has happened; in many cases the officers nave been greatly assisted by the citizens. At first, in some of the lower wards, a few refractory people were found, but Col. NUGENT put his foot down so determinedly, that it soon brought them to their senses. A few people, it is known, nave given false names, but that is a matter of very little consequence. For, if a man's name is JOHN SMITH, and he has passed himself off to the enrolling officer as ALGERNON DE COURCY, from that moment JOHN SMITH becomes a myth and ALGERNON DE COURCY, if called upon, will have to shoulder a musket in his stead.

abstract: We all hope that within a few weeks LEE'S army will have suffered so signal a repulse that he will be forced to retire into Virginia in such a broken, disorganized and demoralized condition, that he will be incapable of standing his ground anywhere on this side of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: We all hope that within a few weeks LEE'S army will have suffered so signal a repulse that he will be forced to retire into Virginia in such a broken, disorganized and demoralized condition, that he will be incapable of standing his ground anywhere on this side of Richmond. This is the very least that even-moderate men lock for. There are, doubtless, numbers of ardent and impassioned people who are quite certain that the whole force will be "bagged," and the rebellion thus brought to a sudden and ignominious close; but the great mass of the community are now sufficiently chastened by experience not to share in these "tender morning visions." The sober multitude asks but for a victory -- one that will drive the invader over the frontier -- and will not complain if he escape utter annihilation. And we admit we think this a reasonable and proper expectation, and one which, after making every allowance for the uncertainty of war, ought to be gratified.

abstract: The adventures of the rebel privateer Tacony along the Atlantic seaboard, almost in sight of our harbors the impunity with which she captured and burnt the numerous craft she encountered, until her victims numbered...
lead_paragraph: The adventures of the rebel privateer Tacony along the Atlantic seaboard, almost in sight of our harbors -- the impunity with which she captured and burnt the numerous craft she encountered, until her victims numbered almost, if not quite, half a hundred -- and finally the facility with which she was obliterated from the face of the sea, and the danger to our commerce not lessened but only transformed to another shape, to play the mad prank in Portland harbor, which was so near a complete success -- must open the minds of our people to new views of the difficulties of our situation and lead to different conclusions from those hitherto prevailing as to the best mode of protecting ourselves at sea. The privateer Tacony is a recent and wholly unannounced rebel craft. The first we hear of her she springs, full armed, into the midst of the lesser craft of our coast, and plunders and burns with an audacity and prodigal destructiveness that appals our shippers and confounds the national authorities. The Navy Department makes haste to charter and dispatch a half dozen of the best vessels it can command in pursuit. Boston capital, afflicted by the privateer's ravages, offers a bounty of $10,0000 for his capture. The entire seaboard, from Port Royal to Portland, is aroused, and by minute descriptions from the officers and crews of captured ships, the bold rover is so advertised that it can hardly fail that the many sail that swarm in pursuit will purge the sea of the offender. With this thought the country consoled itself for the stinging insult of the Tacony's outrages.

abstract: The city is at last waked up. Notwithstanding the telegrams that come from Washington that Harrisburgh is in no danger, the population within it is, and are flocking to arms with a good will. We are surrounded on all sides.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURGH, Sunday, June 28, 1863.
